text:
Creating teams and adding admins
You can view team members, add team members, assign or change roles, and manage team members.
Creating a team
To create a team in your organization, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
Click .
Click Settings.
In the Company section, click Team Management.
Click Create team which is available at the top-right corner of the page. You will be redirected to the New team page.
Enter the name of your team and click Create.

You have successfully created your team.
Adding admins to your team
You can add an existing or invite a new admin to your team. You can only add an admin to existing teams. You must be a Super Admin in your organization to add a new admin. To add an admin to your team, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
Click .
Click Settings.
In the Company section, click Team management.
Click the name of the team to which you want to add an admin.
Click Add admin.
If you want to add an existing admin to your team, then enter the name or email ID of the existing admin. You can select a relevant person from the displayed suggestions. For example, you want to add Alice Smith as an admin to your team.

Important: If you add an admin who already belongs to a team, then that specific admin is removed from the current team and added to your team.
If you want to add a new admin to your team, then select the checkbox beside Invite a new admin. To invite a new admin, follow these steps: 
Enter the first name, last name, and company's email ID of the person you want to add as an admin. For example, Lisa, Smith, and Lisasmith@hackerearth.com respectively.
Select the role that you want to assign to the new admin.

Note: If you select 'Super Admin', then all the other roles are automatically selected.
Click Save.
Note: If you want to add another admin, then click Save and add another.
A confirmation message is displayed on your screen to illustrate that an admin has been successfully added to your team.
markdown:
# Creating teams and adding admins

You can view team members, add team members, assign or change roles, and manage team members.

### **Creating a team**

To create a team in your organization, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-36-38-6752-AM.png).
3.  Click **Settings**.
4.  In the **Company** section, click **Team Management**.
5.  Click **Create team** which is available at the top-right corner of the page. You will be redirected to the **New team** page.
6.  Enter the name of your team and click **Create**.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-34-9942-AM.png)  
    

You have successfully created your team.

### **Adding admins to your team**

You can add an existing or invite a new admin to your team. You can only add an admin to existing teams. You must be a Super Admin in your organization to add a new admin. To add an admin to your team, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-36-33-6106-AM.png).
3.  Click **Settings**.
4.  In the **Company** section, click **Team management**.
5.  Click the name of the team to which you want to add an admin.
6.  Click **Add admin**.
7.  If you want to add an existing admin to your team, then enter the name or email ID of the existing admin. You can select a relevant person from the displayed suggestions. For example, you want to add **Alice Smith** as an admin to your team.
    
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-37-4716-AM.png)  
    **Important**: If you add an admin who already belongs to a team, then that specific admin is removed from the current team and added to your team.  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-36-40-0456-AM.png)
    
8.  If you want to add a new admin to your team, then select the checkbox beside **Invite a new admin**. To invite a new admin, follow these steps:
    1.  Enter the first name, last name, and company's email ID of the person you want to add as an admin. For example, Lisa, Smith, and [Lisasmith@hackerearth.com](mailto:Lisa.smith@hackerearth.com) respectively.
    2.  Select the role that you want to assign to the new admin.  
        ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-36-1854-AM.png)  
        **Note**: If you select '**Super Admin**', then all the other roles are automatically selected.
9.  Click **Save**.  
    **Note**: If you want to add another admin, then click **Save and add another**.

A confirmation message is displayed on your screen to illustrate that an admin has been successfully added to your team.

text:
Question pooling
Question pooling is the process of showing a random set of questions from a bigger list (or pool) of questions to each candidate who takes a test.
For example, assume that you have 100 MCQs in your test. You want to give a random set of 10 questions from this pool of 100 to each of the 20 candidates who take your test.
You can achieve this using HackerEarth's question pooling feature.
markdown:
# Question pooling

Question pooling is the process of showing a random set of questions from a bigger list (or pool) of questions to each candidate who takes a test.

For example, assume that you have 100 MCQs in your test. You want to give a random set of 10 questions from this pool of 100 to each of the 20 candidates who take your test.

You can achieve this using HackerEarth's question pooling feature.

text:
Creating a question pool from the HackerEarth's Library
To create a question pool from HackerEarth's Library, follow these steps: 
Navigate to the test that you have created.
In the Test details section, click Questions.
In the section to which you want to add questions, click Pooling.
Select From a library in question selection.
Select HackerEarth's library under the Select library section.

Note: HackerEarth’s Library is chosen by default.
Select the topic, for example, API testing.
Select the level of difficulty—for example, Easy. 
Select the number of questions you want to pool. For example, 4. You will be shown the number of questions available in HackerEarth's library to pool for the selected topic. The number of questions to be pooled should be less than the available number of questions for pooling.
Click Save.
You have successfully created a question pool in a section.
markdown:
# Creating a question pool from the HackerEarth's Library

To create a question pool from HackerEarth's Library, follow these steps: 

1.  Navigate to the test that you have created.
2.  In the **Test details** section, click **Questions**.
3.  In the section to which you want to add questions, click **Pooling.**
4.  Select **From a library** in question selection**.**
5.  Select **HackerEarth's library** under the **Select library** section.  
    _  
    Note_: HackerEarth’s Library is chosen by default.
6.  Select the topic, for example, API testing.
7.  Select the level of difficulty—for example, _Easy_. 
8.  Select the number of questions you want to pool. For example, 4. You will be shown the number of questions available in HackerEarth's library to pool for the selected topic. The number of questions to be pooled should be less than the available number of questions for pooling.
9.  Click **Save.**

**![Screenshot from 2023-03-24 13-46-44](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot%20from%202023-03-24%2013-46-44.png?width=688&height=416&name=Screenshot%20from%202023-03-24%2013-46-44.png)**

# Adding yourself to a team

In HackerEarth Assessments, you can add yourself to a team. This allows you to manage a team efficiently. To add yourself to a team, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Recruit by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-29-34-1927-AM.png).
3.  Click **Settings**.
4.  In the **Company** section, click **Team management**.
5.  Click **Add now**.  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-29-35-3035-AM.png)
6.  Select the team to which you want to add yourself.

7.  Click **Save**.

You have successfully added yourself to a team.

markdown:
# Becoming an admin

You can become an admin in the following ways:

*   Sign up
*   Super admin adds you from the company settings
*   Super admin adds you as an admin for a specific test with specific company-level access
*   Set a point of contact

### **Signing up**

Your company must have an existing account with Recruit. This is not applicable to Custom plans.

You can sign up as an admin.

1.  Open www.hackerearth.com.
2.  Click **FOR COMPANIES**.
3.  In the **Company Email** field, enter your official company email ID.  
    ![user_roles_permissions_2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_2-1.png?width=688&height=311&name=user_roles_permissions_2-1.png)
4.  Click **START HIRING  
    **A sign-up form will be displayed on the screen.
    
    ![user_roles_permissions_3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_3-1.png?width=349&height=333&name=user_roles_permissions_3-1.png)
    
5.  In the sign-up form, enter the following information:  
    *   Full name
    *   Company name
    *   Email ID will be populated automatically
    *   Password
    *   Contact number
    *   Job title
6.  Click **Create Account**.   
    A verification email will be sent to your email ID.
7.  Log into your official email account and verify your email ID by clicking the link provided in the verification email.  
    _Important_: You cannot proceed if you do not verify your email ID.
8.  Click **Request Invite**.  
    ![user_roles_permissions_4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_4-1.png?width=534&height=282&name=user_roles_permissions_4-1.png)  
    ![user_roles_permissions_5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_5-1.png?width=536&height=35&name=user_roles_permissions_5-1.png)

The super admin will receive a request.

###### 

Was this article helpful?

This form is used when the information you require must be uploaded as a file. For example, if you are conducting an online recruitment drive, you can use this type of form to collect the following information about running the candidate's code:

*   Feedback

Setting a language of your choice
To set the language, follow these steps:
Click on the administrator dashboard.

markdown:
# Language settings

HackerEarth Recruit supports the following languages only:

*   English
*   Japanese
*   Chinese
*   French
*   Portuguese
*   Russian
*   German

### Setting a language of your choice

To set the language, follow these steps:

1.  Click ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-30-35-6488-AM.png?width=28&height=27&name=mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-30-35-6488-AM.png) on the administrator dashboard.
2.  Click **Settings**. 
3.  In the **COMPANY** section, click **Language**.
4.  In **Company Language**[,](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003352433-Recruiter-dashboard) select a language from the list.  
    _Note_: This is the language in which the administrator dashboard will open by default when you log in.
5.  In **Allowed Languages,** you can set multiple languages.  
    _Note_: You can change the language in which the dashboard is displayed based on the languages that you have set.
6.  Click **Save Language Settings.**

You have set the language successfully.

headers.set-cookie:

__cfruid=cf5cc30220cbb21509d534a038d248f6f37b586e-1719137685; path=/; domain=.help.hackerearth.com; HttpOnly; Secure; SameSite=None

text:
Creating a question pool from HackerEarth’s library (Manually-added questions)
Note: It is assumed that you have already created a random section.
1. In the section to which you want to add questions, click Choose from library.
HackerEarth’s Library is chosen by default.
2. In the All levels list, select the level of difficulty. For example, Medium.
Important: The difficulty level and the max. marks of all the questions in a section must be the same to ensure that the testing process is fair. If you add questions of varying difficulty levels to a question pool, then some candidates may get a test that has many questions of the difficulty level Hard, while others may get a test that has many questions of the difficulty levels Easy or Medium. This will not give you an accurate assessment of the candidate’s skills.
3. In the All Topics list, select the topic that you want to add questions from. For example, Java.
Note: While there are no restrictions on the number of topics that you can select, we recommend that you select only one topic per question pool to ensure that you use this feature effectively.
4. Select the questions that you want to add to the question pool.
5. Click Add selected.
You have successfully created a question pool.
6. Click Enable pooling. 
7. Select Manually-added questions and choose the number of questions you want to show in your test in random order from the question pool.
8. Click Save.
A notification will pop up stating that Pooling setting is successfully enabled.
markdown:
# Creating a question pool from HackerEarth’s library (Manually-added questions)

_Note_: It is assumed that you have already created a random section.

1\. In the section to which you want to add questions, click **Choose from library**.

![p1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p1-1.png)

         HackerEarth’s Library is chosen by default.

2\. In the **All levels** list, select the level of difficulty. For example, _Medium_.

![p2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p2-1.png)

_Important_: The difficulty level and the max. marks of all the questions in a section must be the same to ensure that the testing process is fair. If you add questions of varying difficulty levels to a question pool, then some candidates may get a test that has many questions of the difficulty level _Hard_, while others may get a test that has many questions of the difficulty levels _Easy_ or _Medium_. This will not give you an accurate assessment of the candidate’s skills.

3\. In the **All Topics** list, select the topic that you want to add questions from. For example, _Java_.

![p3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p3-1.png)

_Note_: While there are no restrictions on the number of topics that you can select, we recommend that you select only one topic per question pool to ensure that you use this feature effectively.

4\. Select the questions that you want to add to the question pool.

5\. Click **Add selected**.  
![p4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p4-1.png)You have successfully created a question pool.

6\. Click **Enable pooling.** 

**![p5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p5-1.png)**

7\. Select **Manually-added questions** and choose the number of questions you want to show in your test in random order from the question pool.

![p6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p6-1.png)

8\. Click **Save.**

**![p7.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p7-1.png)**

A notification will pop up stating that **Pooling setting is successfully enabled**.

![p8.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/p8-1.png)

text:
Adding admins from company settings
A super admin at the company level can add you as an admin from the company settings.
1. Log in using the admin credentials.
2. Click Billings and Settings.
3. Click Team management.
4. Select the team to which you want to add or invite an existing admin.
5. Click Add admin.
6. You can either invite an Existing admin using the name or email ID or invite a new admin.
7. If you are inviting a new admin, enter the new admin’s first name and last name.
8. Enter the new admin’s work email ID.
9. Click Roles to select the role that you want to assign to the new admin.
10. Click Save.
You have successfully added an admin from the company settings.
markdown:
# Adding admins from company settings

A super admin at the company level can add you as an admin from the company settings.

1\. Log in using the admin credentials.

2\. Click **Billings and Settings**.

3\. Click **Team management.**

4\. Select the team to which you want to add or invite an existing admin.

5\. Click **Add admin**.

![Screenshot_from_2022-10-27_15-26-14.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11917068363417-1.png?width=274&height=201&name=11917068363417-1.png)

6\. You can either invite an **Existing admin** using the name or email ID or **invite a new admin**.

![Screenshot_from_2022-10-27_15-27-37.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11917065609497-1.png?width=470&height=182&name=11917065609497-1.png)

7\. If you are inviting a new admin, enter the new admin’s first name and last name.

8\. Enter the new admin’s work email ID.

9\. Click **Roles** to select the role that you want to assign to the new admin.  
![Screenshot_from_2022-10-27_15-31-17.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11917258455065-1.png)

10\. Click **Save.**

You have successfully added an admin from the company settings.

text:
Adding admins from test settings
Any super admin at the company level can add you as an admin for a specific test from the test settings.
To add an admin for a specific test, follow these steps:
1. Log in with the relevant admin credentials.
2. Click Tests.
3. Click on the test that you want to add an admin for.
4. In the Test Details section, click Overview.
5. In the Test admins section, click Add admins.
6. Click Add admins using email ID. Enter the following information:
Enter the new admin’s full name. For example, John Smith.
Enter the new admin’s work email ID.
Select the type of access that you want to give to the admin.

You can click Add another admin to add any additional admins.
7. Click Add.
Important: If you are added as an admin from the Test Settings page, you will have access only to that test. You will not have access to any other features at the company level.
markdown:
# Adding admins from test settings

Any super admin at the company level can add you as an admin for a specific test from the [test settings](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413-test-settings).

To add an admin for a specific test, follow these steps:

1\. Log in with the relevant admin credentials.

2\. Click **Tests**.

3\. Click on the test that you want to add an admin for.

4\. In the **Test Details** section, click **Overview**.

5\. In the **Test admins** section, click **Add admins**.

![Screenshot_from_2022-10-31_16-32-06__1_.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12035462279321-1.png?width=527&height=67&name=12035462279321-1.png)

6\. Click **Add admins using email ID.** Enter the following information:

*   Enter the new admin’s full name. For example, John Smith.
*   Enter the new admin’s work email ID.
*   Select the type of access that you want to give to the admin.

_![Screenshot_from_2022-10-31_16-36-28.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12035345533081-1.png?width=481&height=400&name=12035345533081-1.png)  
_

You can click **Add another admin** to add any additional admins.

7\. Click **Add.**

_Important_: If you are added as an admin from the [**Test Settings**](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413-test-settings) page, you will have access only to that test. You will not have access to any other features at the company level.

text:
Proctoring settings
You can enable one or all of the following proctoring settings to ensure that your test is plagiarism-free.
Smart Browser 
You can enable Smart Browser to enforce stricter proctoring settings in your assessments. Smart Browser provides you with various features that will help you to enable stricter proctoring settings in your assessments. When you select the Smart Browser setting, some of the settings are selected by default along with the addition of new ones. To learn more about Smart Browser, read this article. 
Random questions shuffling
You can enable random questions shuffling in the proctroing settings. This will change the order of the questions for each candidate when they start the assessment. This will make it difficult for candidates to use any unfair practices in the assessment. 
Disable the Copy and Paste feature in the code editor
When this setting is enabled, a candidate cannot copy the code (for example, from the Web or a local computer) and paste it into the code editor.
We recommend that you enable this setting if your test contains a question that requires the candidate to write code.
Important: By default, the candidates are not allowed to copy the problem statements in the test interface.
Take candidate snapshots during the test
When this option is enabled, candidates must give permission to enable the webcam on their computers. If they do not, they cannot take the test.
When the test is live, we take a snapshot of the candidate at random intervals. A thumbnail preview of the webcam will be displayed on the bottom right of the screen, which indicates that the candidates are being monitored during the test.
When should this option be enabled?
Enable this option for candidates who are taking the test remotely. Ensure that you inform them in advance that they need a webcam to be able to take the test.
Do not enable this option in the following scenarios:
If you know that the candidate does not have/have access to a webcam.
For universities where the tests are taken in the Computer labs because most computers in the lab may not have a webcam.
ID verification
When this option is enabled, candidates must upload a government ID (Aadhar or PAN) along with an image captured before the assessment, which HackerEarth verifies to ensure that the candidate taking the assessment is the same as the one in the government ID. This makes your assessment more secure and provides better proctoring for candidates while taking the assessments.
Restrict candidate to the full-screen mode during the test
You can enable this to prevent candidates from cheating. When this is enabled, candidates can take the test in full-screen mode only. A warning is displayed on the screen if they exit full-screen mode during the test. 
Disable submission results for candidates
You can enable this setting for the candidate if you do not want them to see their own submission results against programming test cases. The candidate will still be able to see the results of their submission for visible test cases and custom input.
Log out on leaving the test environment 
This setting allows you to set the number of times a candidate can move out of the test environment. The ideal number of warnings is 5, which is set by default. You can change this if required.
When this is enabled, the system gives the candidate a warning each time they move out of the test environment. The following actions include but are not limited to actions that are considered as ‘moving out of the test environment’:
Switching tabs
Switching windows
Opening new applications on the computer including system popups like anti-virus notifications, Lync notifications, Skype notifications, etc.
Important: Moving out of the test environment to close notifications is also counted as leaving the test environment.
Restrict test access for certain IP addresses
IP addresses identify specific computers. Restricting IP addresses and subnets allows you to contain the test-taking to a single location. When these restrictions are enabled for a test and a candidate tries to log in from an IP that is outside the restricted range, a warning is displayed. 
Universities use this to ensure that the test is taken only from their computer labs. You can also enable this when you invite candidates to take the test from your office premises.
Important: Do not enable this for remote tests.
markdown:
# Proctoring settings

You can enable one or all of the following proctoring settings to ensure that your test is plagiarism-free.

### Smart Browser 

You can enable Smart Browser to enforce stricter proctoring settings in your assessments. Smart Browser provides you with various features that will help you to enable stricter proctoring settings in your assessments. When you select the Smart Browser setting, some of the settings are selected by default along with the addition of new ones. To learn more about Smart Browser, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/advanced-proctoring-settings-smart-browser). 

### Random questions shuffling

You can enable random questions shuffling in the proctroing settings. This will change the order of the questions for each candidate when they start the assessment. This will make it difficult for candidates to use any unfair practices in the assessment. 

### **Disable the Copy and Paste feature in the code editor**

When this setting is enabled, a candidate cannot copy the code (for example, from the Web or a local computer) and paste it into the code editor.

We recommend that you enable this setting if your test contains a question that requires the candidate to write code.

_Important_: By default, the candidates are not allowed to copy the problem statements in the test interface.

### **Take candidate snapshots during the test**

When this option is enabled, candidates must give permission to enable the webcam on their computers. If they do not, they cannot take the test.

When the test is live, we take a snapshot of the candidate at random intervals. A thumbnail preview of the webcam will be displayed on the bottom right of the screen, which indicates that the candidates are being monitored during the test.

#### **When should this option be enabled?**

Enable this option for candidates who are taking the test remotely. Ensure that you inform them in advance that they need a webcam to be able to take the test.

Do not enable this option in the following scenarios:

*   If you know that the candidate does not have/have access to a webcam.
*   For universities where the tests are taken in the Computer labs because most computers in the lab may not have a webcam.

### ID verification

When this option is enabled, candidates must upload a government ID (Aadhar or PAN) along with an image captured before the assessment, which HackerEarth verifies to ensure that the candidate taking the assessment is the same as the one in the government ID. This makes your assessment more secure and provides better proctoring for candidates while taking the assessments.

### **Restrict candidate to the full-screen mode during the test**

You can enable this to prevent candidates from cheating. When this is enabled, candidates can take the test in full-screen mode only. A warning is displayed on the screen if they exit full-screen mode during the test. 

### Disable submission results for candidates

You can enable this setting for the candidate if you do not want them to see their own submission results against programming test cases. The candidate will still be able to see the results of their submission for visible test cases and custom input.

### **Log out on leaving the test environment** 

This setting allows you to set the number of times a candidate can move out of the test environment. The ideal number of warnings is 5, which is set by default. You can change this if required.

When this is enabled, the system gives the candidate a warning each time they move out of the test environment. The following actions include but are not limited to actions that are considered as ‘moving out of the test environment’:

*   Switching tabs
*   Switching windows
*   Opening new applications on the computer including system popups like anti-virus notifications, Lync notifications, Skype notifications, etc.

_Important_: Moving out of the test environment to close notifications is also counted as leaving the test environment.

### **Restrict test access for certain IP addresses**

IP addresses identify specific computers. Restricting IP addresses and subnets allows you to contain the test-taking to a single location. When these restrictions are enabled for a test and a candidate tries to log in from an IP that is outside the restricted range, a warning is displayed.  

Universities use this to ensure that the test is taken only from their computer labs. You can also enable this when you invite candidates to take the test from your office premises.

_Important_: Do not enable this for remote tests.

text:
Adding company-specific Terms of Use
You can define your own terms of use and add them so that candidates can see them before they begin their assessment.
To add terms of use, follow these steps:
Click on the administrator dashboard.
Click Settings. 
In the COMPANY section, click Terms of Use. 
You will see an option Add in the top right corner.
4. Click Add.
You will be redirected to a field where you can define your Terms of Use.
5. Click Save.
The text written in the field will be added to your Terms of Use.
markdown:
# Adding company-specific Terms of Use

You can define your own terms of use and add them so that candidates can see them before they begin their assessment.

To add terms of use, follow these steps:

1.  Click ![Screenshot__264_.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Screenshot__264_-1.png?width=31&height=30&name=Screenshot__264_-1.png)on the [administrator dashboard.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003352433-administrator-dashboard)
2.  Click **Settings**. 
3.  In the **COMPANY** section, click **Terms of Use**.

You will see an option **Add** in the top right corner.

![Screenshot__203_.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Screenshot__203_-1.png)

4\. Click **Add.**

You will be redirected to a field where you can define your Terms of Use.

![Screenshot__265_.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Screenshot__265_-1.png)

5\. Click **Save.**

The text written in the field will be added to your Terms of Use.

text:
Unification of libraries
This feature is enabled for all our customers. 
We have always aimed to provide the best user experience to customers. HackerEarth Assessment has introduced the feature of unifying the HackerEarth library and My library. Now, you can view all the questions according to the question types that are available in the HackerEarth library or My library on one page. 
To view this feature, follow these steps:
Log in to the HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Library on the Administrator dashboard.
Here, you can successfully view the questions that are in both the libraries, HackerEarth and My library.
You cannot edit or modify questions that are available in the HackerEarth library but you can edit questions that are available in the My library.
markdown:
# Unification of libraries

_This feature is enabled for all our customers._ 

We have always aimed to provide the best user experience to customers. HackerEarth Assessment has introduced the feature of unifying the HackerEarth library and My library. Now, you can view all the questions according to the question types that are available in the HackerEarth library or My library on one page. 

To view this feature, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to the HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Library** on the **Administrator** dashboard.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-30-46-5435-AM.png)

Here, you can successfully view the questions that are in both the libraries, HackerEarth and My library.

![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-30-43-5044-AM.png)

You cannot edit or modify questions that are available in the HackerEarth library but you can edit questions that are available in the My library. 

![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-30-45-1602-AM.png)

text:
Accepting admin requests
When a potential admin makes a request to be added as an admin, you will receive the request by email. 
To grant admin access, click the link provided in the sign-up request email.
You have successfully granted admin access.
When you accept an admin request, by default, you will receive only Test admin access. If you want to be added as any other type of admin (for example, Library admin), you will have to send an email to a super admin requesting access.
You can also add admins from the company settings and the test settings.
markdown:
# Accepting admin requests

When a potential admin makes a request to be added as an admin, you will receive the request by email. 

![user_roles_permissions_6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_6-1.png?width=688&height=225&name=user_roles_permissions_6-1.png)

To grant admin access, click the link provided in the sign-up request email.

![user_roles_permissions_7.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/user_roles_permissions_7-1.png?width=493&height=203&name=user_roles_permissions_7-1.png)

You have successfully granted admin access.

When you accept an admin request, by default, you will receive only _Test admin_ access. If you want to be added as any other type of admin (for example, _Library admin_), you will have to send an email to a super admin requesting access.

You can also add admins from the company settings and the [test settings.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413-test-settings)

text:
Deactivating a profile
To be able to deactivate a profile, you must be a Super admin.
When your profile is deactivated you will not be able to view the pages or access your account on HackerEarth Assessment.
To deactivate a profile, follow these steps:
Click Settings on the administrator dashboard.
In the Company section, click Team Management. 
Select the team from which you want to deactivate a team member's profile.
Navigate to the details of the team member whose profile you want to deactivate and click the Ellipsis icon (). Now, click Deactivate.
A confirmation modal appears on the screen. Click Yes.
You have successfully deactivated a profile. You can reactivate the profile at any time.
markdown:
# Deactivating a profile

To be able to deactivate a profile, you must be a Super admin.

When your profile is deactivated you will not be able to view the pages or access your account on HackerEarth Assessment.

To deactivate a profile, follow these steps:

1.  Click **Settings** on the administrator dashboard.
2.  In the **Company** section, click **Team Management**. 
3.  Select the team from which you want to deactivate a team member's profile.
4.  Navigate to the details of the team member whose profile you want to deactivate and click the Ellipsis icon (![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-23-6263-AM.png)). Now, click **Deactivate**.  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-36-21-2502-AM.png)
5.  A confirmation modal appears on the screen. Click **Yes**.  
    ![mceclip4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-36-22-4279-AM.png)

You have successfully deactivated a profile. You can [reactivate](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003593054-activating-a-profile) the profile at any time.

text:
Candidate snapshots
HackerEarth Assessment provides you the feature to capture and view snapshots of candidates during a test. This proctoring setting allows you to reduce malpractices or cheating in your test. 
Enabling this setting
To enable this proctoring setting, follow these steps:
Log into the HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the name of the test in which you want to enable this setting.
In the Test Details section, click Test settings.
Navigate to the Proctoring Settings section.
Select the checkbox beside Take candidate snapshot during test.
Click Yes.
Click Save Proctoring Settings.
You have successfully enabled proctoring settings for your test.
The snapshots are categorized by the number of candidates who appear in a snapshot at an instant.
Categories
The snapshots are divided into the following categories:
Multiple candidates: If there is more than one candidate in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the Multiple candidates category.
Candidate missing: If the candidate is missing in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the Candidate missing category.
Needs review: If the same person who has started attempting the test does not appear in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the Needs review category.
All snapshots: This category contains all the snapshots that are taken during a test.
Viewing snapshots
To view the snapshots that are taken during the test, follow these steps:
Log into the HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the name of the test in which you want to view the snapshot of a candidate.
In the Candidates section, click Test taken, Review pending, Currently taking, or Shortlisted to view the snapshot of a candidate.
Click the name of the candidate whose snapshots you want to view.
Click .
Click View snapshots.
You can view the different types of categories under which the snapshots are stored. The snapshots that are constituted under different categories are as follows:
Candidate missing

The white-colored exclamation mark indicates that the snapshot contains a discrepancy that has occurred during the test.
Multiple candidates

These snapshots contain instances where more than one candidate is captured in the webcam frame.
Note: Multiple candidates are differentiated by the green-colored bounding boxes. 
Needs review

These snapshots infer if the same person has attempted the test throughout the total duration of the test. The snapshot that is taken at the starting of the test is called the reference image. The snapshot of another person during the duration of the test is represented as the selected image.
If a snapshot does not match with the reference image, then it is stored in the Needs review category.
All snapshots

This category contains all the snapshots that are taken during the test.
Click on the snapshot to view the details of the photo. These details are as follows:

Date and time when the snapshot gets captured
Status of the snapshot
You have successfully viewed the snapshots that are taken during the test.
You can also view the description of the snapshots that are taken during the test in the Points to heed section. The information that is displayed for the snapshots are as follows:
No issues found in snapshots
Issues found in snapshots
Proctoring setting is not enabled when a candidate is taking the test
No snapshots of a candidate are taken during a test
Candidate's interface
HackerEarth Assessment detects the low brightness of the surrounding where the snapshot is captured and suggests to attempt the test in a bright surrounding. This allows you to view the face of the candidate clearly.
Important: This warning does not block a candidate from attempting the test.
markdown:
# Candidate snapshots

HackerEarth Assessment provides you the feature to capture and view snapshots of candidates during a test. This proctoring setting allows you to reduce malpractices or cheating in your test. 

## Enabling this setting

To enable this proctoring setting, follow these steps:

1.  Log into the HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of the test in which you want to enable this setting.
4.  In the **Test Details** section, click **Test settings**.
5.  Navigate to the **Proctoring Settings** section.
6.  Select the checkbox beside **Take candidate snapshot during test**.  
    ![arrow_code_quality.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/arrow_code_quality-Jan-30-2023-11-24-44-1876-AM.png)
7.  Click **Yes**.
8.  Click **Save Proctoring Settings**.

You have successfully enabled proctoring settings for your test.

The snapshots are categorized by the number of candidates who appear in a snapshot at an instant.

## Categories

The snapshots are divided into the following categories:

*   **Multiple candidates**: If there is more than one candidate in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the **Multiple candidates** category.
*   **Candidate missing**: If the candidate is missing in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the **Candidate missing** category.
*   **Needs review**: If the same person who has started attempting the test does not appear in a snapshot, then that photograph is stored in the **Needs review** category.
*   **All snapshots**: This category contains all the snapshots that are taken during a test.

## Viewing snapshots

To view the snapshots that are taken during the test, follow these steps:

1.  Log into the HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of the test in which you want to view the snapshot of a candidate.
4.  In the **Candidates** section, click **Test taken**, **Review pending**, **Currently taking**, or **Shortlisted** to view the snapshot of a candidate.
5.  Click the name of the candidate whose snapshots you want to view.
6.  Click ![arrow_code_quality.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/arrow_code_quality-Jan-30-2023-11-24-49-6857-AM.png).
7.  Click **View snapshots**.
8.  You can view the different types of categories under which the snapshots are stored. The snapshots that are constituted under different categories are as follows:  
    1.  **Candidate missing**  
        ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-24-52-9428-AM.png)  
        The white-colored exclamation mark indicates that the snapshot contains a discrepancy that has occurred during the test.
    2.  **Multiple candidates**  
        ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-25-00-9696-AM.png)  
        These snapshots contain instances where more than one candidate is captured in the webcam frame.  
        **Note**: Multiple candidates are differentiated by the green-colored bounding boxes. 
    3.  **Needs review**  
        ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-24-51-4361-AM.png)  
        These snapshots infer if the same person has attempted the test throughout the total duration of the test. The snapshot that is taken at the starting of the test is called the **reference image**. The snapshot of another person during the duration of the test is represented as the **selected image**.  
        If a snapshot does not match with the reference image, then it is stored in the **Needs review** category.
    4.  **All snapshots**  
        ![mceclip4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-24-57-4143-AM.png)  
        This category contains all the snapshots that are taken during the test.
9.  Click on the snapshot to view the details of the photo. These details are as follows:  
    ![snapshot_details.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/snapshot_details-1.png)  
    1.  Date and time when the snapshot gets captured
    2.  Status of the snapshot

You have successfully viewed the snapshots that are taken during the test.

You can also view the description of the snapshots that are taken during the test in the **Points to heed** section. The information that is displayed for the snapshots are as follows:

1.  **No issues found in snapshots**  
    ![no_error_snapshot.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/no_error_snapshot-1.png)
2.  **Issues found in snapshots**  
    ![errors_in_snapshots.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/errors_in_snapshots-1.png)
3.  **Proctoring setting is not enabled when a candidate is taking the test**  
    ![setting_disabled_snapshots.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/setting_disabled_snapshots-1.png)
4.  **No snapshots of a candidate are taken during a test**  
    ![no_snapshots_available.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/no_snapshots_available-1.png)

## Candidate's interface

HackerEarth Assessment detects the low brightness of the surrounding where the snapshot is captured and suggests to attempt the test in a bright surrounding. This allows you to view the face of the candidate clearly.

![mceclip5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip5-Jan-30-2023-11-24-59-0399-AM.png)

Important: This warning does not block a candidate from attempting the test.

text:
Defining access for existing admins
Prerequisites
You have added admins to your test.
For information about adding admins to your account, see Adding admins from company settings.
Process
To define access for test-level roles, follow these steps:
Log in with the relevant admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click on the test that you want to add an admin for.
In the Test Details section, click Overview.
In the Test admins section, select the Access control you want to give to your admins.

All Access	Provides the admin with all the access regarding the test	
Only Questions And Reports	Provides the admin with access to questions and reports of the test	
Only Questions	Provides the admin with access to questions in the test	
Only Reports
	Provides the admin with access to Reports of the test.	
Questions And Comments	Provides the admin with access to questions and comments in the test.
markdown:
# Defining access for existing admins

**Prerequisites**

You have [added admins to your test.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003074034-adding-admins-from-test-settings)

For information about adding admins to your account, see [Adding admins from company settings](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003096193-adding-admins-from-company-settings).

**Process**

To define access for test-level roles, follow these steps:

1.  Log in with the relevant admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click on the test that you want to add an admin for.
4.  In the **Test Details** section, click **Overview**.
5.  In the **Test admins** section, select the Access control you want to give to your admins.  
    ![Screenshot_from_2022-10-31_17-17-17.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12036389008281-1.png?width=688&height=189&name=12036389008281-1.png)  
    
    |     |     |
    | --- | --- |
    | All Access | Provides the admin with all the access regarding the test |
    | Only Questions And Reports | Provides the admin with access to questions and reports of the test |
    | Only Questions | Provides the admin with access to questions in the test |
    | Only Reports | Provides the admin with access to Reports of the test. |
    | Questions And Comments | Provides the admin with access to questions and comments in the test. |

text:
My Library (Custom library)
While the HackerEarth library has an exhaustive list of questions, you can also create your own questions for tests. These questions can be stored in your custom library or My Library.
Important: Questions that you create for a test are not added automatically to My Library. A Library admin or a Super admin must add the questions manually to My Library. 
A test admin cannot add, delete, or modify the questions in the My Library, however, they can use them while creating a test.
Advantages of using a custom library
It contains all the questions that you have created based on your requirements
You can customize and organize your questions
You can add different sections
You may add these questions to your test
If you have any one of these privileges, you can perform the following actions on the questions that are present in your custom library:
Add 
Edit
Delete 
These actions can only be done if you are a Super Admin.
You can also upload your questions in bulk. For more information, see adding questions in bulk.
markdown:
# My Library (Custom library)

While the HackerEarth library has an exhaustive list of questions, you can also create your own questions for tests. These questions can be stored in your custom library or My Library.

_Important:_ Questions that you create for a test are not added automatically to My Library. A Library admin or a Super admin must add the questions manually to My Library. 

A test admin cannot add, delete, or modify the questions in the My Library, however, they can use them while creating a test.

### **Advantages of using a custom library**

*   It contains all the questions that you have created based on your requirements
*   You can customize and organize your questions
*   You can add different sections
*   You may add these questions to your test

If you have any one of these privileges, you can perform the following actions on the questions that are present in your custom library:

*   Add 
*   Edit
*   Delete   
    

These actions can only be done if you are a Super Admin.

You can also upload your questions in bulk. For more information, see [adding questions in bulk](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360001159754-adding-mcqs-in-bulk-).

text:
Adding a payment method
You can add, view, and manage payment methods here.
There is no limit to the number of payment methods that you can add. However, you can only select only one card as your primary payment method.
Adding a payment method
Click Settings on the recruiter dashboard.
In the COMPANY section, click Payment.
Click Add New Payment Method.
In the Payment section, enter the following information: 
Credit card number
Name of the person who owns the credit card
Month and year in which the credit card will expire
Address to which you want your bill to be sent
Select Mark this card as primary to make this card your primary payment method.
The credit card that you select as your primary payment method will be used for all future transactions. You can change this at any time.
6. Click Save Card.
You have successfully added a payment method.
markdown:
# Adding a payment method

You can add, view, and manage payment methods here.

![Screenshot_from_2022-10-07_15-32-44.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11269241842073-1.png?width=572&height=383&name=11269241842073-1.png)

There is no limit to the number of payment methods that you can add. However, you can only select only one card as your primary payment method.

### **Adding a payment method**

1.  Click **Settings** on the recruiter dashboard.
2.  In the **COMPANY** section, click **Payment**.
3.  Click **Add New Payment Method**.
4.  In the **Payment** section, enter the following information:
    1.  Credit card number
    2.  Name of the person who owns the credit card
    3.  Month and year in which the credit card will expire
    4.  Address to which you want your bill to be sent
5.  Select **Mark this card as primary** to make this card your primary payment method.

The credit card that you select as your primary payment method will be used for all future transactions. You can change this at any time.

   6. Click **Save Card**.

You have successfully added a payment method.

text:
Publicly available questions
HackerEarth Assessments has introduced the feature of detecting the questions that are available on the Internet. The goal of this feature is to provide confidence to recruiters regarding the questions. The questions must be reliable and not available anywhere on the Internet. 
If a question is available online, then the Publicly available tag is associated with the question.
Click on the Publicly available tag to view the details of the question that contains the link where the question is available.
Important
This feature is applicable for both the libraries, HackerEarth library and My library, and all the types of questions. 
You can add a publicly available question to your test.
markdown:
# Publicly available questions

HackerEarth Assessments has introduced the feature of detecting the questions that are available on the Internet. The goal of this feature is to provide confidence to recruiters regarding the questions. The questions must be reliable and not available anywhere on the Internet.   
If a question is available online, then the **Publicly available** tag is associated with the question.  

![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-29-2300-AM.png)

Click on the **Publicly available** tag to view the details of the question that contains the link where the question is available.  

![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-36-27-9555-AM.png)

Important

*   This feature is applicable for both the libraries, HackerEarth library and My library, and all the types of questions. 
*   You can add a publicly available question to your test.

text:
Creating a new test
HackerEarth has introduced an improved process to create a new test. This will help you to create tests in a simple and quick manner. HackerEarth provides you with the following ways to create a test:
Test based on job role
Test based on the job description
Custom test
The new process combines all three ways into one and makes the test creation process easy and quick.
Creating a new test
To create a new test, follow these steps:
1. Log in to your HackerEarth account.
2. Click Assessments.
3. Click Create a new test.
4. Select the job role for which you want to create the test. Selecting the job role is important because it helps us to create a relevant test for the selected job role. For example, you select Backend Developer - Spring as the job role.
You can also create a new role by clicking Create new role. If you create a new role, you can customize the skills for the test. This role can be reused later.
5. You will be asked to select how would you like to add questions. If you select Automatically, the recommended skills for the job role will be auto-selected which can be modified by you. You can select a maximum of 5 skills.
If you select Manually (Custom test), you can directly click Create test to create a customized test where you can add the questions on your own.
6. You can also add more skills by clicking .
You can create tests where the skills are directly imported from the job description. Click Import skills from Job description. You can either upload the Job description or enter the Job description in the text area. We will automatically import skills for the relevant job role from the given job description. If more than 5 skills are detected in the Job description, you will need to choose 5 skills to create the test before proceeding to the next step.
7. Click Continue.
8. You can modify the settings of your assessment by entering the test name, Experience, test duration, and the relevant tags for the test.
9. Click Create test. Your test will be created
HackerEarth will try to create the test with questions from the HackerEarth library. If we are unable to find enough questions for the test from our library then you can contact support@hackerearth.com to request additional content.
markdown:
# Creating a new test

HackerEarth has introduced an improved process to create a new test. This will help you to create tests in a simple and quick manner. HackerEarth provides you with the following ways to create a test:

1.  Test based on job role
    
2.  Test based on the job description
    
3.  Custom test
    

The new process combines all three ways into one and makes the test creation process easy and quick.

### Creating a new test

To create a new test, follow these steps:

1\. Log in to your HackerEarth account.

2\. Click **Assessments**.

3\. Click **Create a new test**.

![1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337368900761-4.png?width=550&height=205&name=12337368900761-4.png)

4\. Select the job role for which you want to create the test. Selecting the job role is important because it helps us to create a relevant test for the selected job role. For example, you select **Backend Developer - Spring** as the job role.

![2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337412305433-4.png?width=509&height=361&name=12337412305433-4.png)

You can also create a new role by clicking **Create new role.** If you create a new role, you can customize the skills for the test. This role can be reused later.

![3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337368785945-4.png?width=506&height=361&name=12337368785945-4.png)

5\. You will be asked to select how would you like to add questions. If you select **Automatically,** the **recommended skills for the job role** will be auto-selected which can be modified by you. You can select a maximum of 5 skills.

![4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337368595737-3.png?width=512&height=303&name=12337368595737-3.png)

If you select Manually (Custom test), you can directly click **Create test to create** a customized test where you can add the questions on your own**.**

![5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337368595865-4.png?width=500&height=208&name=12337368595865-4.png)

6\. You can also add more skills by clicking ![8.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337530351641-3.png).

You can create tests where the skills are directly imported from the job description. Click **Import skills from Job description.** You can either upload the Job description or enter the Job description in the text area. We will automatically import skills for the relevant job role from the given job description. If more than 5 skills are detected in the Job description, you will need to choose 5 skills to create the test before proceeding to the next step.

![6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337412014489-3.png?width=477&height=328&name=12337412014489-3.png)

7\. Click **Continue.**

8\. You can modify the settings of your assessment by entering the test name, Experience, test duration, and the relevant tags for the test.

![7.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12337368462617-3.png?width=458&height=270&name=12337368462617-3.png)

9\. Click **Create test.** Your test will be created

HackerEarth will try to create the test with questions from the HackerEarth library. If we are unable to find enough questions for the test from our library then you can contact support@hackerearth.com to request additional content.

text:
IP address restriction
This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager.
You can enable IP-based restrictions for candidates and control access to tests. When these restrictions are enabled for a test and a candidate tries to log in from an IP that is outside the restricted range, the following message is displayed on the candidate’s screen:
Why IP restriction?
IP addresses identify specific computers. Restricting IP addresses and subnets allows you to contain the test-taking to a single location.
Without this restriction, candidates will either be able to access the test themselves from any location or even have someone else take the test for them.
markdown:
# IP address restriction

_This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager._

You can enable IP-based restrictions for candidates and control access to tests. When these restrictions are enabled for a test and a candidate tries to log in from an IP that is outside the restricted range, the following message is displayed on the candidate’s screen:

![restrict_ip_address.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/restrict_ip_address-1.png)

**Why IP restriction?**

IP addresses identify specific computers. Restricting IP addresses and subnets allows you to contain the test-taking to a single location.

Without this restriction, candidates will either be able to access the test themselves from any location or even have someone else take the test for them.

text:
HackerEarth library: Question types
HackerEarth provides various kinds of question types that cover different skills and programming languages. The HackerEarth library has the following question types:
Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs)
Subjective
Programming
Front end
Approximate
DevOps
Data Science
SQL
Machine Learning
Java Project
C# Project
Python Project
Diagram
Selenium
All these question types are designed to assess one or more skills. 
To know more about adding questions to your test from the HackerEarth library, see Choosing questions from HackerEarth library.
While the HackerEarth library has an exhaustive list of questions, you can also create your own questions for tests. These questions can be stored in your custom library—My Library.
markdown:
# HackerEarth library: Question types

HackerEarth provides various kinds of question types that cover different skills and programming languages. The HackerEarth library has the following question types:

1.  [Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs)](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#multiple-choice-questions-mcqs)
2.  [Subjective](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#subjective)[](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006511414-creating-subjective-questions)
3.  [Programming](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#programming)
4.  [Front end](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#front-end)
5.  [Approximate](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#approximate)
6.  [DevOps](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#devops)
7.  [Data Science](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#data-science)
8.  [SQL](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#sql)
9.  [Machine Learning](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#machine-learning-ml)
10.  [Java Project](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#java-project)
11.  [C# Project](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#c-project-questions)
12.  [Python Project](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#python-project-questions)
13.  [Diagram](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#diagram)
14.  [Selenium](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#selenium)  
    

All these question types are designed to assess one or more skills. 

To know more about adding questions to your test from the HackerEarth library, see [Choosing questions from HackerEarth library.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003662934-selecting-questions-from-the-hackerearth-s-library)

While the HackerEarth library has an exhaustive list of questions, you can also create your own questions for tests. These questions can be stored in your custom library—My Library.

# Enhanced view and edit mode of questions

_This feature is enabled for all our customers._ 

HackerEarth (we or us) is now live with an enhanced view and edit mode of questions. This enhancement helps us to attain the optimized user experience and helps you to easily view, edit, and save questions in your test. 

**Important**: Currently, this feature is enabled for Multiple choice, Programming, Data science, Machine Learning, Front end, Approximate, Golf, and Subjective questions.

The benefits of this enhanced user interface are as follows:

1.  It provides you a more simple way to view or edit any parts of a question. You do not have to scroll down an entire page to view or edit all the parts of a question because all the elements of the question are now available on the top of the page in a tabbed structure.  
    _View mode of a question_  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-39-21-2784-AM.png)  
    _Edit mode of a question  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-39-15-4474-AM.png)_
2.  It provides you a more clear picture while navigating through a question. The enhanced interface facilitates your interaction with HackerEarth Assessment's core element, that is, questions in our platform. To improve the clarity of the interface, we have used clear and concise navigation, labels, and content for buttons and actions.
3.  This enhanced interface now provides you consistent design navigation through different elements among all the supported question types. In simpler words, various elements of questions of different question types are displayed through consistent design.   
    The design of a Programming question is similar to a Data science question.  
    _Programming questions_  
    ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-39-23-8242-AM.png)  
    _Data science questions_  
    ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-39-17-2716-AM.png)
4.  This improved interface is more intuitive in terms of performing all the operations on a question in the test. The name of the new buttons and elements of the question are nearly similar to the old design for the purpose of providing you familiarity so as to increase the user interaction. Also, all the critical components of a question are provided with the necessary information.  
    For example, the terms that are used in different questions are the same, we have always used the hamburger icon to display the available menu on the page, and so on.
5.  Also, HackerEarth supports the usage of the visual hierarchy feature. All the important buttons, labels, and functions are highlighted so that you can focus on the important tasks.   
    **Example**  
    ![mceclip4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-39-25-0724-AM.png)  
    ![mceclip5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip5-Jan-30-2023-11-39-14-3081-AM.png)
6.  It provides you with a more efficient user interface allowing you to perform tasks with speed and ease. In simpler words, it easily tells you which, where, and how of the user interface.

The changes that are done in the supported question types are as follows:

#### Programming

**View mode**

text:
Restricting IP addresses
This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager.
To restrict IP addresses for your test, follow these steps:
Identify IP addresses that correspond to the network that will be used to conduct the test.
Log in to your HackerEarth account using your admin credentials.
Click the name of your test to open it.
In the Test Details section, click Test Settings.
Scroll to the Proctoring Settings section.
Select Restrict test access for certain IP addresses. 
Add the required IP addresses.
These IP addresses must be listed in the Proctoring Settings section by adding one or all the following: 
Multiple IP addresses separated by commas (,), for example, 10.73.82.21, 10.21.43.54 
Range of IP addresses, for example, 10.10.16.1-10.10.16.240 
A range of IP addresses is a set of IP addresses from the lowest IP to the highest IP that is specified. For more information, see Private and Public IP Address Ranges.
Subnets, for example, 10.2.10.0/24
A subnet (or subnetwork) is a logical subdivision of an IP network. For more information, see Subnetwork.
Click Save Proctoring Settings.
You have successfully restricted IP addresses for your test.
Related topics
IP address restriction
Proctoring settings
Enabling proctoring settings
markdown:
# Restricting IP addresses

_This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager._

To restrict IP addresses for your test, follow these steps:

1.  Identify IP addresses that correspond to the network that will be used to conduct the test.
2.  Log in to your HackerEarth account using your admin credentials.
3.  Click the name of your test to open it.
4.  In the **Test Details** section, click **Test Settings**.
5.  Scroll to the **Proctoring Settings** section.
6.  Select **Restrict test access for certain IP addresses**. 
7.  Add the required IP addresses.  
    These IP addresses must be listed in the Proctoring Settings section by adding one or all the following:
    1.  Multiple IP addresses separated by commas (,), for example, 10.73.82.21, 10.21.43.54 
    2.  Range of IP addresses, for example, 10.10.16.1-10.10.16.240  
        A range of IP addresses is a set of IP addresses from the lowest IP to the highest IP that is specified. For more information, see [Private and Public IP Address Ranges](http://blog.adiglobal.us/private-and-public-ip-address-ranges/).
    3.  Subnets, for example, 10.2.10.0/24  
        A subnet (or subnetwork) is a logical subdivision of an IP network. For more information, see [Subnetwork](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subnetwork).
8.  Click **Save Proctoring Settings**.

You have successfully restricted IP addresses for your test.

### _Related topics_

*   [IP address restriction](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004123273-IP-address-restriction)
*   [Proctoring settings](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002987633-Proctoring-settings)
*   [Enabling proctoring settings](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003097113-Enabling-proctoring-settings)

text:
R-rated content detection
HackerEarth has introduced R-rated content detection in which if a programming question or MCQ contains offensive or inclusive content, it will be highlighted in the platform and can be removed or changed if you want to. This feature was developed by HackerEarth so that the problem statements can be made appropriate for the candidates and they do not feel any bias or offense. The platform checks the whole question and detects the sentences that signify violence, hate, bias, or other negative emotions.
You can just open any of the questions in My library on the platform, and the flagged sentence will be highlighted in red or yellow color. You can then easily change the sentence or modify the sentence so that the question’s meaning remains intact even after removing the flagged words or sentences. For example, A is the enemy you want to murder. In this sentence, words like enemy and murder will be flagged and they will be highlighted so that you can make the alterations or modifications in the sentence if you want to. Words that can be categorized as offensive are killer, lazy, fat, etc.
How does R-rated content detection works in the recruiter?
R-rated content detection works only on programming and MCQ questions. To check how the feature works, do the following:
Select programming or MCQ questions from my library.
Click on the question you want to check the content for. Here we will select ‘Agitated souls’
You can see that the flagged words or sentences are highlighted in various colors.
The colors signify the various criteria under which flagged words or sentences are classified into. They basically signify the various reasons due to which the words or sentences are flagged. They will be shown to you at the end of the question.
You can now edit the question and change the flagged words or the sentences.
markdown:
# R-rated content detection

HackerEarth has introduced R-rated content detection in which if a programming question or MCQ contains offensive or inclusive content, it will be highlighted in the platform and can be removed or changed if you want to. This feature was developed by HackerEarth so that the problem statements can be made appropriate for the candidates and they do not feel any bias or offense. The platform checks the whole question and detects the sentences that signify violence, hate, bias, or other negative emotions.

You can just open any of the questions in My library on the platform, and the flagged sentence will be highlighted in red or yellow color. You can then easily change the sentence or modify the sentence so that the question’s meaning remains intact even after removing the flagged words or sentences. For example, A is the enemy you want to murder. In this sentence, words like **enemy** and **murder** will be flagged and they will be highlighted so that you can make the alterations or modifications in the sentence if you want to. Words that can be categorized as offensive are killer, lazy, fat, etc.

## How does R-rated content detection works in the recruiter?

R-rated content detection works only on programming and MCQ questions. To check how the feature works, do the following:

1.  Select programming or MCQ questions from my library.
    
2.  Click on the question you want to check the content for. Here we will select ‘Agitated souls’
    

![1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/1-Jan-30-2023-11-28-27-3323-AM.png)

3.  You can see that the flagged words or sentences are highlighted in various colors.
    

![2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/2-Jan-30-2023-11-28-24-5042-AM.png)

4.  The colors signify the various criteria under which flagged words or sentences are classified into. They basically signify the various reasons due to which the words or sentences are flagged. They will be shown to you at the end of the question.
    

![3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/3-Jan-30-2023-11-28-25-9036-AM.png)

You can now edit the question and change the flagged words or the sentences.

text:
MCQ checklist
There are different kind of MCQ in the HackerEarth assessment which are as follows:
IO based MCQ
Scenario-based
Code-based
Code plus scenario-based questions
Different kind of MCQ has the following components:
IO based MCQ
Language
Complete code snippet
Formatted options
Relevant tags
Difficulty level
Certain conditions that are mentioned need to be followed:
Conditions
The language must be mentioned in which the code is written.
The code should be complete in IO-based MCQ.
If your option consists of multiple lines, they should be added to the problem statement itself and mention the corresponding number in the options.
Make sure you follow the scoring system properly which is Easy-2, medium - 4, hard - 6.
At least one skill should be there in tags from the list of skills in the library.
IO-based questions should compile successfully.
The questions should not be plagiarised.
Do not use terms like valid, true. Use the word ‘correct’ instead.
Use All of these, none of these, or both of these as options.
Code snippets should always be named when multiple code snippets are in the problem statement.
Use the names which are already in the naming convention.
Every MCQ should have 4 options exactly.
For more information on MCQ, read this article.
markdown:
# MCQ checklist

#### There are different kind of MCQ in the HackerEarth assessment which are as follows:

*   *   IO based MCQ
    *   Scenario-based
    *   Code-based
    *   Code plus scenario-based questions

### Different kind of MCQ has the following components:

*   IO based MCQ

*   Language
*   Complete code snippet
*   Formatted options
*   Relevant tags
*   Difficulty level

Certain conditions that are mentioned need to be followed:

### Conditions

1.  The language must be mentioned in which the code is written.
2.  The code should be complete in IO-based MCQ.
3.  If your option consists of multiple lines, they should be added to the problem statement itself and mention the corresponding number in the options.
4.  Make sure you follow the scoring system properly which is Easy-2, medium - 4, hard - 6.
5.  At least one skill should be there in tags from the list of skills in the library.
6.  IO-based questions should compile successfully.
7.  The questions should not be plagiarised.
8.  Do not use terms like valid, true. Use the word ‘correct’ instead.
9.  Use All of these, none of these, or both of these as options.
10.  Code snippets should always be named when multiple code snippets are in the problem statement.
11.  Use the names which are already in the naming convention.
12.  Every MCQ should have 4 options exactly.

For more information on MCQ, read [this article.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002710473-multiple-choice-questions-mcqs-)
