text:
Question listing
HackerEarth Assessment has updated the way of listing questions in the tests. The updated view provides you a better understanding and representation of the questions that are added to your test. You have the option to drag and drop the question to change the order in which they can be displayed in the test. 
To view the new update of the question listing, follow these steps:
Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Navigate to any tests to view the new format of the question listing.
In the Test details sections, click Questions.
You can view the following details about the questions that are added to your test:
S.No.	Name	Description	
1	Test duration	Represents the total duration of the test	
2	Create a new question	Creates a new manual question	
3	Choose from library	Helps to choose the questions for HackerEarth's library	
4	Total score	Represents the total score of the section	
5	Other options (section)	Represents the other options for the section	
6	Problem statement	Represents the problem statement 	
7	Hide the question	Helps in hiding or unhiding the question from the test	
8	Other options (question)	Represents the other options for the question	
9	Skill tag	Represents the skill that associates with the questions	
10	Score of the problem	Represents the score assigned to the problem
markdown:
# Question listing

HackerEarth Assessment has updated the way of listing questions in the tests. The updated view provides you a better understanding and representation of the questions that are added to your test. You have the option to drag and drop the question to change the order in which they can be displayed in the test. 

![mceclip15.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip15-Jan-30-2023-11-42-22-0053-AM.png)

To view the new update of the question listing, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click Tests.
3.  Navigate to any tests to view the new format of the question listing.
4.  In the **Test details** sections, click **Questions**.
5.  You can view the following details about the questions that are added to your test:  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-42-09-8577-AM.png)
    
    |     |     |     |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | **S.No.** | **Name** | **Description** |
    | 1   | Test duration | Represents the total duration of the test |
    | 2   | Create a new question | Creates a new manual question |
    | 3   | Choose from library | Helps to choose the questions for HackerEarth's library |
    | 4   | Total score | Represents the total score of the section |
    | 5   | Other options (section) | Represents the other options for the section |
    | 6   | Problem statement | Represents the problem statement |
    | 7   | Hide the question | Helps in hiding or unhiding the question from the test |
    | 8   | Other options (question) | Represents the other options for the question |
    | 9   | Skill tag | Represents the skill that associates with the questions |
    | 10  | Score of the problem | Represents the score assigned to the problem |

text:
Advanced proctoring settings - Smart Browser
Overview
HackerEarth has introduced advanced proctoring settings that force candidates to attempt a test in a HackerEarth desktop application with stricter proctoring features than those provided by our browser test environment. This is done to offer stricter proctoring settings that can be instilled in the platform so that you can be assured about the proctoring of the tests you are conducting on our platform. 
Benefits of Smart Browser
Several new proctoring settings have been introduced in the smart browser to incorporate stricter proctoring settings in the test. The smart browser or desktop application will prevent the following candidate actions:
Screensharing the test window
Keeping other applications open during the test
Resizing the test window
Using multiple monitors during the test
Taking screenshots of the test window
Recording the test window
Restrict keystrokes that are as follows: 
All function keys and combos involving these keys ex: F1, F5 + Alt
Alt + Tab
Ctrl + Alt + Delete
Ctrl + V
Ctrl + C
OS superkeys and combos involving these keys ex: Windows Key, Mac Command Key, Windows Key + C
Viewing OS notifications
Running the test window within a Virtual Machine
Usage of browser developer tools
You can also use IntelliSense with full screen if you have enabled Smart browser settings for your test. 
Smart Browser preview does not work for unpublished tests. You need to publish the test to preview it in the Smart Browser. 
Supported Operating systems
Smart Browser is supported by the following Operating Systems (OS):
OS	Versions	
Windows	10, 11	
Linux	Ubuntu 22.04, Ubuntu 20.04	
macOS	13.5 Ventura
markdown:
# Advanced proctoring settings - Smart Browser

### Overview

HackerEarth has introduced advanced proctoring settings that force candidates to attempt a test in a HackerEarth desktop application with stricter proctoring features than those provided by our browser test environment. This is done to offer stricter proctoring settings that can be instilled in the platform so that you can be assured about the proctoring of the tests you are conducting on our platform. 

### Benefits of Smart Browser

Several new proctoring settings have been introduced in the smart browser to incorporate stricter proctoring settings in the test. The smart browser or desktop application will prevent the following candidate actions:

*   Screensharing the test window
*   Keeping other applications open during the test
*   Resizing the test window
*   Using multiple monitors during the test
*   Taking screenshots of the test window
*   Recording the test window
*   Restrict keystrokes that are as follows:
    *   *   All function keys and combos involving these keys ex: F1, F5 + Alt
        *   Alt + Tab
        *   Ctrl + Alt + Delete
        *   Ctrl + V
        *   Ctrl + C
        *   OS superkeys and combos involving these keys  ex: Windows Key, Mac Command Key, Windows Key + C
*   Viewing OS notifications
*   Running the test window within a Virtual Machine
*   Usage of browser developer tools

You can also use IntelliSense with full screen if you have enabled Smart browser settings for your test. 

![](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/zshBzaEBqWlBuFDeCo2mt9lEGGTuIeH2jk7dcIPo9rQ1zvWwueox_HN1PKHvJks8f7zP8lkdCdq6gFpOAsh2z_uK6DKI0b5NcNmFGzx7eJLB62KPaACC1_JpRulKFclJjuJYxo7-jrQq2HWolYLFXWY)

Smart Browser preview does not work for unpublished tests. You need to publish the test to preview it in the Smart Browser. 

### Supported Operating systems

Smart Browser is supported by the following Operating Systems (OS):

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| **OS** | **Versions** |
| Windows | 10, 11 |
| Linux | Ubuntu 22.04, Ubuntu 20.04 |
| macOS | 13.5 Ventura |

text:
User roles and permissions
A user role is a collection of permissions that are defined to indicate the actions that an admin can complete. For example, to create or edit questions in My Library, you must be a Library admin.
In Recruit, there are two roles:
Company-level roles
Test-level roles
Company-level roles
You can access these roles in your account settings.
There are five company-level roles:
Super Admin
Tests Admin
Interviews Admin
Library admin
Send API Requests
S. No. Role Permissions 
1	Super Admin	A Super admin has access to all the features in the company account. A few features are exclusive only to super admins, such as:
Adding and removing users
Viewing billing and usage details
Modifying tests created by any admin
	
2	Test Admin	
A Test admin can do everything related to tests (only in tests that have been created by them) such as:
Create, edit, and delete tests
Add, modify, and delete questions
Modify test settings
Invite users
Access reports
Important: Test admins will not be able to alter tests that they have not created or were not explicitly added to.
	
3	Interviews Admin	
An Interviews admin can do everything related to FaceCode, such as:
Create interviews
Add questions to an interview
Note: An Interviews admin has access to the company's custom library (My Library) only.
Edit and delete questions from an interview
View interview notes and chat rooms
	
4	Library Admin	
A Library admin can do everything related to the library, such as:
Create questions in My Library
Edit and delete questions in My Library
Note: Only questions of the question types that your subscription supports can be created.
	
5	Send API Requests	
An API admin can send API requests. Recruit allows you to use the following types of API:
HackerEarth Recruit API
API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS)
	
If you do not assign any role to an admin, you will see No Access against that admin's name.
You can also deactivate or delete an admin by clicking 
Test-level roles
You can access these roles in the Test Admins section in the test settings of a specific test.
There are four test-level roles:
All access
Only Questions and reports 
Only Questions
Only Reports
Questions And Comments
S. No. Role Permissions 
1	All access	Complete access to a test	
2	Only questions and reports	You can complete the following tasks: 
Add questions
Edit questions
Delete questions
View reports
Filter, view, download, and share reports
Manually evaluate solutions
	
3	Only questions	You can complete the following tasks: 
Add questions
Edit questions
Delete questions
	
4	Only reports	
You can complete the following tasks:
View reports
Filter, view, download, and share reports
Manually evaluate solutions
	
5	Questions And Comments	
You can complete the following tasks:
Add questions
Edit questions
Delete questions
View comments

A few features are exclusive only to super admins, such as:

* Adding and removing users
* Viewing billing and usage details
* Modifying tests created by any admin | | 2 | Test Admin | A Test admin can do everything related to tests (only in tests that have been created by them) such as:

* Create, edit, and delete tests
* Add, modify, and delete questions
* Modify test settings
* Invite users
* Access reports

_Important:_ Test admins will not be able to alter tests that they have not created or were not explicitly added to. | | 3 | Interviews Admin | An Interviews admin can do everything related to FaceCode, such as:

Note: An Interviews admin has access to the company's custom library (My Library) only.
* Edit and delete questions from an interview
* View interview notes and chat rooms | | 4 | Library Admin | A Library admin can do everything related to the library, such as:

_Note_: Only questions of the question types that your subscription supports can be created. | | 5 | Send API Requests | An API admin can send API requests. Recruit allows you to use the following types of API:

* HackerEarth Recruit API
* API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS) | If you do not assign any role to an admin, you will see **No Access** against that admin's name. You can also deactivate or delete an admin by clicking ![Screenshot_from_2022-10-26_15-10-13.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11880445325209-3.png)  ![Screenshot_from_2022-10-26_15-08-30.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11880420544665-3.png) ### **Test-level roles** You can access these roles in the **Test Admins** section in the test settings of a specific test. ![Screenshot_from_2022-10-26_15-11-40.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11880520936729-3.png?width=611&height=137&name=11880520936729-3.png) There are four test-level roles: * All access * Only Questions and reports  * Only Questions * Only Reports * Questions And Comments | **S. No.** | **Role** | **Permissions** | | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | All access | Complete access to a test | | 2 | Only questions and reports | You can complete the following tasks:

Test overview
To see the overview of a test, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the name of the test whose overview you want to see.
In the Test details section, click Overview.
You can view the following details on the page: 
Overview: The following details are displayed in this section:
S. No.	Description	
1.	You can view all the questions in the assessment. 	
2.	This signifies the question type present in the assessment.	
3.	This signifies the difficulty level of the questions.	
4.	This signifies the number of questions of a particular question type.	
5.	This signifies the total score of a particular question type.	
6.	This shows the total time duration of the assessment.	
Settings: You can edit the test settings on a single page.

All the enabled settings are displayed in the different types of settings. You can enable or disable the settings by clicking Edit. To know more about test settings, click here.
Note: If you have not enabled the test setting, then it is displayed as follows:
Other details: You can also view and edit the details of the test on the same page. 

S. No.	Description	
1	This states the name of the assessment.	
2	This can be used to toggle test access on or off.	
3	This states the starting date and time of the test.	
4	This states the ending date and time of the test.

Important

Test admins: You can also add the admins of your test on this single page.

S. No.	Description

4	This states the Email ID of all the admins.

Click Add to add the description of your test. 
You can also view the default instructions provided by the platform. Click Edit to add the instructions according to your requirements. It is not recommended to edit the default instructions that are provided by the platform. 
Click Reset to the default template to restore the automatically-provided default instructions. After clicking this button, all the new and saved changes are lost. 
You have successfully viewed the Overview section.

# Test overview

To see the overview of a test, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of the test whose overview you want to see.
4.  In the **Test details** section, click **Overview**.
5.  You can view the following details on the page:
    1.  **Overview**: The following details are displayed in this section:
        
        ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-23-11-8486-AM.png)
        
        |     |     |
        | --- | --- |
        | **S. No.** | **Description** |
        | 1.  | You can view all the questions in the assessment. |
        | 2.  | This signifies the question type present in the assessment. |
        | 3.  | This signifies the difficulty level of the questions. |
        | 4.  | This signifies the number of questions of a particular question type. |
        | 5.  | This signifies the total score of a particular question type. |
        | 6.  | This shows the total time duration of the assessment. |
        
    2.  **Settings**: You can edit the test settings on a single page.  
        ![mceclip5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip5-Jan-30-2023-11-23-06-4317-AM.png)  
        All the enabled settings are displayed in the different types of settings. You can enable or disable the settings by clicking **Edit**. To know more about test settings, click [here](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413).  
        **Note**: If you have not enabled the test setting, then it is displayed as follows:  
        ![mceclip6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-23-13-0021-AM.png)
    3.  **Other details**: You can also view and edit the details of the test on the same page.   
        ![mceclip7.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip7-Jan-30-2023-11-23-14-3259-AM.png)  
        
        |     |     |
        | --- | --- |
        | **S. No.** | **Description** |
        | 1   | This states the name of the assessment. |
        | 2   | This can be used to toggle test access on or off. |
        | 3   | This states the starting date and time of the test. |
        | 4   | This states the ending date and time of the test. |
        | 5   | This shows the test link for the assessment. |
        | 6   | This shows the practice test link for the assessment. |
        | 7   | This states the test type of assessment. |
        | 8   | This shows the Recruiter API ID. |
        
          
        **Important**  
        *   Click ![mceclip9.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip9-Jan-30-2023-11-23-04-4342-AM.png) to edit specific details.
        *   Click ![mceclip10.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip10-Jan-30-2023-11-23-07-6330-AM.png) to copy specific details.
    4.  **Test admins**: You can also add the admins of your test on this single page.  
        ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-23-03-2897-AM.png)  
        
        |     |     |
        | --- | --- |
        | **S. No.** | **Description** |
        | 1   | This states the name of the admins. |
        | 2   | This can be used to add admins. |
        | 3   | This states the names of all the admins. |
        | 4   | This states the Email ID of all the admins. |
        | 5   | This shows the Access controls for the assessment. |
        | 6   | This is used to delete the admin for the assessment. |
        
    5.  Click **Add** to add the description of your test. 
    6.  You can also view the default instructions provided by the platform. Click **Edit** to add the instructions according to your requirements. It is not recommended to edit the default instructions that are provided by the platform.   

Click **Reset to the default template** to restore the automatically-provided default instructions. After clicking this button, all the new and saved changes are lost. 

You have successfully viewed the **Overview** section.

text:
Integrity index
Integrity index
HackerEarth has introduced integrity index, a metric calculated from the number and severity of proctoring violations made by the candidate while taking the assessment. Proctoring violations detected by our system, such as tab switches, snapshot violations, and plagiarism, lower a candidate's integrity index, facilitating quicker decision-making by summarizing all the proctoring violations into a single index. 
How does it help?
You can easily filter out 50 to 75% of the candidates based on their integrity index, making your hiring decision quicker and more efficient. To calculate the integrity index, we use artificial intelligence effectively to check for all the proctoring violations and summarize them into a single index from a particular score they get as a candidate. This helps you identify if the candidate has taken the assessment honestly or is worthy of being shortlisted, making the hiring decisions faster and more efficient. 
How do you see a candidate’s integrity index?
You can see the integrity index of a candidate by following these steps:
Log in to the HackerEarth assessment.
Select the assessment taken by the candidate.
Under the Candidates section, select Review pending or Test taken.
You can see the integrity index clearly, which is defined into three parameters which are as follows:
Good: The candidate has made none or minimal proctoring violations while taking the assessment.
Needs review: The candidate has committed some proctoring violations, and we recommend reviewing their report.
Poor: The candidate has committed several or serious proctoring violations, and we strongly recommend reviewing their report. 
Some of the candidates will have NA as their integrity index. The integrity index is only available for the candidates who took an assessment after February 1, 2024. 
That integrity index is calculated based on the proctoring features enabled (snapshot & tab switch). To get an accurate integrity index score, consider enabling additional proctoring features.
markdown:
# Integrity index

### Integrity index

HackerEarth has introduced integrity index, a metric calculated from the number and severity of proctoring violations made by the candidate while taking the assessment. Proctoring violations detected by our system, such as tab switches, snapshot violations, and plagiarism, lower a candidate's integrity index, facilitating quicker decision-making by summarizing all the proctoring violations into a single index. 

### How does it help?

You can easily filter out 50 to 75% of the candidates based on their integrity index, making your hiring decision quicker and more efficient. To calculate the integrity index, we use artificial intelligence effectively to check for all the proctoring violations and summarize them into a single index from a particular score they get as a candidate. This helps you identify if the candidate has taken the assessment honestly or is worthy of being shortlisted, making the hiring decisions faster and more efficient. 

### How do you see a candidate’s integrity index?

You can see the integrity index of a candidate by following these steps:

1.  Log in to the HackerEarth assessment.
2.  Select the assessment taken by the candidate.
3.  Under the **Candidates** section, select **Review pending** or **Test taken**.
    
    ![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/lTIdJg_GujuUTmfLJDz9dCCCgoCTMSprRm2K0SuemjkeC3S9tXtXbn6LaUEk2UP_QQidiezgNKsVPCPkfUT9amRILiA01dzs_EjmEf3SraDo6xyvZCDb3lc-TQT8s2LFtdb-FZ9_a6fXWA1_2nrolSM)
    
4.  You can see the integrity index clearly, which is defined into three parameters which are as follows:

*   *   **Good**: The candidate has made none or minimal proctoring violations while taking the assessment.
    *   **Needs review**: The candidate has committed some proctoring violations, and we recommend reviewing their report.
    *   **Poor**: The candidate has committed several or serious proctoring violations, and we strongly recommend reviewing their report.      

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/sf4XUWA1KWhfh0aDZIBLvodnP7jW2M089JOkf5XiTbxfagrMuZ9THw5LWQ0U086b8bIH3Fxfbnimh0tJ3a9XnZlza231elKmApHGzZDxjZ_0Kiq-VncbvOWfhFjam4nK2aEGH8wRx9Xidt-TWKElv4Y)

Some of the candidates will have NA as their integrity index. The integrity index is only available for the candidates who took an assessment after February 1, 2024. 

That integrity index is calculated based on the proctoring features enabled (snapshot & tab switch). To get an accurate integrity index score, consider enabling additional proctoring features.

text:
Test admin
How can you become a Test admin?
You can become a test admin in the following ways:
By signing up
When a Super admin adds you as a test admin from the company settings
When a Super admin adds you as a test admin for a specific test with specific company-level access
By setting a point of contact
What can a Test admin do?
A test admin can do everything related to tests (only in tests that have been created by them) such as:
Create, edit, and delete tests
Add, modify, and delete questions in the test
Modify test settings
Invite users
Access reports
Clone tests
Add multiple proctoring mechanisms
Restrict IP addresses from which the test can be taken
For more information, see Test settings.
Limitations
Test admins will not be able to alter tests that they have not created or were not explicitly added to.
A Test admin cannot add, delete, or modify the questions in the My Library, however, he can use them while creating a test. 
If you are added as a test admin from the Test settings page, you will have access only to that test. You will not have access to any other features at the company level.
markdown:
# Test admin

### **How can you become a Test admin?**

You can become a test admin in the following ways:

*   By signing up
*   When a Super admin adds you as a test admin from the company settings
*   When a Super admin adds you as a test admin for a specific test with specific company-level access
*   By setting a point of contact

### **What can a Test admin do?**

A test admin can do everything related to tests (only in tests that have been created by them) such as:

*   Create, edit, and delete tests
*   Add, modify, and delete questions in the test
*   Modify test settings
*   Invite users
*   Access reports
*   Clone tests
*   Add multiple proctoring mechanisms
*   Restrict IP addresses from which the test can be taken

For more information, see [Test settings.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413-test-settings)

### **Limitations**

*   Test admins will not be able to alter tests that they have not created or were not explicitly added to.
*   A Test admin cannot add, delete, or modify the questions in the My Library, however, he can use them while creating a test. 
*   If you are added as a test admin from the Test settings page, you will have access only to that test. You will not have access to any other features at the company level.

text:
Creating MCQs in your custom library
To add MCQs to your custom library, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessment using admin credentials.
On the recruiter dashboard, click Library.

By default, all the MCQs that are available in HackerEarth's library are displayed.
Click Create a question.
In Question types, select Multiple Choice Questions under the General section.
In the Problem Statement field, enter the problem statement.
You can allow multiple answers to be selected by the candidate by clicking Allow multiple answers. This will allow candidates to give multiple answers to a single question.
You can also shuffle the answers by clicking Allow shuffling options. This will shuffle the options every time a candidate takes the assessment.
In the Choices section, complete the following actions: 
Enter each choice.
Select the radio button corresponding to the correct option.
Note: By default, Assessment provides 4 option fields. If you want to add more options, click the Add a choice button that is displayed after the fourth field.
In the Difficulty level list, select the difficulty level of the problem: Easy, Medium, and Hard.
In the Score section, perform the following tasks:
Enter the maximum marks that you want to assign to candidates if they answer the question correctly. For example, 2 for Easy, 4 for Medium, and 6 for Hard questions.
Enter the negative score that is subtracted from the candidates' total score if they answer the problem incorrectly. For example, if you enter 1, then 1 mark will be subtracted from the candidate's total score.
In the Time section, if you want to make the question a timed MCQ, then add the maximum time in the Max Time field within which the candidate must answer the problem. If this time is greater than 0, then the question is treated as a timed question.
In the Tags section, add the tags that are relevant to the question.
For example, if your problem is assessing the knowledge of inheritance in Java, then you can add multiple tags such as Java, Inheritance, OOP, and so on. These tags can be used to auto-generate tests for specific profiles. 
You can click Save as draft to save the question for further editing or Click Publish if you are ready to add the question to your library.
You have successfully added MCQs to your custom library.
markdown:
# Creating MCQs in your custom library

To add MCQs to your custom library, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessment using admin credentials.
2.  On the recruiter dashboard, click **Library**.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-46-35-1265-AM.png)  
    By default, all the MCQs that are available in HackerEarth's library are displayed.
3.  Click **Create a question**.![Screenshot from 2023-12-20 12-23-20](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot%20from%202023-12-20%2012-23-20.png?width=688&height=76&name=Screenshot%20from%202023-12-20%2012-23-20.png)
4.  In **Question types**, select **Multiple Choice Questions** under the **General** section**.**  
    ![Screenshot from 2023-12-20 12-24-07](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot%20from%202023-12-20%2012-24-07.png?width=452&height=271&name=Screenshot%20from%202023-12-20%2012-24-07.png)
5.  In the **Problem Statement** field, enter the problem statement.
6.  You can allow multiple answers to be selected by the candidate by clicking **Allow multiple answers**. This will allow candidates to give multiple answers to a single question.
7.  You can also shuffle the answers by clicking **Allow shuffling options.** This will shuffle the options every time a candidate takes the assessment.![Screenshot from 2023-05-18 17-10-37](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot%20from%202023-05-18%2017-10-37.png?width=688&height=497&name=Screenshot%20from%202023-05-18%2017-10-37.png)
8.  In the **Choices** section, complete the following actions:
    1.  Enter each choice.
    2.  Select the radio button corresponding to the correct option.  
        _Note_: By default, Assessment provides 4 option fields. If you want to add more options, click the **Add a choice** button that is displayed after the fourth field.
9.  In the **Difficulty level** list, select the difficulty level of the problem: **Easy**, **Medium**, and **Hard**.
10.  In the **Score** section, perform the following tasks:  
    1.  Enter the maximum marks that you want to assign to candidates if they answer the question correctly. For example, **2** for Easy, **4** for Medium, and **6** for Hard questions.
    2.  Enter the negative score that is subtracted from the candidates' total score if they answer the problem incorrectly. For example, if you enter **1**, then **1** mark will be subtracted from the candidate's total score.
11.  In the Time section, if you want to make the question a timed MCQ, then add the maximum time in the **Max Time** field within which the candidate must answer the problem. If this time is greater than **0**, then the question is treated as a timed question.
12.  In the **Tags** section, add the tags that are relevant to the question.  
    For example, if your problem is assessing the knowledge of inheritance in Java, then you can add multiple tags such as Java, Inheritance, OOP, and so on. These tags can be used to auto-generate tests for specific profiles. 
13.  You can click **Save as draft** to save the question for further editing or Click **Publish** if you are ready to add the question to your library.

 You have successfully added MCQs to your custom library.

markdown:
# How to request access to the Smart browser?

You can easily access smart browser settings by following these steps:

1.  Click on the test in which you want to access smart browser settings.
2.  Click **Overview** under the **Test details** section**.**
3.  Go to **Proctoring settings** and click the **Request access** button popping beside **Enable Smart Browser stricter proctoring** settings**.**
4.  You will get a message saying **Thanks. Our team will get in touch with you**. Someone from our team will get in touch with you regarding access to the smart browser.

Once you get access to smart browser settings, you can easily select the smart browser settings for stricter proctoring in your test.

text:
Partial scoring
HackerEarth has introduced partial scoring in the MCQ questions with multiple correct answers. Partial scoring is a concept of providing scoring on the basis of the number of correct answers. It will also equally distribute the Maximum and Negative scores across correct and incorrect options, respectively. Partial scoring is only available if you allow multiple answers in MCQ. You can easily enable partial scoring in MCQs with multiple answers by selecting the check box stating ‘Allow partial scoring’.
Scoring for Partial scoring 
The scoring is as follows:
Example of partial scoring 
For example, an MCQ with partial scoring has the following settings:
Max score: 4
Negative score: 2
Available choices: A, B, C, and D
Correct choice: A and C
Candidate’s answer
	
Assigned score
	
Explanation
	
A (One correct)
	
2
	
The correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points for a total of 2 points
	
B (One incorrect)
	
-1
	
The incorrect option earns -2/2 = -1 point for a total of -1 point
	
A & C (Both correct)
	
4
	
Each correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points for a total of 2x2 = 4 points
	
A & B (One correct and one incorrect)
	
1
	
The correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points, and the incorrect one earns -2/2 = -1 points for a total of
2 - 1 = 1 point
	
B & D (Both incorrect)
	
-2
	
Each incorrect option earns -2/2 = -1 points for a total of 2 x -1 = -2 points
	
A, C & D
	
-2
	
Since the candidate has selected more than the number of correct options available (2) the candidate will receive the full negative score of -2

# Partial scoring HackerEarth has introduced partial scoring in the MCQ questions with multiple correct answers. Partial scoring is a concept of providing scoring on the basis of the number of correct answers. It will also equally distribute the Maximum and Negative scores across correct and incorrect options, respectively. Partial scoring is only available if you allow multiple answers in MCQ. You can easily enable partial scoring in MCQs with multiple answers by selecting the check box stating ‘**Allow partial scoring**’. Scoring for Partial scoring The scoring is as follows: Example of partial scoring For example, an MCQ with partial scoring has the following settings: * Max score: 4 * Negative score: 2 * Available choices:  A, B, C, and D * Correct choice: A and C | | | | | --- | --- | --- | | **Candidate’s answer** | **Assigned score** | **Explanation** | | A (One correct) | 2 | The correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points for a total of 2 points | | B (One incorrect) | \-1 | The incorrect option earns -2/2 = -1 point for a total of -1 point | | A & C (Both correct) | 4 | Each correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points for a total of 2x2 = 4 points | | A & B (One correct and one incorrect) | 1 | The correct option earns 4/2 = 2 points, and the incorrect one earns -2/2 = -1 points for a total of

2 - 1 = 1 point | | B & D (Both incorrect) | \-2 | Each incorrect option earns -2/2 = -1 points for a total of 2 x -1 = -2 points | | A, C & D | \-2 | Since the candidate has selected more than the number of correct options available (2) the candidate will receive the full negative score of -2 |

text:
Recommended test duration
HackerEarth displays the recommended duration of your tests so that you do not have to worry about setting up the appropriate duration for your test every time you perform a task in the test. The recommended duration is calculated based on the number of questions that are added to the test and their difficulty levels.
To view the recommended test duration of your tests, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the name of the test whose recommended duration you want to see.
In the Test details section, click Overview.
Hover over Test duration. You can view the following popup:
Click Update to recommended duration to change the test duration to the recommended duration.
You have successfully updated the test duration. 
The recommended duration gets updated when you perform the following actions:
Adding, creating, or editing a question
Deleting a question, hiding a question, or making a question visible
Creating a section, deleting a section, hiding a section, or making a section visible
Note: The section can be pooled or not pooled.
Reordering problems
Important
The minimum recommended duration of a test or challenge is 30 min.
The default time for a custom test is set to 60 min.
markdown:
# Recommended test duration

HackerEarth displays the recommended duration of your tests so that you do not have to worry about setting up the appropriate duration for your test every time you perform a task in the test. The recommended duration is calculated based on the number of questions that are added to the test and their difficulty levels.

To view the recommended test duration of your tests, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of the test whose recommended duration you want to see.
4.  In the **Test details** section, click **Overview**.
5.  Hover over **Test duration**. You can view the following popup:  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-45-59-1536-AM.png)
6.  Click **Update to recommended duration** to change the test duration to the recommended duration.

You have successfully updated the test duration. 

The recommended duration gets updated when you perform the following actions:

*   Adding, creating, or editing a question
*   Deleting a question, hiding a question, or making a question visible
*   Creating a section, deleting a section, hiding a section, or making a section visible  
    **Note**: The section can be pooled or not pooled.
*   Reordering problems

**Important**

*   The minimum recommended duration of a test or challenge is **30 min**.
*   The default time for a custom test is set to **60 min**.

# Library admin

### **How can you become a Library admin?**

A Super admin at the company level can add you as a Library admin. For more information, see [Company settings.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003337694-company-settings)

### **What can a Library admin do?**

A Library admin can make changes related to My Library and customize it based on the requirements.

You cannot add, edit, or delete the questions in the HackerEarth library. 

A Library admin can do everything related to My Library, such as:

*   Create questions in My Library
*   Edit and delete questions in My Library
*   Edit, create, and delete different types of questions (section)

Only questions of the question types that your subscription supports can be created.

For more information about My library, see [My Library.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002677273-my-library-custom-library-)

text:
Adding MCQs in bulk
To add your questions in bulk, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using the admin credentials.
Click My Library.
Note: By default, the MCQs that are added to your library get displayed on the screen.
Click Upload Bulk MCQs. The following message is displayed on the screen:
Enter your MCQs by using this format only in the Excel sheet that you have downloaded.
Note: Only the first sheet is read by the system. Therefore, ensure that you add all the MCQs only in the first sheet of the Excel file.
Save the Excel file. Now, navigate to HackerEarth Assessment.
Click Browse.
Navigate to the folder where you have saved the Excel sheet. Select the relevant file and click Open.
Click Upload.
Note: Your questions are displayed in the respective sections.
Important: Questions that do not have a section are not uploaded in your library. The Section name field is mandatory to upload MCQs.
You can add multiple MCQs in one go by using an Excel sheet. For more information, see Format for adding MCQs in bulk.
markdown:
# Adding MCQs in bulk

To add your questions in bulk, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessment by using the admin credentials.
2.  Click **My Library**.  
    **Note**: By default, the MCQs that are added to your library get displayed on the screen.
3.  Click **Upload Bulk MCQs**. The following message is displayed on the screen:  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-35-49-6260-AM.png)
4.  Enter your MCQs by using [this format only](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003878774-format-for-adding-mcqs-in-bulk)[](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003878774) in the Excel sheet that you have downloaded.  
    **Note**: Only the first sheet is read by the system. Therefore, ensure that you add all the MCQs only in the first sheet of the Excel file.
5.  Save the Excel file. Now, navigate to HackerEarth Assessment.
6.  Click **Browse**.
7.  Navigate to the folder where you have saved the Excel sheet. Select the relevant file and click **Open**.
8.  Click **Upload**.

**Note**: Your questions are displayed in the respective sections.

_Important_: Questions that do not have a section are not uploaded in your library. The **Section name** field is mandatory to upload MCQs.

You can add multiple MCQs in one go by using an Excel sheet. For more information, see [Format for adding MCQs in bulk.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003878774-format-for-adding-mcqs-in-bulk)

markdown:
# Super admin

### **How can you become a Super admin?**

You can be added as a Super admin by another Super admin. Initially, your PoC can add you as a Super admin from the [Company settings](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003337694-Company-settings). A Super admin has access to all the features in the company account.

### **What can a Super admin do?**

A few features are exclusive only to super admins, such as:

*   Adding and removing users
*   Viewing billing and usage details
*   Modifying tests created by any admin
*   Add or remove administrators from the test
*   Manage permissions that each administrator is given
*   Set a point of contact whose email ID will be used to send emails to candidates and receive emails from candidates

text:
Listed tests
HackerEarth has introduced the listed test feature that allows you to publish a pre-prepared test for a specific job role. This challenge will be published on HackerEarth’s challenges page and in the Jobs section and will be visible to the community users for up to 5 weeks. 
For the duration the test is publicly listed, community users can take up the test and apply for the job role. So with this option, you get access to a high-quality talent pool that comes with validated skill sets. 
Creating a listed test
You will get an option to create a listed test in the admin dashboard. You can follow these steps to create a listed test:
Log in to your HackerEarth account.
Click Create new test.
Click Community Hiring. This is a listed test so you cannot create a new role and have to select a predefined role. The recommended skills for the job role will automatically get selected that cannot be modified by you.
Click Continue. You can configure your assessment by entering the test name, Experience range, Test duration, and tags.
Note: If you do not find the role that you are hiring for in the list of available roles, please contact us at support@hackerearth.com.
Click Continue. In the job details screen, you will see the following: 
Compensation
Number of open positions
Job location
Job description
In the Job details section, add information about the job, for example, roles and responsibilities, mandatory qualifications, educational qualifications, etc., compensation, number of open positions, and job location.
Click Create test. The test will be created.
If you choose not to disclose the salary for a job role, then the salary details will be specified as ‘Per company benchmark’.
markdown:
# Listed tests

HackerEarth has introduced the listed test feature that allows you to publish a pre-prepared test for a specific job role. This challenge will be published on HackerEarth’s [challenges page](https://www.hackerearth.com/challenges/) and in the [Jobs section](https://www.hackerearth.com/jobs/) and will be visible to the community users for up to 5 weeks. 

For the duration the test is publicly listed, community users can take up the test and apply for the job role. So with this option, you get access to a high-quality talent pool that comes with validated skill sets. 

### Creating a listed test

You will get an option to create a listed test in the admin dashboard. You can follow these steps to create a listed test:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth account.
2.  Click **Create new test.**
3.  Click **Community Hiring.** This is a listed test so you cannot create a new role and have to select a predefined role. The **recommended skills for the job role** will automatically get selected that cannot be modified by you.![Screenshot_from_2022-11-24_16-05-17.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12826751854873-1.png)
4.  Click **Continue.** You can configure your assessment by entering the **test name, Experience range, Test duration, and tags.**  
    **Note**: If you do not find the role that you are hiring for in the list of available roles, please contact us at [support@hackerearth.com](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/support@hackerearth.com).
5.  Click **Continue**. In the job details screen, you will see the following: 
    *   Compensation
    *   Number of open positions
    *   Job location
    *   Job description
6.  In the **Job details** section, add information about the job, for example, roles and responsibilities, mandatory qualifications, educational qualifications, etc., compensation, number of open positions, and job location.  
    
7.  Click **Create test**. The test will be created.

If you choose not to disclose the salary for a job role, then the salary details will be specified as ‘Per company benchmark’.

text:
Sections
A section is used to group a set of questions to do the following:
Show different questions to candidates who are taking the same test (question pooling)
Have an overall view of how a candidate has fared in a specific section (through reports)
There is no limit on the number of sections that you create and the number of questions that you add to a section.
Important: Sections are not visible to candidates.
Types of sections
There are two types of sections in Recruit: fixed and random
Note: Only random sections are used for question pooling.
Fixed
Questions that are added to a fixed section will be visible (in the same order) to all the candidates who are taking the test.
Random
These sections are used for question pooling. A certain number of questions are added to a section (pool) from which only a few questions are randomly shown in a test to the candidate. The number of questions that must be shown to the candidate can be configured by the recruiter.
markdown:
# Sections

A section is used to group a set of questions to do the following:

*   Show different questions to candidates who are taking the same test (question pooling)
*   Have an overall view of how a candidate has fared in a specific section (through reports)

There is no limit on the number of sections that you create and the number of questions that you add to a section.

_Important_: Sections are not visible to candidates.

## Types of sections

There are two types of sections in Recruit: fixed and random

_Note_: Only random sections are used for question pooling.

### **Fixed**

Questions that are added to a fixed section will be visible (in the same order) to all the candidates who are taking the test.

### **Random**

These sections are used for question pooling. A certain number of questions are added to a section (pool) from which only a few questions are randomly shown in a test to the candidate. The number of questions that must be shown to the candidate can be configured by the recruiter.

text:
Format for adding MCQs in bulk
You can add multiple MCQs in one go by using an Excel sheet.
Note: The Excel file that you will use to upload MCQs in bulk must be in the .xls or .xlsx format only.
The format that you must follow in the Excel sheet is as follows:
S. No.	Column names (in your Excel sheet)	Information to be added in each column	
1
	
Section name
	
Enter the name of the section in which you want to upload the questions.
	
2
	
Problem Statement
	
Enter your question.
	
3
	
Option 1 (mandatory)
	
Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. It is mandatory to add at least 2 options to an MCQ.
	
4
	
Option 2 (mandatory)
	
Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. It is mandatory to add at least 2 options to an MCQ.
	
5
	
Option 3 (optional)
	
Add one of the choices as an answer to your question.
	
6
	
Option 4 (optional)
	
Add one of the choices as an answer to your question.
	
7
	
Option 5 (if you want to add multiple options)
	
Add one of the choices as an answer to your question.
	
8
	
Correct Option number between 1 to n
	
Enter the option number that has the correct answer. For example, 3 (which denotes option #3).
	
9
	
Correct score
	
Enter the correct score of the question.
	
10	
Negative marking
	
Enter the marks that will be deducted from the candidate’s overall score, if the answer is incorrect i.e. a negative score.
	
11	Difficulty level	Enter the difficulty level of the questions.	
12	Time in seconds (Optional)	Enter the total time within which the candidate must answer this question.	
13	Comma-separated skills and tags (optional)	Add the skills and tags that are relevant to your question.	
14 	Partial scoring	If partial scoring is available in the question, enter YES else NO	
Important
You must enter the same name as the section that you have created in your library.
Only the first sheet of the Excel file is considered for the bulk upload.
In the Options field, if the options end with 0 after a decimal point such as 20.0, 1.0, etc., then change the format of the field to 'text' in the Excel sheet.
The questions that have no errors are uploaded to the library whereas the questions that contain errors are not uploaded to the library. You can also view the error that the question contains.
Do not remove or change the header row, however, to add more than four options for an MCQ, create a column next to Option 4 with the header in the same format. For example, Option 5.
Partial scoring is only allowed for multiple answers. The default value of the partial scoring column is No.
markdown:
# Format for adding MCQs in bulk

You can add multiple MCQs in one go by using an Excel sheet.

**Note**: The Excel file that you will use to upload MCQs in bulk must be in the **.xls** or **.xlsx** format only.

The format that you must follow in the Excel sheet is as follows:

|     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **S. No.** | **Column names** **(in your Excel sheet)** | **Information to be added in each column** |
| 1   | Section name | Enter the name of the section in which you want to upload the questions. |
| 2   | Problem Statement | Enter your question. |
| 3   | Option 1 (mandatory) | Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. It is mandatory to add at least 2 options to an MCQ. |
| 4   | Option 2 (mandatory) | Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. It is mandatory to add at least 2 options to an MCQ. |
| 5   | Option 3 (optional) | Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. |
| 6   | Option 4 (optional) | Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. |
| 7   | Option 5 (if you want to add multiple options) | Add one of the choices as an answer to your question. |
| 8   | Correct Option number between 1 to n | Enter the option number that has the correct answer. For example, 3 (which denotes option #3). |
| 9   | Correct score | Enter the correct score of the question. |
| 10  | Negative marking | Enter the marks that will be deducted from the candidate’s overall score, if the answer is incorrect i.e. a negative score. |
| 11  | Difficulty level | Enter the difficulty level of the questions. |
| 12  | Time in seconds (Optional) | Enter the total time within which the candidate must answer this question. |
| 13  | Comma-separated skills and tags (optional) | Add the skills and tags that are relevant to your question. |
| 14  | Partial scoring | If partial scoring is available in the question, enter YES else NO |

**Important**

1.  You must enter the same name as the section that you have created in your library.
2.  Only the first sheet of the Excel file is considered for the bulk upload.
3.  In the Options field, if the options end with **0** after a decimal point such as **20.0**, **1.0**, etc., then change the format of the field to '**text**' in the Excel sheet.
4.  The questions that have no errors are uploaded to the library whereas the questions that contain errors are not uploaded to the library. You can also view the error that the question contains.
5.  Do not remove or change the header row, however, to add more than four options for an MCQ, create a column next to Option 4 with the header in the same format. For example, Option 5.
6.  Partial scoring is only allowed for multiple answers. The default value of the partial scoring column is No.

text:
Dynamic practice tests
HackerEarth Assessment automatically generates a practice test for a specific test that is created by you. The purpose of this test is to make candidates familiar with the test environment. It is created only after a test gets published.
The features of a practice test are as follows:
It contains the same question format as the original test. For example, if you have added MCQs, programming questions, and SQL questions, then the practice that is created for this test also contains the same question types. The practice test does not contain the same number of questions as the original test.
The duration of all the practice tests that are generated for any tests is 45 minutes. This duration does not change with respect to the format of the original tests.
The link to the practice test is attached to the Invite and automated reminder emails. You can also view and copy the practice test link from the Overview page.
If you make any changes to the format of the questions in the original test, then the format of the practice test is automatically updated with respect to the modified format of the original test.
It cannot contain the same questions that are added to the original test. 
Candidates can attempt this test anywhere they want. Also, they can attempt the practice test for multiple numbers of times.
The description and instructions of the practice test can be modified for a better understanding of its purpose.
The types of questions that are supported by the automatically-generated practice tests and the number of questions for the respective types that are added to the test are as follows:
S. No.	Question types	No. of questions added to the test	
1	MCQs	Ranges from 2 to 5 per defined skill	
2	Subjective	1	
3	Programming	1	
4	SQL	1	
5	Java project	1	
6	C# project	1	
7	Python project	1	
8	Frontend	1	
9	File upload	1	
10	Machine Learning	1	
For MCQs, if questions for a specific skill or topic do not exist, then the questions that are related to the other defined skills are added. In case, if no skills are defined, then the questions related to logical reasoning are added to the test.
markdown:
# Dynamic practice tests

HackerEarth Assessment automatically generates a practice test for a specific test that is created by you. The purpose of this test is to make candidates familiar with the test environment. It is created only after a test gets published.

![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-29-32-9391-AM.png)

The features of a practice test are as follows:

*   It contains the same question format as the original test. For example, if you have added MCQs, programming questions, and SQL questions, then the practice that is created for this test also contains the same question types. The practice test does not contain the same number of questions as the original test.
*   The duration of all the practice tests that are generated for any tests is **45** minutes. This duration does not change with respect to the format of the original tests.
*   The link to the practice test is attached to the Invite and automated reminder emails. You can also view and copy the practice test link from the **Overview** page.  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-29-31-0917-AM.png)
*   If you make any changes to the format of the questions in the original test, then the format of the practice test is automatically updated with respect to the modified format of the original test.
*   It cannot contain the same questions that are added to the original test. 
*   Candidates can attempt this test anywhere they want. Also, they can attempt the practice test for multiple numbers of times.
*   The description and instructions of the practice test can be modified for a better understanding of its purpose.

The types of questions that are supported by the automatically-generated practice tests and the number of questions for the respective types that are added to the test are as follows:

|     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **S. No.** | **Question types** | **No. of questions added to the test** |
| 1   | MCQs | Ranges from 2 to 5 per defined skill |
| 2   | Subjective | 1   |
| 3   | Programming | 1   |
| 4   | SQL | 1   |
| 5   | Java project | 1   |
| 6   | C# project | 1   |
| 7   | Python project | 1   |
| 8   | Frontend | 1   |
| 9   | File upload | 1   |
| 10  | Machine Learning | 1   |

For MCQs, if questions for a specific skill or topic do not exist, then the questions that are related to the other defined skills are added. In case, if no skills are defined, then the questions related to logical reasoning are added to the test.

markdown:
# Creating sections

_Note_: It is assumed that you have created a test and are on the **Test details** page.

1.  In the **Test details** section, click **Questions**.
    
    ![Screenshot_from_2022-12-07_16-52-29.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13257711044249-1.png?width=288&height=162&name=13257711044249-1.png)
    
2.  Click **Add a section ![Screenshot_from_2022-12-07_16-56-20.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13257774811161-1.png)** .![Screenshot_from_2022-12-07_16-53-18.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13257757740569-1.png)
3.  In the **Section name** field, enter a name for the section. For example, MCQ hard.
4.  Select the **question type**. For example, Multiple choice.
5.  You can also enable **pooling** and **bulk scoring** for the section.

text:
Types of tests
You can create the following types of tests in HackerEarth Recruit:
Invite-only 
Public
For more information, see Creating a new test.
Invite-only test
In this type of test, candidates who are invited through their respective e-mail IDs can take the test. The invite-only type of test is recommended for lateral hiring because the number of candidates who attempt the test is defined.
Public test
In this type of test, candidates are sent a link to access the test. Anyone with this link can take the test. The public test is recommended when the number of candidates who attempt the test is not defined. For example, campus hiring.

# Types of tests

*   Invite-only

![Screenshot_from_2022-11-24_16-50-53.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12828019599385-1.png)

text:
API admin
How can you become an API admin?
You can be added as an API admin by a Super admin from the Company settings. 
What can an API admin do?
An API admin can send API requests. HackerEarth Recruit allows you to use the following types of API:
HackerEarth Recruit API
API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS)
HackerEarth Recruit API
HackerEarth Recruit API helps you manage tests, candidate invites, and reports on your own with just a few lines of code. For more information, see HackerEarth's API documentation.
Your client ID and client secret ID must be kept confidential because they can be misused. It is recommended that you do not share these details with anyone. 
If you do share this information and it is misused, HackerEarth does not take responsibility for the same.
Only super admins and API admins can access this feature.
API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS)
You can integrate your HackerEarth Recruit account with the following Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS):
Greenhouse: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the greenhouse dashboard. To know more about the functionality of the greenhouse, click here.
Bullhorn: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the Bullhorn dashboard.
iCIMS: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the iCIMS dashboard.
Only super admins can access this feature.
For integration requests, please contact your Customer Success Manager.
An API admin is not allowed to access My Library or create and access tests.
markdown:
# API admin

### **How can you become an API admin?**

You can be added as an API admin by a Super admin from the [Company settings](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003337694-Company-settings). 

### **What can an API admin do?**

An API admin can send API requests. HackerEarth Recruit allows you to use the following types of API:

1.  HackerEarth Recruit API
2.  API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS)

#### **HackerEarth Recruit API**

HackerEarth Recruit API helps you manage tests, candidate invites, and reports on your own with just a few lines of code. For more information, see [HackerEarth's API documentation](https://www.hackerearth.com/docs/api/recruiter/v2/tests/invite-candidates/).

Your client ID and client secret ID must be kept confidential because they can be misused. It is recommended that you do not share these details with anyone.   
If you do share this information and it is misused, HackerEarth does not take responsibility for the same.

Only super admins and API admins can access this feature.

#### **API of the integrated Applicant Tracking System (ATS)**

You can integrate your HackerEarth Recruit account with the following Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS):

*   Greenhouse: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the greenhouse dashboard. To know more about the functionality of the greenhouse, click [here](http://news.hackerearth.com/2015/10/09/hackerearth-greenhouse-integration/).
*   Bullhorn: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the Bullhorn dashboard.
*   iCIMS: It allows you to list tests, send invites, and see candidate report in the iCIMS dashboard.

Only super admins can access this feature.

For integration requests, please contact your Customer Success Manager.

An API admin is not allowed to access My Library or create and access tests.

text:
Adding diagrams to MCQs
To add diagrams to the MCQs, follow these steps:
Log into HackerEarth Recruit using admin credentials.
Click Questions Library.
In Library, click MCQ.
Click Add multiple-choice question.
In the Problem Statement field, click .
The Image Properties dialog box appears as follows:
In the Image Info tab, you can set the following options:
S. No. Title Description 
1	URL	
Link to the image that you want to upload
Note: When you choose and upload an image in the Upload tab, the URL of the image will be added to the URL field in the Image Info tab.
	
2	Alternative Text	Provides alternate information about the image if the candidate is unable to view it	
3	Width	Width of the image	
4	Height	Height of the image	
5	Lock ratio	Prevents the size of your image from being changed	
6	Reset 	Erases the number mentioned in the Height and Width fields if the lock ratio option is not enabled	
7	Alignment	
None: By default, the image is aligned along the left margin by default
Left: Image is aligned along the left margin
Center: Image is neither aligned to left nor right margin. There is an even gap on either side of the margin.
Right: Image is aligned along the right margin
	
8	Captioned image	Allows you add a caption to your image	
In the Upload tab, you can set the following options:
Click Choose file.
Navigate to the folder from which you want to upload the image.
Click Upload Image.
Click OK.
Note: You can double-click on the image that is uploaded and reset the image properties by using the same steps as mentioned in this article.
You have successfully added an image to your MCQ.

# Adding diagrams to MCQs To add diagrams to the MCQs, follow these steps: 1. Log into HackerEarth Recruit using admin credentials. 2. Click **Questions Library**. 3. In **Library**, click **MCQ**. 4. Click **Add multiple-choice question**. 5. In the **Problem Statement** field, click ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-47-00-6320-AM.png?width=20&height=17&name=mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-47-00-6320-AM.png) . The **Image Properties** dialog box appears as follows: ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-47-01-8209-AM.png) 6. In the **Image Info** tab, you can set the following options: | S. No. | Title | Description | | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | URL | Link to the image that you want to upload

_Note_: When you choose and upload an image in the _Upload_ tab, the URL of the image will be added to the _URL_ field in the _Image Info_ tab. | | 2 | Alternative Text | Provides alternate information about the image if the candidate is unable to view it | | 3 | Width | Width of the image | | 4 | Height | Height of the image | | 5 | Lock ratio | Prevents the size of your image from being changed | | 6 | Reset | Erases the number mentioned in the _Height_ and _Width_ fields if the lock ratio option is not enabled | | 7 | Alignment | _None_: By default, the image is aligned along the left margin by default

_Left_: Image is aligned along the left margin

_Center_: Image is neither aligned to left nor right margin. There is an even gap on either side of the margin.

_Right_: Image is aligned along the right margin | | 8 | Captioned image | Allows you add a caption to your image | 7. In the **Upload** tab, you can set the following options: ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-47-03-6726-AM.png) 1. Click **Choose file.** 2. Navigate to the folder from which you want to upload the image. 3. Click **Upload Image.** 8. Click **OK.** _Note_: You can double-click on the image that is uploaded and reset the image properties by using the same steps as mentioned in this article. text:
Parts of a programming problem
Programming questions on the HackerEarth platform must have the following components:
Description 
Includes the problem statement and problem name
Critical to a question because it tells candidates what their tasks are
Solution and test cases 
Contains the solution to the problem, which includes sample input, sample output, and test cases
Critical to a question because a candidate's code is evaluated against the solution
Code snippets 
Add starter code in 38+ languages
Allows candidates to focus on writing the logic required to solve the problem
Tip: Use our auto code snippet generator to generate code snippets in C, C++, C++14, C++17, C#, Java, Java 8, JavaScript (Node.js), PHP, Python, Python 3, Python 3.8, Ruby.
Editorial 
You can use this field to enter the approach or answers that can be used to solve the problem.
This will not be visible to the candidate.
This field has been provided to save information about the solution to the problem. This helps you access this information quickly when required.
Related topics
Code snippets
Generating code snippets manually
Generating code snippets automatically
markdown:
# Parts of a programming problem

Programming questions on the HackerEarth platform must have the following components:

1.  **Description**
    *   Includes the problem statement and problem name
    *   Critical to a question because it tells candidates what their tasks are
2.  **Solution and test cases**
    *   Contains the solution to the problem, which includes sample input, sample output, and test cases
    *   Critical to a question because a candidate's code is evaluated against the solution
3.  **Code snippets**
    *   Add starter code in 38+ languages
    *   Allows candidates to focus on writing the logic required to solve the problem
        
        **Tip**: Use our auto code snippet generator to generate code snippets in C, C++, C++14, C++17, C#, Java, Java 8, JavaScript (Node.js), PHP, Python, Python 3, Python 3.8, Ruby.
        
4.  **Editorial**
    *   You can use this field to enter the approach or answers that can be used to solve the problem.
    *   This will not be visible to the candidate.
    *   This field has been provided to save information about the solution to the problem. This helps you access this information quickly when required.

### **Related topics**

*   [Code snippets](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005347153)
*   [Generating code snippets manually](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005288154-Generating-your-code-snippets-manually)
*   [Generating code snippets automatically](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005344333-Generating-your-code-snippets-automatically)

text:
Code snippets
This feature is enabled for all our customers. 
A code snippet is a boilerplate code that can be used without changing it. This code helps such candidates who are not familiar with the online coding environment to focus more on the algorithm that is required to solve the question rather than understanding the STD INPUT and OUTPUT syntaxes. 
When a candidate writes code, it is evaluated using input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT). 
STDIN: The default source of providing input to any computer program.
STDOUT: The default channel where the output of the program is written.
In HackerEarth Assessment's in-built library, code snippets can be generated for Programming questions in the following languages:
C
C++
C++14
C++17
C#
Java
Java 8
JavaScript(Node.js)
PHP
Python
Python 3
Ruby
Go
Kotlin
Objective-C
Python 3.8
Ruby
Scala
Swift
These code stubs are already loaded in the code editor of a question for candidates to use when they are attempting the test.
Use of code snippets
Candidates who take online coding tests are usually not familiar with the online coding process. There may not be enough time for a candidate to understand HackerEarth’s evaluation process—specifically how the input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT) must be written to ensure that the evaluation process runs correctly.
If the code snippet is already available, then the candidate can do the following:
Focus on writing the logic that is required to solve the problem
Not spend time figuring out the input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT) that needs to be used
Example
A candidate must write the code to add N numbers (1, 2, 3…N). The code will be as follows:
Note: The code has been written in different colors only for clarity. In this code, the colors mean the following:
Blue = Input
Orange = Logic
Green = Output
Add the input and output in the form of a code snippet to this question. This becomes visible to the candidates when they are attempting this question. The candidates can then focus only on writing the logic required to calculate the sum of N numbers. 
Generating code snippets
To generate code stubs for a Programming question, follow these steps:
Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the name of any tests in which you want to add code stubs to its Programming questions. For example, Algorithms test.
In the Test details section, click Questions.
Navigate to the Programming questions section and click the name of the question. The modal containing different parts of the question is displayed.
Click Edit question.
In the Edit Programming question section, click Languages.
Navigate to the Code snippets section and click Auto generate.
Enter or select the following details: 
Name of the function, for example, func
Return type, for example, Integer
Any comments that you want to add in your code, for example, mycode
Notify whether there are multiple test cases in a single file
Function parameter and name of the parameter, for example, Character and test
Important: If you want to add multiple parameters, then click Add parameters.
Click Generate code.
To view your generated code, navigate to the Generated code preview section. 
Click the name of the supported programming languages to view the generated code snippet.
Click Use generated code to use all the generated code snippets in the test. A confirmation message is displayed on the screen asking your permission to replace the existing code if any with the currently-generated code. Click Overwrite to use the generated code. If you wish to use the existing code, then click Don't use generated code.

Or
Click Cancel if you do not want to save the created code snippets. A confirmation message is displayed on your screen checking whether you want to discard the code snippets that you have created. Click Discard generated code to reject the automatically-generated code. If you want to keep your code, then click Cancel.
Click Publish changes to save your code snippets into the question.
You have successfully generated code snippets for your Programming questions.
You need to manually write or auto-generate code snippets for each language in which you want the candidates to attempt the question.
markdown:
# Code snippets

_This feature is enabled for all our customers._ 

A code snippet is a boilerplate code that can be used without changing it. This code helps such candidates who are not familiar with the online coding environment to focus more on the algorithm that is required to solve the question rather than understanding the STD INPUT and OUTPUT syntaxes. 

When a candidate writes code, it is evaluated using input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT). 

*   STDIN: The default source of providing input to any computer program.
*   STDOUT: The default channel where the output of the program is written.

![codesnip_1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/codesnip_1-1.png)

In HackerEarth Assessment's in-built library, code snippets can be generated for Programming questions in the following languages:

*   C
*   C++
*   C++14
*   C++17
*   C#
*   Java
*   Java 8
*   JavaScript(Node.js)
*   PHP
*   Python
*   Python 3
*   Ruby
*   Go
*   Kotlin
*   Objective-C
*   Python 3.8
*   Ruby
*   Scala
*   Swift

These code stubs are already loaded in the code editor of a question for candidates to use when they are attempting the test.

### Use of code snippets

Candidates who take online coding tests are usually not familiar with the online coding process. There may not be enough time for a candidate to understand HackerEarth’s evaluation process—specifically how the input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT) must be written to ensure that the evaluation process runs correctly.

If the code snippet is already available, then the candidate can do the following:

*   Focus on writing the logic that is required to solve the problem
*   Not spend time figuring out the input (STDIN) and output (STDOUT) that needs to be used

**Example**

A candidate must write the code to add N numbers (1, 2, 3…N). The code will be as follows:

**Note**: The code has been written in different colors only for clarity. In this code, the colors mean the following:

*   **Blue** \= Input
*   **Orange** \= Logic
*   **Green** \= Output

![codesnip_2.PNG](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/codesnip_2-1.png)

Add the input and output in the form of a code snippet to this question. This becomes visible to the candidates when they are attempting this question. The candidates can then focus only on writing the logic required to calculate the sum of N numbers. 

![code_snippets.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/code_snippets-1.png?width=522&height=622&name=code_snippets-1.png)

### Generating code snippets

To generate code stubs for a Programming question, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of any tests in which you want to add code stubs to its Programming questions. For example, Algorithms test.
4.  In the **Test details** section, click **Questions**.
5.  Navigate to the Programming questions section and click the name of the question. The modal containing different parts of the question is displayed.
6.  Click **Edit question**.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-34-41-2620-AM.png)
7.  In the **Edit Programming question** section, click **Languages**.  
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-34-48-7523-AM.png)
8.  Navigate to the **Code snippets** section and click **Auto generate**.  
    ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-34-46-2883-AM.png)
9.  Enter or select the following details:
    *   Name of the function, for example, **func**
    *   Return type, for example, **Integer**
    *   Any comments that you want to add in your code, for example, **mycode**
    *   Notify whether there are multiple test cases in a single file
    *   Function parameter and name of the parameter, for example, **Character** and **test**  
        **Important**: If you want to add multiple parameters, then click **Add parameters**.
10.  Click **Generate code**.  
    ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-34-40-0894-AM.png)
11.  To view your generated code, navigate to the **Generated code preview** section. 
12.  Click the name of the supported programming languages to view the generated code snippet.  
    ![mceclip4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-34-47-4426-AM.png)
13.  Click **Use generated code** to use all the generated code snippets in the test. A confirmation message is displayed on the screen asking your permission to replace the existing code if any with the currently-generated code. Click **Overwrite** to use the generated code. If you wish to use the existing code, then click **Don't use generated code**.  
    ![mceclip5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip5-Jan-30-2023-11-34-45-1162-AM.png)  
    Or  
    Click **Cancel** if you do not want to save the created code snippets. A confirmation message is displayed on your screen checking whether you want to discard the code snippets that you have created. Click **Discard generated code** to reject the automatically-generated code. If you want to keep your code, then click **Cancel**.  
    ![mceclip6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-34-38-7833-AM.png)
14.  Click **Publish changes** to save your code snippets into the question.

You have successfully generated code snippets for your Programming questions.

You need to manually write or auto-generate code snippets for each language in which you want the candidates to attempt the question.
