text:
Reports
This is a premium feature. To enable this feature for your account, contact us at support@hackerearth.com.
HackerEarth Assessment has now introduced the feature where you can view and analyze the details of your account. A new dashboard is created that contains information about the number of tests that are created by using your account, the number of candidates who were invited to the tests, the number of candidates who attempted the test, and so on.
To view the details of your account, follow these steps:
Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Reports.
You can view the following information: 
Account data: This section contains insights about the tests that have been created from your account and candidates who have been invited to or have attempted these tests. You can also view these metrics within a selected range of dates. 
Overview: It depicts the comparison between the number of candidates who were invited to all the tests created by using your account, the number of candidates who attempted the tests, and the number of candidates who got shortlisted. You can download this report by clicking Download in the .xls format.
You can also get your data within a selected range of dates.
Invited vs. attempted candidates: It represents the comparison between the number of invited and attempted candidates for tests in the specified range of dates that have been created by using your account.
Tests: You can view the following information about tests that are created by using your account: 
Test name: The name of the test. For example, Senior Java Developer test.
Account name: The name of the administrator's account or your account that is used to create a test.
Team name: The name of the team to which you belong.
Test type: The type of the test, whether it is an Invite-only or a Public test. To know more about the types of tests, click here.
Created: The date and time when the test was created.
Created by: The email ID of the admin who created the test.
Total score: The total score of the test.
Invites: The number of candidates who are invited to attempt the test.
Test attempted: The number of candidates who have attempted the test.
Shortlisted: The number of candidates who are shortlisted to go to the next step in the hiring process.
Teams: You can view the following details about teams that are added to your account: 
Team name: The name of the team that is added to your account.
Total tests: The total number of tests created by a specific team.
Account name: The name of your account.
Invites: The number of invites sent by a specific team.
Test attempted: The number of candidates who attempted the tests created by a specific team.
Shortlisted: The number of candidates who got shortlisted in the tests created by a specific team.
Admins: You can view the following details about the admins who are added to your account: 
Admin name: The name of the admin who is added to your account.
Total tests: The total number of tests created by the admin.
Account name: The name of the account.
Invites: The total number of invites sent by the admin.
Test attempted: The total number of candidates who attempted the tests created by the admin.
Shortlisted: The number of candidates who got shortlisted in the tests that are created by the admin.
markdown:
# Reports

_This is a premium feature. To enable this feature for your account, contact us at support@hackerearth.com._

HackerEarth Assessment has now introduced the feature where you can view and analyze the details of your account. A new dashboard is created that contains information about the number of tests that are created by using your account, the number of candidates who were invited to the tests, the number of candidates who attempted the test, and so on.

To view the details of your account, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Reports**.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-48-3025-AM.png)
3.  You can view the following information:
    1.  **Account data**: This section contains insights about the tests that have been created from your account and candidates who have been invited to or have attempted these tests. You can also view these metrics within a selected range of dates.
        1.  _Overview_: It depicts the comparison between the number of candidates who were invited to all the tests created by using your account, the number of candidates who attempted the tests, and the number of candidates who got shortlisted. You can download this report by clicking **Download** in the **.xls** format.  
            You can also get your data within a selected range of dates.  
            ![image__70_.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12635805874969-1.png)
        2.  _Invited vs. attempted candidates_: It represents the comparison between the number of invited and attempted candidates for tests in the specified range of dates that have been created by using your account.  
            ![image__70__copy.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12635764464153-1.png)
    2.  **Tests**: You can view the following information about tests that are created by using your account:
        1.  _Test name_: The name of the test. For example, Senior Java Developer test.
        2.  _Account name_: The name of the administrator's account or your account that is used to create a test.
        3.  _Team name_: The name of the team to which you belong.
        4.  _Test type_: The type of the test, whether it is an Invite-only or a Public test. To know more about the types of tests, click [here](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004042134).
        5.  _Created_: The date and time when the test was created.
        6.  _Created by_: The email ID of the admin who created the test.
        7.  _Total score_: The total score of the test.
        8.  _Invites_: The number of candidates who are invited to attempt the test.
        9.  _Test attempted_:  The number of candidates who have attempted the test.
        10.  _Shortlisted_: The number of candidates who are shortlisted to go to the next step in the hiring process.  
            ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-36-51-2112-AM.png)
    3.  **Teams**: You can view the following details about teams that are added to your account:
        1.  _Team name_: The name of the team that is added to your account.
        2.  _Total tests_: The total number of tests created by a specific team.
        3.  _Account name_: The name of your account.
        4.  _Invites_: The number of invites sent by a specific team.
        5.  _Test attempted_: The number of candidates who attempted the tests created by a specific team.
        6.  _Shortlisted_: The number of candidates who got shortlisted in the tests created by a specific team.  
            ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-36-45-5068-AM.png)
    4.  **Admins**: You can view the following details about the admins who are added to your account:
        1.  _Admin name_: The name of the admin who is added to your account.
        2.  _Total tests_: The total number of tests created by the admin.
        3.  _Account name_: The name of the account.
        4.  _Invites_: The total number of invites sent by the admin.
        5.  _Test attempted_: The total number of candidates who attempted the tests created by the admin.
        6.  _Shortlisted_: The number of candidates who got shortlisted in the tests that are created by the admin.  
            ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-36-46-9076-AM.png)

text:
Sending reminders to candidates
To send reminders of tests to candidates, follow these steps:
Log in to your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Navigate to the test for which you want to send reminders to the candidates.

Note: You must publish the test to be able to invite candidates.
In the Candidates section, click Invited.
Select the candidates to whom you want to send reminders for the test.
Important: You can send reminders to the candidates with the statuses 'Not attempted' or 'Test reset' only.
When you click Select now, the applicable row gets deselected. You can select relevant rows and continue.
Click Send reminder. You will see the following confirmation message on your screen.
Click Yes, send the reminder(s).
You have successfully sent the reminders.
You can also select auto-reminders, which will send the reminders automatically to the candidates after the initial invite. To learn more about auto-reminders, read this article.
How does auto-reminder work?
The first reminder is sent 48 hours after the initial invite if any of the following conditions happen:
The candidate hasn’t taken the test. 
The test invite hasn’t expired.
The test End Date is more than 48 hours in the future
If either the end date or expiration date is set, a reminder will be sent 24 hours before the test ends or before the invite expires, whichever comes first, if the candidate has not yet taken the test. If both the end date and expiration date are not set, a reminder will be sent one week after the invite was sent if the candidate has not taken the test yet.
markdown:
# Sending reminders to candidates

To send reminders of tests to candidates, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Navigate to the test for which you want to send reminders to the candidates.  
    _  
    Note:_ You must publish the test to be able to invite candidates.

1.  In the **Candidates** section, click **Invited**.
2.  Select the candidates to whom you want to send reminders for the test.
    
    _Important__:_ You can send reminders to the candidates with the statuses '**Not attempted**' or '**Test reset**' only.
    
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-44-13-6745-AM.png?width=621&height=282&name=mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-44-13-6745-AM.png)
    
    When you click **Select now**, the applicable row gets deselected. You can select relevant rows and continue.
    
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-44-12-3406-AM.png?width=610&height=223&name=mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-44-12-3406-AM.png)
    
3.  Click **Send reminder**. You will see the following confirmation message on your screen.
    
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip7-Jan-30-2023-11-44-10-7456-AM.png)
    
4.  Click **Yes, send the reminder(s)**.

You have successfully sent the reminders.

You can also select auto-reminders, which will send the reminders automatically to the candidates after the initial invite. To learn more about auto-reminders, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002887413-test-settings).

### How does auto-reminder work?

The first reminder is sent 48 hours after the initial invite if any of the following conditions happen:

*   *   The candidate hasn’t taken the test. 
    *   The test invite hasn’t expired.
    *   The test End Date is more than 48 hours in the futureIf either the end date or expiration date is set, a reminder will be sent 24 hours before the test ends or before the invite expires, whichever comes first, if the candidate has not yet taken the test. If both the end date and expiration date are not set, a reminder will be sent one week after the invite was sent if the candidate has not taken the test yet.

text:
Sending invites to candidates
The article talks about how to invite the candidates to take the assessment. 
To invite candidates, follow these steps:
1. Log in to your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
2. Click Assessments.
3. Navigate to the assessment for which you want to invite candidates. Click Invite candidates. 

Important: You must publish the assessment to invite candidates.
4. You can also select the assessment and then click Invite candidates. 
5. You can invite the candidates by either of the two methods:
a. Inviting them by entering their information: You can only invite up to 5 candidates using this method. You need to enter the following information:
Email (mandatory)
First name
Last name
Click Add to add the candidate to the invite list. 
b. Inviting the candidates through bulk upload
I. Click upload multiple candidate detail.
II. To download the sample file, click download sample template.
III. Once you have filled out the sheet, upload it by clicking upload file.
You can select an expiration date for the invitation, but this is not mandatory. The invitation for the assessment will no longer be valid after the specified date has passed.
6. Click Invite candidates to invite all the added candidates. 
A notification will appear at the top of your screen once you have successfully invited candidates to take the test.
You can see all the invited candidates for the assessment under the Candidates section. Select Invited, and a list of invited candidates will be displayed.
markdown:
# Sending invites to candidates

## The article talks about how to invite the candidates to take the assessment.

To invite candidates, follow these steps:

1\. Log in to your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.

2\. Click **Assessments.**

3\. Navigate to the assessment for which you want to invite candidates. Click **Invite candidates**.  
![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/L25khikz1eeMuRrzHsVTwFDys_8-IBzaycQ1ugyubl3EtK-HbFNWRlQC0AsrRy6I02K_-b2dAtfpzeNVWZueGrAohIxRb-dpiTywf79STk4iUfh_Z6jM1AuCCTruCtB60J382EFrmV-L-i2uaBpsOBc)  
_Important:_ You must publish the assessment to invite candidates.

4\. You can also select the assessment and then click **Invite candidates**. 

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/PxMYZg1gzopRFhsa5xvCJNB6pQOHfb51c1MKal00HccqADdDxBZztEacXjmgh8ILOPdmdOm2l6GNbQjQ2No3frBIvsxali52pzjNk5zU_QHEz-T_s6F_nxwp-FEgXWC4pAL_BNCRlC2SbSuKabJIndQ)

5\. You can invite the candidates by either of the two methods:

**a. Inviting them by entering their information**: You can only invite up to 5 candidates using this method. You need to enter the following information:

1.  1.  1.  Email (mandatory)
        2.  First name
        3.  Last name  
            Click **Add** to add the candidate to the invite list. 

**b. Inviting the candidates through bulk upload**

I. Click **upload multiple candidate detail**.

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/HGYGD6V1JIfuwrIGIArlqZfv6mOzHP3esMOTDUTks_LFedg7Ltw2kIJjYIOZ--0zY1YjYGN2pKWj1Z1TpxHG7gi6JbmN66scOvRTeodcONSTBFw5FKGd68Iu3DiHqVkzr4DiRxjWno_62fQoYaHif9M)

II. To download the sample file, click **download sample template.**

III. Once you have filled out the sheet, upload it by clicking **upload file**.

You can select an expiration date for the invitation, but this is not mandatory. The invitation for the assessment will no longer be valid after the specified date has passed.

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/i0GpOrgcYMCa2sJwNH1ElWRd-XHNL_URRRq5rHjWOvh-BIKrJDpT77WG8BlZviJSWwciOD1DmKkvSV0GJ7eYmNcPF9w7YN1P4jkddnP0uY2sA0gVz0RXTFuLzEaDEPVlrEWecG21_8LI4RBMuM6ASPs)

6\. Click **Invite candidates** to invite all the added candidates. 

A notification will appear at the top of your screen once you have successfully invited candidates to take the test.

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/SFzlYEDaQZMGTt4HZRZogMLYk58Lk20CPcfzXWmZ-9QKLruxGv4904LOyHyBLDFRILYKDjse0CdDWtnzWujTvrdlFDYDbh0IcFn6ow28yqzaD7zusQSOpJRKzJjLycNH4Bf1NN5uoYTinhd9iMLCrpQ)

You can see all the invited candidates for the assessment under the **Candidates** section. Select **Invited,** and a list of invited candidates will be displayed.

![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/Q5ulaF2l6cHX55zCCac7B-_KWwWSQGqlz8mnA60sHDhCRdmBrgGotiWK3JJrX_vrG7ItrTILfzq0rEncIn1sSzlMREpsrPBxU6J7Te50gY7u5FrULZUr4gRW-M0Btx7aeoyh1xylL-IVk0t-uwGxRCU)

Downloading auto-generated invites

3. Invited on: This column contains the date on which the candidate is invited to take the test

5. Invite type: This column contains the type of invite.

3\. **Invited on**: This column contains the date on which the candidate is invited to take the test

4\. **Invited by**: This column contains the email ID of the test admin

5\. **Invite type**: This column contains the type of invite.

text:
Auto-generated invites
This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager. 
This feature allows you to create anonymous invitation links for your test. As the name 'anonymous' suggests, the details of the candidates who use these links to take tests will not be visible to HackerEarth. This means that HackerEarth will not be able to save the data of such candidates.
Advantages
Candidates can directly click the link to take the test
Allows the candidate to take the test without a user profile on HackerEarth platform thus providing anonymity
Important: HackerEarth will not be able to help you with the details of candidates as no details are entered into the system. Therefore, it is important that you map and store these details by downloading them from your HackerEarth Recruit account.
Format
The format of an auto-generated invite is as follows:
<Name of the company-testID-invite sequence-hackerearthcandidate.com>
The invite sequence in each candidate ID helps you to track the number of invites and the corresponding candidates.
Test status
You can view the status of a candidate's test. 
S. No. Title Description 
1	Candidate email	Auto-generated email IDs 	
2	Candidate name	This will remain blank because the candidate's name is not available.	
3	Status	
Active: Candidates who have completed the test
Currently taking: Candidates who are taking the test at the present time
Test reset: Reset a test for a candidate or all the candidates
Not attempted: Candidates who have not started the test 
Offered: Candidates who have passed the test and shortlisted by the recruiter
Archived: Candidates who are rejected or have underperformed the test
	
4	Invited on	Date on which the candidate is invited to take the test	
5	Invited by	Email ID of the test admin	
6	Email status	
Read: Candidate has read the email
Unknown: Data is unavailable or an internal error has occurred
Delivered: Invite email was delivered to candidate's mailbox
Undelivered: Invite email was not delivered because the email is either dropped or bounced back
Processed: Invite has been processed successfully but yet to be delivered
Not available: Data is unavailable for older invites
	
7	Anonymous email IDs	Email IDs generated by the HackerEarth Recruit anonymously 	
8	Email ID	Email ID of a particular candidate that is used to invite to take up the test

# Auto-generated invites _This is a premium feature. If you want it enabled for your account, please contact your account manager._  This feature allows you to create anonymous invitation links for your test. As the name 'anonymous' suggests, the details of the candidates who use these links to take tests will not be visible to HackerEarth. This means that HackerEarth will not be able to save the data of such candidates. **Advantages** * Candidates can directly click the link to take the test * Allows the candidate to take the test without a user profile on HackerEarth platform thus providing anonymity _Important:_ HackerEarth will not be able to help you with the details of candidates as no details are entered into the system. Therefore, it is important that you map and store these details by [downloading them](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005407033-downloading-auto-generated-invites) from your HackerEarth Recruit account. **Format** The format of an auto-generated invite is as follows: **** The invite sequence in each candidate ID helps you to track the number of invites and the corresponding candidates. **Test status** You can view the status of a candidate's test.  ![mceclip2](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mceclip2.png?width=688&height=195&name=mceclip2.png) | **S. No.** | **Title** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | Candidate email | Auto-generated email IDs | | 2 | Candidate name | This will remain blank because the candidate's name is not available. | | 3 | Status | _Active_: Candidates who have completed the test

_Currently taking_: Candidates who are taking the test at the present time

_Test reset_: Reset a test for a candidate or all the candidates

_Not attempted_: Candidates who have not started the test 

_Offered_: Candidates who have passed the test and shortlisted by the recruiter

_Archived_: Candidates who are rejected or have underperformed the test | | 4 | Invited on | Date on which the candidate is invited to take the test | | 5 | Invited by | Email ID of the test admin | | 6 | Email status | _Read_: Candidate has read the email

_Unknown_: Data is unavailable or an internal error has occurred

_Delivered_: Invite email was delivered to candidate's mailbox

text:
Viewing invites
You can view your plan details and track your invite usage by following these steps:
1. Log in to your HackerEarth account.
2. Click Billing and settings.
3. Select Billing.
You can see the relevant details in the Your current plan & usage section.
Plan and usage components
Total invites
Refers to the total number of invites that you received with your subscription.
Remaining invites
This is the number of invites that you have not yet used.
Remaining invites = Total invites – invites used
Admins
Super admins
The total number of super admins that you can have in your organization.
Other admins
The total number of admins who do not have super admins' permission.
Invites usage
Assessments
Used invites
This is the total number of invites that you have used for assessments.
Cancelable invites
These are the invites in which candidates have been invited to take the assessment but have not participated yet.
FaceCode
Created interviews
These are the number of FaceCode interviews created by you.
Ongoing interviews
These are the number of interviews created by you but the candidate has not joined the interview yet.
Conducted interviews
These are the number of FaceCode interviews conducted by you.
Hours of interviews conducted by you
These are the number of hours of interviews conducted by you.
markdown:
# Viewing invites

You can view your plan details and track your invite usage by following these steps:

1\. Log in to your HackerEarth account.

2\. Click **Billing and settings**.

3\. Select **Billing.**

**![Screenshot_from_2022-11-28_17-04-06.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12947780447001-Jan-30-2023-11-22-24-8588-AM.png?width=196&height=285&name=12947780447001-Jan-30-2023-11-22-24-8588-AM.png)**

You can see the relevant details in the **Your current plan & usage** section.

![Screenshot_from_2022-11-28_17-05-51.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12947851697305-2.png)

## **Plan and usage components**

### **Total invites**

Refers to the total number of invites that you received with your subscription.

### Remaining invites

This is the number of invites that you have not yet used.

_Remaining invites = Total invites – invites used_

### **Admins  
**

####     **Super admins**

The total number of super admins that you can have in your organization.

#### **Other admins**

     The total number of admins who do not have super admins' permission.

### **Invites usage**

####     **Assessments**

#### **Used invites**

This is the total number of invites that you have used for assessments.

#### **Cancelable invites**

These are the invites in which candidates have been invited to take the assessment but have not participated yet.

**FaceCode**

**Created interviews**

These are the number of FaceCode interviews created by you.

#### **Ongoing interviews**

These are the number of interviews created by you but the candidate has not joined the interview yet.

#### **Conducted interviews**

These are the number of FaceCode interviews conducted by you.

#### **Hours of interviews conducted by you**

These are the number of hours of interviews conducted by you.

text:
Canceling invites
To cancel invites, follow these steps:
Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Navigate to the test in which you want to cancel invites.
In the Candidates section, click Invited.
Select the candidates whose invites you want to cancel.
If you select candidates who have already taken tests or whose tests have been reset, you will see the following message on your screen.

When you click Select now, the rows that are not applicable are deselected. You can select relevant rows and continue.
Click Cancel invite. You will see the following confirmation message on your screen.
Click Yes, cancel the invite(s).
You have successfully cancelled the invites.
What happens when an invite is canceled?
The invites that you cancel are added to your Remaining invites.
markdown:
# Canceling invites

To cancel invites, follow these steps:

1.  Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Navigate to the test in which you want to cancel invites.
4.  In the **Candidates** section, click **Invited**.
5.  Select the candidates whose invites you want to cancel.
    
    If you select candidates who have already taken tests or whose tests have been reset, you will see the following message on your screen.
    
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-41-29-3731-AM.png?width=654&height=268&name=mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-41-29-3731-AM.png)  
    When you click **Select now**, the rows that are not applicable are deselected. You can select relevant rows and continue.
    
6.  Click **Cancel invite**. You will see the following confirmation message on your screen.
    
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-41-33-7444-AM.png)
    
7.  Click **Yes, cancel the invite(s)**.

You have successfully cancelled the invites.

![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-41-32-1988-AM.png)

## **What happens when an invite is canceled?**

The invites that you cancel are added to your **Remaining** invites.  

![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip7-Jan-30-2023-11-41-30-7991-AM.png)

text:
Invite email template
By default, HackerEarth Recruit provides an invite email template that can be used by you to send invite emails to the candidates. This template can be edited by you at your preference. The invite email template is shown below.
It comprises the following strings, which will be replaced by text:
It is recommended that you do not remove these strings while composing your invite email.
The body of the invite email comprises the following information:
Test duration: Number of minutes within which the candidate should finish the test
Test link: Link to access the test
Login credentials: Login details of the test
Information: Important information regarding the test
Practice test link: Link to the practice test that helps candidates get familiar with the HackerEarth Recruit platform
Edit email invite template 
You can also edit your email invite template by following these steps:
1. Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.
2. Click Assessments.
3. Navigate to the test for which you want to invite candidates.

Important: You must publish the test to be able to invite candidates. 
4. Click Invite Candidates.
5. Click View details under the Email section.
6. An invite email template will open up that can be edited by you. After you have made the changes, click Save.
You can now invite candidates using the email template.
markdown:
# Invite email template

By default, HackerEarth Recruit provides an invite email template that can be used by you to send invite emails to the candidates. This template can be edited by you at your preference. The invite email template is shown below.

![invitetemplate.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/invitetemplate-3.png)

It comprises the following strings, which will be replaced by text:

It is recommended that you do not remove these strings while composing your invite email.  
The body of the invite email comprises the following information:

1.  **Test duration**: Number of minutes within which the candidate should finish the test
2.  **Test link**: Link to access the test
3.  **Login credentials**: Login details of the test
4.  **Information**: Important information regarding the test
5.  **Practice test link**: Link to the practice test that helps candidates get familiar with the HackerEarth Recruit platform

### Edit email invite template     

You can also edit your email invite template by following these steps:

1\. Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using your admin credentials.

2\. Click **Assessments.**

3\. Navigate to the test for which you want to invite candidates.  
_Important:_ You must publish the test to be able to invite candidates. 

4\. Click **Invite Candidates**.

5\. Click **View details** under the **Email** section.

          ![Screenshot_from_2022-12-05_10-40-01.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13168325921689-3.png)

6\. An invite email template will open up that can be edited by you. After you have made the changes, click **Save**.

![Screenshot_from_2022-12-05_10-44-18.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13168435205785-3.png)

You can now invite candidates using the email template.

text:
General components of a candidate assessment report
The Candidate assessment report is generated after a candidate has successfully completed the test. This report is generated for recruiters to share with candidates. You can view the following information in this report:
1. Name of the company
2. Name of the test
3. Report URL
4. Rank of the candidate
5. Total score achieved by the candidate
6. Number of questions attempted by the candidate
Test time analysis
1. Represents the test invite time
2. Represents the time the candidate started the test
3. Represents the time the candidate ended the test
4. Represents the total duration taken by the candidate to complete the test
Skill-wise performance 
In this graph, the X-axis represents the score (in percentage) that has been obtained by the candidate with respect to a specific skill. The Y-axis represents each skill along with the total number of skills available in the test. 
You can view a candidate's score for a specific skill that is added to the test. You can assess the candidate's proficiency in a skill by comparing their score to the average score obtained by all the other candidates for that specific skill in the test.
The average score is determined by calculating the average of all the scores obtained by all the candidates for that specific skill.
Skill-specific performance: Key observations 
You can view the points to heed cards that are related to the candidate's performance with respect to skills. These cards contain various achievements that a candidate has earned in a specific skill. For example, the highest score in basic programming, the second-highest score in Python, etc.
Candidate's information 
You can view the information that has been provided by the candidate while starting the test. These fields must be selected by you while configuring the setting of the test. For more information, see Candidate settings. 
The following details are displayed:
Email ID
Contact number
Designation
Location
Programming languages that the candidate knows
Education details
Candidate's photograph (if uploaded)
Key observations
S. No.	Function	
1.	Displays the integrity index of a candidate	
2.	Displays the number of tab switches done by the candidate	
3.	Displays the test duration used by the candidate to complete the test	
4.	Displays if the candidate has done some plagiarism in the answers	
5.	Displays whether the ID verification is successful or not. You can also see the uploaded images by clicking View.	
6.	Displays if the candidate is a top performer in a particular skill	
7.	Displays if the candidate is a top performer in a particular skill	
8.	Displays if the candidate snapshots are meeting the proctoring guidelines	
Detailed submission report
You can view the detailed report of the best solution that has been submitted by the candidate.
1. Problem name states the name of the programming problem.
2. Problem description states the description of the problem statement.
3. Time states the time the candidate's code takes to pass the test cases.
4. Score states the total score the candidate achieves for the problem.
5. Time complexity states the time complexity of the candidate's solution.
6. Space complexity states the space complexity of the candidate's solution.
7. Memory states the memory space taken by the candidate's solution.
8. Language states the language in which the candidate wrote the code.
9. Submitted on signifies the date and time on which the candidate submitted the code.
10. No. of attempts states the number of attempts the candidate took to solve the problem.
11. Code quality is the metric that states the quality of the code written by the candidate.
12. Score states the total score the candidate achieved out of the total allotted score.
Available only for programming questions
markdown:
# General components of a candidate assessment report

The Candidate assessment report is generated after a candidate has successfully completed the test. This report is generated for recruiters to share with candidates. You can view the following information in this report:

![candidate_assessment_report_1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/candidate_assessment_report_1-3.png)

1\. Name of the company

2\. Name of the test

3\. Report URL

4\. Rank of the candidate

5\. Total score achieved by the candidate

6\. Number of questions attempted by the candidate

#### Test time analysis

![candidate_assessment_time_analysis.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/candidate_assessment_time_analysis-3.png)

1\. Represents the test invite time

2\. Represents the time the candidate started the test

3\. Represents the time the candidate ended the test

4\. Represents the total duration taken by the candidate to complete the test

#### Skill-wise performance 

![candidate_assessment_skill_wise_performance.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/candidate_assessment_skill_wise_performance-3.png)

In this graph, the X-axis represents the score (in percentage) that has been obtained by the candidate with respect to a specific skill. The Y-axis represents each skill along with the total number of skills available in the test. 

You can view a candidate's score for a specific skill that is added to the test. You can assess the candidate's proficiency in a skill by comparing their score to the average score obtained by all the other candidates for that specific skill in the test.

The average score is determined by calculating the average of all the scores obtained by all the candidates for that specific skill.

Skill-specific performance: Key observations

![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-24-30-3756-AM.png)

You can view the **points to heed** cards that are related to the candidate's performance with respect to skills. These cards contain various achievements that a candidate has earned in a specific skill. For example, the highest score in basic programming, the second-highest score in Python, etc.

Candidate's information

![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-24-31-7628-AM.png)

You can view the information that has been provided by the candidate while starting the test. These fields must be selected by you while configuring the setting of the test. For more information, see [Candidate settings](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002904874-candidate-settings).   

The following details are displayed:

*   Email ID
*   Contact number
*   Designation
*   Location
*   Programming languages that the candidate knows
*   Education details
*   Candidate's photograph (if uploaded)

**Key observations**

![image (9)-1](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image%20(9)-1.png?width=688&height=348&name=image%20(9)-1.png)

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| **S. No.** | **Function** |
| 1.  | Displays the integrity index of a candidate |
| 2.  | Displays the number of tab switches done by the candidate |
| 3.  | Displays the test duration used by the candidate to complete the test |
| 4.  | Displays if the candidate has done some plagiarism in the answers |
| 5.  | Displays whether the ID verification is successful or not. You can also see the uploaded images by clicking **View.** |
| 6.  | Displays if the candidate is a top performer in a particular skill |
| 7.  | Displays if the candidate is a top performer in a particular skill |
| 8.  | Displays if the candidate snapshots are meeting the proctoring guidelines |

### Detailed submission report

You can view the detailed report of the best solution that has been submitted by the candidate.

![Screenshot from 2023-03-14 14-26-14 (1)](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screenshot%20from%202023-03-14%2014-26-14%20(1).png?width=688&height=338&name=Screenshot%20from%202023-03-14%2014-26-14%20(1).png)

1\. **Problem name** states the name of the programming problem.

2\. **Problem description** states the description of the problem statement.

3\. **Time** states the time the candidate's code takes to pass the test cases.

4\. **Score** states the total score the candidate achieves for the problem.

5\. **Time complexity** states the time complexity of the candidate's solution.

6\. **Space complexity** states the space complexity of the candidate's solution.

7\. **Memory** states the memory space taken by the candidate's solution.

8\. **Language** states the language in which the candidate wrote the code.

9\. **Submitted on** signifies the date and time on which the candidate submitted the code.

10\. **No. of attempts** states the number of attempts the candidate took to solve the problem.

11\. **Code quality** is the metric that states the quality of the code written by the candidate.

12\. **Score** states the total score the candidate achieved out of the total allotted score.

**Available only for programming questions**

markdown:
# Viewing reports

You can view detailed reports about each candidate’s performance in your HackerEarth Assessment account. These reports provide you with the required information that will allow you to understand whether the candidate matches your requirements. You can test a candidate on various skills and view their performance in each skill. For example, if your requirement is to hire a Python developer, you can test the candidate in Django and JavaScript skills. The candidate report contains the details of how the candidate has performed in each question related to each of the mentioned skills.

## Viewing a report

You can view a candidate assessment report only after the candidate has taken the test.

To view a candidate’s test report, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  In the **Tests** section, click **Ongoing** to view the ongoing tests that have been created from your account.
4.  Click the name of the test for which you want to view or download a candidate report.
    
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-42-44-5692-AM.png)
    
    **Note**: You can view or download the candidate report of a test only if at least one candidate has taken the test.
    
5.  You will be redirected to the **Test** page that is displayed as follows:
    
    ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-42-38-6508-AM.png)
    
6.  In the **Candidates** section, click **Test taken** or **Review pending**.
7.  Click the name of the candidate. For example, _Charles Smith_.
    
    **Note**: You can generate the reports for candidates who have attempted the test.
    

Now, you can successfully view the candidate report of this test.

To download or copy the link to the candidate assessment report, follow these steps:

1.  Follow Step 1 to Step 7.
2.  Click ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-42-40-9807-AM.png).
3.  Click **Candidate assessment report**.
4.  To copy the link to the report, click **Copy report link**.  
    Or  
    To download the report, click **Download report**.
    
    ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-42-42-3993-AM.png)  
    **Note**: This link allows anyone to view the report without having access to HackerEarth Assessment.
    
5.  The notifications that are displayed after copying the link to the report and downloading the report are as follows:
    1.  **Copy**: ![mceclip2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-42-39-8228-AM.png)
    2.  **Download**: ![mceclip3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip3-Jan-30-2023-11-42-45-8027-AM.png)

You have successfully copied the link to the candidate assessment report or downloaded the same.

To know more about candidate assessment reports, click [here](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004080654).

text:
FaceCode plan
Invites usage
Total invites
This is the total number of invites that you have used. 
Remaining invites
This is the number of invites that you have not yet used.
Remaining invites = Test invites – invites used
Extra invites used
This is the additional number of invites that you have used after exhausting all the invites that came with your plan.
Extra invites = Invites used – test invites
For example, assume that you received 20 invites with your plan. Other than the 20 invites, you have also consumed additional 15 invites. Thus, in total, you have used 35 invites.
Extra invites: 35 – 20 = 15
Invite type
Created interviews
This is the number of interviews you have created.
Ongoing interviews
This is the number of interviews that are created but the candidate has not joined the interview yet. 
Conducted interviews
These are the number of interviews which are conducted by you which means they are the number of completed interviews
Hrs of interviews conducted
This displays the hours of interviews conducted by you.
markdown:
# FaceCode plan

![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/image-0-Jan-30-2023-11-23-43-0528-AM.png)

## **Invites usage**

**Total invites**

This is the total number of invites that you have used. 

### **Remaining invites**

This is the number of invites that you have not yet used.

_Remaining invites = Test invites – invites used_

### **Extra invites used**

This is the additional number of invites that you have used after exhausting all the invites that came with your plan.

_Extra invites = Invites used – test invites_

For example, assume that you received 20 invites with your plan. Other than the 20 invites, you have also consumed additional 15 invites. Thus, in total, you have used 35 invites.

_Extra invites: 35 – 20 = 15_

## **Invite type**

### **Created interviews**

This is the number of interviews you have created.

### **Ongoing interviews**

This is the number of interviews that are created but the candidate has not joined the interview yet.

### **Conducted interviews**

These are the number of interviews which are conducted by you which means they are the number of completed interviews

### **Hrs of interviews conducted**

This displays the hours of interviews conducted by you.

text:
Benchmarking the performance of candidates
HackerEarth Assessment has introduced the feature of benchmarking the performance of candidates based on the test level and global or product level.
Test benchmarking
The performance of a candidate is compared with all other candidates who have attempted the same test.
Global benchmarking
The performance of a candidate is compared with the performance of all the candidates who have attempted the tests that have been similarly designed and conducted on HackerEarth Assessments.
Viewing the benchmarking analysis
To view this analysis, follow these steps:
Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
Navigate to the test that you have created.
Note: This feature is only available for the ongoing and completed tests.
Select any of the options in the Candidate status section. For example, Review pending.
Click on the name of the candidate who has attempted the test.
You can successfully view the benchmarking feature in the candidate's profile.
Based on the image:
Global benchmark: The candidate is among the top 5 percent of candidates who have attempted all the similarly-designed tests that have been conducted on HackerEarth Assessments.
Test benchmark: The candidate is among the top 20 percent of the candidates who have attempted the same test.
Important
The test benchmark is a derived representation of the percentile score of the candidates who have attempted the test.
The global benchmark is calculated based on the number of attempts by a candidate attempts on the problems that are available in the test and the past number of attempts of the same problems.
The minimum number of attempts of a problem must be 400 for using it to derive the benchmarking derivative. 
The problem-level benchmark is calculated and aggregated to calculate the global benchmark for the test.
The benchmark is updated once when participation is over and recalculated when the event or test is over.
For events that do not have an end date, seven days from the last participation end date is considered as the virtual end date to update the benchmarks on a regular basis.
The test and global benchmarks for the candidate participation are only visible if it is less than the maximum threshold value that is 50 percent.
It is a custom plan feature and is disabled by default. To enable it for your account, contact us at support@hackerearth.com.
markdown:
# Benchmarking the performance of candidates

HackerEarth Assessment has introduced the feature of benchmarking the performance of candidates based on the test level and global or product level.

### **Test benchmarking**

The performance of a candidate is compared with all other candidates who have attempted the same test.

### **Global benchmarking**

The performance of a candidate is compared with the performance of all the candidates who have attempted the tests that have been similarly designed and conducted on HackerEarth Assessments.

### **Viewing the benchmarking analysis**

To view this analysis, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to HackerEarth Assessments by using your admin credentials.
2.  Navigate to the test that you have created.  
    **Note**: This feature is only available for the ongoing and completed tests.
3.  Select any of the options in the Candidate status section. For example, **Review pending**.
4.  Click on the name of the candidate who has attempted the test.

You can successfully view the benchmarking feature in the candidate's profile.

![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-28-28-7512-AM.png)

Based on the image:

*   **Global benchmark**: The candidate is among the top 5 percent of candidates who have attempted all the similarly-designed tests that have been conducted on HackerEarth Assessments.
*   **Test benchmark**: The candidate is among the top 20 percent of the candidates who have attempted the same test.

Important

*   The test benchmark is a derived representation of the percentile score of the candidates who have attempted the test.
*   The global benchmark is calculated based on the number of attempts by a candidate attempts on the problems that are available in the test and the past number of attempts of the same problems.
*   The minimum number of attempts of a problem must be 400 for using it to derive the benchmarking derivative. 
*   The problem-level benchmark is calculated and aggregated to calculate the global benchmark for the test.
*   The benchmark is updated once when participation is over and recalculated when the event or test is over.
*   For events that do not have an end date, seven days from the last participation end date is considered as the virtual end date to update the benchmarks on a regular basis.
*   The test and global benchmarks for the candidate participation are only visible if it is less than the maximum threshold value that is 50 percent.
*   It is a custom plan feature and is disabled by default. To enable it for your account, contact us at support@hackerearth.com.

text:
Test analytics: Overview
HackerEarth Assessment enables you to see the overview of the test that is created by you. These reports are generated only after at least one candidate has attempted the test.
The Test analytics report provides you an overview of the performance of candidates based on their score, test completion time, etc.
Viewing the overview of tests
To see the overview of a specific test, follow these steps:
Log into your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click the type of tests. For example, Ongoing or Completed.
Click the name of the specific test whose overview you want to view.
In the Analytics section, click Overview.
You have successfully accessed the overview of your tests.
A test's overview contains the analysis that is performed on that test. The Test analytics section contains several reports that provide you an overview of the test based on the candidate performance, score obtained by candidates, time taken to complete a test, etc. You can view the following information in the Test analytics section of your test:
Candidate hiring funnel
This analysis is performed based on various parameters such as:
Number of candidates who are invited to attempt the test
Number of candidates who attempted the test
Number of candidates who cleared the cut-off score
Number of candidates who are shortlisted
Note: If a test is public, then the Invited candidates metric is not available in the hiring funnel. For more information, see Public test.
Test performance metrics
You can view the performance of your test with respect to all the tests that have been created on HackerEarth Assessment.
You can also set the cut-off score for your test. This allows you to make quick hiring decisions by shortlisting the candidates efficiently.
You can measure the performance of the test as follows:
When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is set
When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is not set
When a test is public and the cut-off score is set
When a test is public and the cut-off score is not set
When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is set
You can view the performance metric of the test based on the number of candidates who are invited and who have attempted the test with respect to all the tests that are available in HackerEarth Assessment.

The performance analysis of this test is as follows:
There is an 8% rise in the percentage of candidates who have attempted the test out of the total invited candidates compared to all tests.
There is a 22% drop in the percentage of candidates who have cleared the cut-off score with respect to all tests in HackerEarth Assessment
When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is not set
When the test is public and the cut-off score is set

The analysis of these types of tests is performed based on the percentage of candidates who have cleared the cut-off score out of the total candidates who have attempted the test.
Note: Public tests are open to anyone who has already registered for the challenge. Therefore, there are no invites sent to candidates to attempt the test.
When the test is public and the cut-off score is not set
Distribution of candidates based on the score
This distribution of candidates is based on the score that they have obtained in the test. The number of candidates who have scored between the specific range of scores (in percentage) is displayed. 
Distribution of candidates based on the completion time
The distribution of candidates who have completed the test based on the test completion time.
markdown:
# Test analytics: Overview

HackerEarth Assessment enables you to see the overview of the test that is created by you. These reports are generated only after at least one candidate has attempted the test.

The Test analytics report provides you an overview of the performance of candidates based on their score, test completion time, etc.

## Viewing the overview of tests

To see the overview of a specific test, follow these steps:

1.  Log into your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the type of tests. For example, **Ongoing** or **Completed**.
4.  Click the name of the specific test whose overview you want to view.
5.  In the **Analytics** section, click **Overview**.  
    ![analytics.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/analytics-3.png)

 You have successfully accessed the overview of your tests.

A test's overview contains the analysis that is performed on that test. The **Test analytics** section contains several reports that provide you an overview of the test based on the candidate performance, score obtained by candidates, time taken to complete a test, etc. You can view the following information in the **Test analytics** section of your test:

## Candidate hiring funnel

This analysis is performed based on various parameters such as:

*   Number of candidates who are invited to attempt the test
*   Number of candidates who attempted the test
*   Number of candidates who cleared the cut-off score
*   Number of candidates who are shortlisted

![star_mark.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/star_mark-Jan-30-2023-11-47-45-3241-AM.png)

**Note**: If a test is public, then the **Invited candidates** metric is not available in the hiring funnel. For more information, see [Public test](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004042134).

## Test performance metrics

You can view the performance of your test with respect to all the tests that have been created on HackerEarth Assessment.

You can also set the cut-off score for your test. This allows you to make quick hiring decisions by shortlisting the candidates efficiently.

You can measure the performance of the test as follows:

*   When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is set
*   When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is not set
*   When a test is public and the cut-off score is set
*   When a test is public and the cut-off score is not set

### When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is set

You can view the performance metric of the test based on the number of candidates who are invited and who have attempted the test with respect to all the tests that are available in HackerEarth Assessment.

![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-47-42-6649-AM.png)  
The performance analysis of this test is as follows:

1.  There is an 8% rise in the percentage of candidates who have attempted the test out of the total invited candidates compared to all tests.
2.  There is a 22% drop in the percentage of candidates who have cleared the cut-off score with respect to all tests in HackerEarth Assessment

### When a test is invite-only and the cut-off score is not set

![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-47-43-9853-AM.png)

### When the test is public and the cut-off score is set

![test_performance_metrics_2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/test_performance_metrics_2-3.png)  
The analysis of these types of tests is performed based on the percentage of candidates who have cleared the cut-off score out of the total candidates who have attempted the test.  
**Note**: Public tests are open to anyone who has already registered for the challenge. Therefore, there are no invites sent to candidates to attempt the test.

### When the test is public and the cut-off score is not set

![cut_off_score_not_set.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/cut_off_score_not_set-3.png)

## Distribution of candidates based on the score

This distribution of candidates is based on the score that they have obtained in the test. The number of candidates who have scored between the specific range of scores (in percentage) is displayed. 

![distribution_of_candidates_by_score.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/distribution_of_candidates_by_score-3.png)

## Distribution of candidates based on the completion time

The distribution of candidates who have completed the test based on the test completion time.

markdown:
# Requesting a plagiarism report

To request a plagiarism report, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Recruit account.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click on the test name for which you want to request the plagiarism report.
4.  In **Candidates**, click the categories of candidates for which you want to request the plagiarism report. For example, **Review pending.**

        ![Screenshot_from_2023-01-02_16-08-11.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/14123255225497-1.png)

         _Important_: You cannot request the plagiarism report for candidates in the **Invited** list.

     5. Click **Request reports.**

**![Screenshot_from_2023-01-02_16-10-04.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/14123283432729-1.png)**

6\. Click **Generate plagiarism report**.

You have successfully requested the plagiarism report.

**Viewing the report**

You will receive an email with a link to the report. When you click the link, your report will be downloaded in the .xlsx format.

![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-36-42-8251-AM.png?width=688&height=90&name=mceclip2-Jan-30-2023-11-36-42-8251-AM.png)

To view a detailed color-coded report, click the link in column D.

Read more about plagiarism insights on HackerEarth Recruit [here.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003777793-plagiarism-insights)

text:
Health score of questions
The following parameters are used to calculate the health score of a question in the HackerEarth library:
The number of times a question is used: This is calculated based on the number of tests in which a question is used.
The number of times candidates attempted a question: This is calculated based on the number of times a problem is attempted by candidates.
The number of users who solved a question: This is calculated based on the number of times a problem was solved fully or partially.
Delta days: This is calculated based on the number of days that have passed since the problem was last used.
Difficulty level: This is calculated based on the number of times a candidate solved/attempted a question.
markdown:
# Health score of questions

The following parameters are used to calculate the health score of a question in the HackerEarth library:

*   The number of times a question is used: This is calculated based on the number of tests in which a question is used.
*   The number of times candidates attempted a question: This is calculated based on the number of times a problem is attempted by candidates.
*   The number of users who solved a question: This is calculated based on the number of times a problem was solved fully or partially.
*   Delta days: This is calculated based on the number of days that have passed since the problem was last used.
*   Difficulty level: This is calculated based on the number of times a candidate solved/attempted a question.

text:
Question analytics
The Question analytics feature provides an analysis of the questions that have been added to your test. It helps you to determine the usability factor of each question in your test.
This report is generated by performing various analyses based on different parameters. The score that is assigned to a question determines the health of the question. This allows you to decide whether or not to add this question to your test.
The following score parameters are used to calculate the health of a question:
0-2.9: The health of the question is low.
3-6.9: The health of the question is satisfactory.
7-10: The health of the question is good.
Note: Currently, the question analytics section is available only for MCQs and programming questions.
Viewing the question analytics section
To view the question analytics section, follow these steps:
Log into HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
Click Tests.
Click Ongoing.
Click the name of the test in which you want to view the Question analytics section.
In the Test details section, click Questions.
Click the MCQ or programming question for which you want to view the Question analytics section.
Click Analytics.
You have successfully viewed the question analytics for this question.
Parts of the Question analytics section 
The initial analysis of a question is as follows:
Attributes used for analysis
S. No.	Description	
1	Copy the link to the question analytics report so that anyone can view the report without having to log into HackerEarth Assessment	
2	Download the Question analytics report in PDF	
3	Name of the problem	
4	Problem description	
5	Health and score of the question	
6	Date and time when the question is created	
Attempt rate of the question
You can view the number of candidates who have successfully solved and attempted the question. 
Attempt rate of the question in different programming languages
You can view the number of candidates who have solved and attempted the question in a specific programming language.
The X-axis represents the number of candidates.
The Y-axis represents different programming languages in which the candidates have attempted the question. 
If you hover over a bar, then the number of candidates who have solved and attempted the question in that specific programming language is displayed. For example, if you place your cursor on the C++ bar, then you can see that 16 candidates have solved that question and 35 candidates have attempted that question in C++.
Important: This distribution is not available for MCQs.
Score distribution
You can view the distribution of scores that are obtained by the candidates who have attempted a specific question.
The X-axis represents the ranges of scores obtained by the candidates.
The Y-axis represents the number of candidates. If you hover over a bar, then the exact number of candidates who have scored within that specific score range is displayed. 
For example, if you hover over the bar of the score range 40-49, then you see that 70 candidates have scored within that specific range. 
Question usage
You can view the volume of usage of a question in a specific year starting from September of that year to August of the next year. This distribution represents the number of candidates who have attempted this question in a specific month.
The X-axis represents the months in a year.
The Y-axis axis represents the number of candidates. If you hover over , then the number of candidates who have attempted this question in a specific month is displayed. 
For example, if you place your cursor on the point that is present above March 2019, then you see that 173 candidates have attempted that question in March 2019.
markdown:
# Question analytics

The Question analytics feature provides an analysis of the questions that have been added to your test. It helps you to determine the usability factor of each question in your test.

This report is generated by performing various analyses based on different parameters. The score that is assigned to a question determines the health of the question. This allows you to decide whether or not to add this question to your test.

The following score parameters are used to calculate the health of a question:

1.  0-2.9: The health of the question is low.
2.  3-6.9: The health of the question is satisfactory.
3.  7-10: The health of the question is good.![question_analytics.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/question_analytics-4.png)

**Note**: Currently, the question analytics section is available only for MCQs and programming questions.

### Viewing the question analytics section

To view the question analytics section, follow these steps:

1.  Log into HackerEarth Assessment by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click **Ongoing**.
4.  Click the name of the test in which you want to view the Question analytics section.
5.  In the T**est details** section, click **Questions.**
6.  Click the MCQ or programming question for which you want to view the Question analytics section.
7.  Click **Analytics**.

![Screenshot_from_2022-12-13_11-01-24.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/13448398403481-4.png?width=591&height=367&name=13448398403481-4.png)

You have successfully viewed the question analytics for this question.

Parts of the Question analytics section

The initial analysis of a question is as follows:

![blue_dot.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/blue_dot-Jan-30-2023-11-42-03-2653-AM.png)

Attributes used for analysis

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| **S. No.** | **Description** |
| 1   | Copy the link to the question analytics report so that anyone can view the report without having to log into HackerEarth Assessment |
| 2   | Download the Question analytics report in PDF |
| 3   | Name of the problem |
| 4   | Problem description |
| 5   | Health and score of the question |
| 6   | Date and time when the question is created |

### Attempt rate of the question

You can view the number of candidates who have successfully solved and attempted the question.   
![qa_attempt_rate.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/qa_attempt_rate-4.png)

### Attempt rate of the question in different programming languages

You can view the number of candidates who have solved and attempted the question in a specific programming language.  
![qa_attempt_rate_languages.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/qa_attempt_rate_languages-4.png)

*   The X-axis represents the number of candidates.
*   The Y-axis represents different programming languages in which the candidates have attempted the question.  
    If you hover over a bar, then the number of candidates who have solved and attempted the question in that specific programming language is displayed. For example, if you place your cursor on the C++ bar, then you can see that 16 candidates have solved that question and 35 candidates have attempted that question in C++.

Important: This distribution is not available for MCQs.

### Score distribution

You can view the distribution of scores that are obtained by the candidates who have attempted a specific question.

![qa_score_distribution.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/qa_score_distribution-4.png)

*   The X-axis represents the ranges of scores obtained by the candidates.
*   The Y-axis represents the number of candidates. If you hover over a bar, then the exact number of candidates who have scored within that specific score range is displayed.
    
    For example, if you hover over the bar of the score range 40-49, then you see that 70 candidates have scored within that specific range. 
    

### Question usage

You can view the volume of usage of a question in a specific year starting from September of that year to August of the next year. This distribution represents the number of candidates who have attempted this question in a specific month.

![qa_question_usage.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/qa_question_usage-4.png)

*   The X-axis represents the months in a year.
*   The Y-axis axis represents the number of candidates. If you hover over ![blue_dot.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/blue_dot-Jan-30-2023-11-41-51-7791-AM.png), then the number of candidates who have attempted this question in a specific month is displayed.
    
    For example, if you place your cursor on the point that is present above March 2019, then you see that 173 candidates have attempted that question in March 2019.

text:
Billing
Billing and usage give you an overview of your HackerEarth Recruit account. Here you can add and modify your payment method. You can also view information about your current plan, invites used, subscription end date, etc.
Where can I find my billing and usage details?
1. Log in to your HackerEarth account.
2. Click Billing and settings.
3. Click Billing.
Primary payment method
This refers to your credit card, which you will use to complete transactions in Recruit. Your billing address is displayed in this section.
You can add, change, or delete your payment method in the Primary Payment Method section.
Billing cycle
The billing cycle, irrespective of the plan that you have subscribed to, is from the 1st to 31st of every month. Your bill is generated on the 2nd of every month and your payment method is charged accordingly.
Billing cycle when you change your subscription
When you upgrade or downgrade plans, the billing is done on a pro-rata basis. 
Assume that you were in the Startup plan from June 1 to June 13. Your billing for this plan ends on the 13th. You upgrade to the Enterprise plan.
From June 13 to 30, you will be billed for the Enterprise plan.
If you use extra invites outside of your plan, you will be billed for these invites accordingly.
For more information about changing subscriptions, see Upgrading and downgrading your subscription plan.
markdown:
# Billing

Billing and usage give you an overview of your HackerEarth Recruit account. Here you can add and modify your payment method. You can also view information about your current plan, invites used, subscription end date, etc.

**Where can I find my billing and usage details?**

1\. Log in to your HackerEarth account.

2\. Click **Billing and settings**.

![Screenshot_from_2023-01-04_10-09-29.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/14183288753177-1.png)

3\. Click **Billing**.

**Primary payment method**

This refers to your credit card, which you will use to complete transactions in Recruit. Your billing address is displayed in this section.

![billing_and_usage_2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/billing_and_usage_2-1.png)

You can add, change, or delete your payment method in the **Primary Payment Method** section.

**Billing cycle**

The billing cycle, irrespective of the plan that you have subscribed to, is from the _1st to 31st of every month_. Your bill is generated on the 2nd of every month and your payment method is charged accordingly.

### **Billing cycle when you change your subscription**

When you upgrade or downgrade plans, the billing is done on a pro-rata basis. 

Assume that you were in the Startup plan from June 1 to June 13. Your billing for this plan ends on the 13th. You upgrade to the Enterprise plan.

From June 13 to 30, you will be billed for the Enterprise plan.  
If you use extra invites outside of your plan, you will be billed for these invites accordingly.

For more information about changing subscriptions, see [Upgrading and downgrading your subscription plan.](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360003204753-upgrading-and-downgrading-your-subscription)

markdown:
# Code player

HackerEarth Assessment's code player records candidates' keystrokes such that it can be played as a video. This helps you verify their approach to the solution and minimize any possibility of cheating. 

This feature is only available for programming questions.

### Prerequisites

1.  You have created and published the test.
2.  The candidates have taken the test.
3.  You are [viewing a candidate report](https://support.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004036334-Viewing-reports).

### Process

To play code written by a candidate, follow these steps:

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessment account by using your admin credentials.
2.  Click **Tests**.
3.  Click the name of the test in which you want to view the code submission of a candidate.
4.  In the **Candidates** section, click **Test taken**, **Review pending**, **Shortlisted**, or **Archived**.
5.  Click the name of the candidate whose code submission you want to see.
6.  In the Detailed submission report, go to the **Programming questions** section. 
7.  Click ![mceclip7.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip7-Jan-30-2023-11-38-12-0144-AM.png) beside the name of the question in which you want to view the code submission.
8.  Click **Play code**.   
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-38-14-8797-AM.png)  
    You are redirected to the **Code player** page.
9.  Select the programming question in which you want to see code. For example, C#.
10.  Click ![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-38-16-1929-AM.png).
11.  You can also change the playback speed of the video to **1x**, **2x**, or **5x** of the original playback speed of the video. By default, the speed is set to **1x**.  
    ![mceclip4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip4-Jan-30-2023-11-38-13-4965-AM.png)
12.  You can also view the key highlights of the submission when the video is being played or by clicking ![mceclip5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip5-Jan-30-2023-11-38-17-4327-AM.png). Here, the date and time of the events are also displayed.  
    ![mceclip6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip6-Jan-30-2023-11-38-18-7551-AM.png)

You have successfully viewed code of a candidate to analyze the logical and analytical skills of the candidate.

# Current plan and usage

You can view your current plan and usage in the Billing and Usage section. 

Let's understand what you see on the screen. You can see the relevant details in the **Your current plan & usage** section.

![Screenshot_from_2022-11-28_17-05-51.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12947851697305-3.png)

## **Plan and usage components**

### **Total invites**

Refers to the total number of invites that you received with your subscription.

### Remaining invites

This is the number of invites that you have not yet used.

_Remaining invites = Total invites – invites used_

### **Admins  
**

####     **Super admins**

These are the invites in which candidates have been invited to take the assessment but have not participated yet.

These are the number of FaceCode interviews conducted by you.

These are the number of hours of interviews conducted by you.
