metadata.title: Workable FaceCode integration
metadata.description: Workable has now integrated with FaceCode interviews and you can enable the interviews by following the given steps: Login to your workable profile and go to settings -> integrations (https://{company

openGraph.content: Workable has now integrated with FaceCode interviews and you can enable the interviews by following the given steps: Login to your workable profile and go to settings -> integrations (https://{company

text:
Workable FaceCode integration
Workable has now integrated with FaceCode interviews and you can enable the interviews by following the given steps:
Enable FaceCode from Workable
Login to your workable profile and go to settings -> integrations (https://{company-name}.workable.com/backend/settings/integrations)
In the Integrations section under Video Interview Providers, click on HackerEarth FaceCode tab and paste the API key there and click update settings.
Generate Access Token in the Workable integrations page and copy the token. Even copy the workable domain, which is in the form *.workable.com
Open the HackerEarth integrations page and paste both the values (Access Token, Workable Domain) in the relevant fields, and click Save.
Your Workable is now integrated with FaceCode and you can use FaceCode interviews.
Configure a job on workflow
Open a created job in your workable profile. Click Edit job.
Click the Workflow tab. You will see different pipelines. Click the Interview tab and select HackerEarth FaceCode.
Click Save changes.
Your interview is now linked with FaceCode interviews and you can use FaceCode interviews for the interview pipeline.
Send Interview invite to candidate
Move the candidate to the interview stage.
In the interview tab, click on the option to invite the candidate for a video interview with HE.
Click Send Video Interview
Reload the page once. A new comment will be visible under Candidate Profile containing the interview URL with further instructions.
Note: The user will have to copy the interview URL and send an invitation mail to the candidate with the interviewers in cc. Remember, only 5 interviewers should be added in cc else the rest will get discarded. You can also schedule an interview with the interview URL in google calendar.
markdown:
# Workable FaceCode integration

Workable has now integrated with FaceCode interviews and you can enable the interviews by following the given steps:

## Enable FaceCode from Workable

1.  Login to your workable profile and go to settings -> integrations (_https://{company-name}.workable.com/backend/settings/integrations_)
    

![1.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/1-1.jpg)

2.  In the Integrations section under **Video Interview Providers**, click on **HackerEarth FaceCode** tab and **paste the API key** there and click update settings.
    

![2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/2-Jan-30-2023-11-32-23-3289-AM.png)

3.  **Generate Access Token** in the Workable integrations page and copy the token. Even copy the **workable domain**, which is in the form \*.workable.com
    

![3.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/3-1.jpg)

4.  Open the HackerEarth integrations page and paste both the values (Access Token, Workable Domain) in the relevant fields, and click **Save**.
    

![4.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/4-1.jpg)

Your Workable is now integrated with FaceCode and you can use FaceCode interviews.

## Configure a job on workflow

1.  Open a created job in your workable profile. Click **Edit job**.
    

![5.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/5-1.jpg)

2.  Click the **Workflow** tab. You will see different pipelines. Click the Interview tab and select **HackerEarth FaceCode.**
    

![6.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/6-1.jpg)

3.  Click **Save changes.**
    

Your interview is now linked with FaceCode interviews and you can use FaceCode interviews for the interview pipeline.

## Send Interview invite to candidate

1.  Move the candidate to the interview stage.
    
2.  In the interview tab, click on the option to invite the candidate for a video interview with HE.
    

![7.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/7-1.jpg)

3.  Click **Send Video Interview**
    

![8.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/8-1.jpg)

4.  Reload the page once. A new comment will be visible under **Candidate Profile** containing the interview URL with further instructions.
    

![9.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/9-2.jpg)

**Note:** The user will have to copy the interview URL and send an invitation mail to the candidate with the interviewers in cc. Remember, only 5 interviewers should be added in cc else the rest will get discarded. You can also schedule an interview with the interview URL in google calendar.

text:
Jobvite: Overview
HackerEarth Assessment is integrated with a new ATS—Jobvite. This integration allows you to screen candidates efficiently and streamline the technical recruitment workflow. You can perform the following tasks on Jobvite:
Post job requirements on the platform
Set up multiple tests on HackerEarth Assessments
Invite candidates to tests
Generate detailed candidate reports and share the reports with your team members
Key features 
The key features of Jobvite are as follows:
Create any type of job requisition to fit your needs: You can create and add any types of job requisitions or job requirements to fit your business needs by tailoring attributes such as posting type, location, custom workflow, and more. You can also edit a requisition that you have created.
Create FaceCode interview meetings and send the link to candidates: You can easily create FaceCode meeting links and directly send the interview link to the candidates for the assessment.
Track job openings and prospective candidates: After you create a requisition, Jobvite automatically posts your job openings on the web. It allows you to get the updates of the added job positions and you can also track the candidates who apply for these positions.
Screen prospects quickly: It organizes all your lead generation and sourcing results in one place. Additionally, the screening and ranking tools in Jobvite help you to identify suitable candidates.
Map multiple HackerEarth tests to job requisition: You can create and add multiple tests and invite candidates to fill a job position. There is no limitation on the number of candidates that you can assess at a time. All these tasks can be done directly from Jobvite’s interface.
View detailed candidate reports in the workflow setup: You can view their scores and other performance data in their Jobvite profile. This feature makes the selection process effective and less time-consuming. Additionally, if a candidate is shortlisted or rejected, then his or her status is updated automatically in both Jobvite and HackerEarth platforms.
Integrating Jobvite with HackerEarth 
To integrate Jobvite with HackerEarth Assessment and use its features, follow these steps:
Generate the Jobvite Webhook key for your organization. 
Adding job requirements and tests.
markdown:
# Jobvite: Overview

HackerEarth Assessment is integrated with a new ATS—Jobvite. This integration allows you to screen candidates efficiently and streamline the technical recruitment workflow. You can perform the following tasks on Jobvite:

*   Post job requirements on the platform
*   Set up multiple tests on HackerEarth Assessments
*   Invite candidates to tests
*   Generate detailed candidate reports and share the reports with your team members

Key features

The key features of Jobvite are as follows:

*   **Create any type of job requisition to fit your needs**: You can create and add any types of job requisitions or job requirements to fit your business needs by tailoring attributes such as posting type, location, custom workflow, and more. You can also edit a requisition that you have created.
*   **Create FaceCode interview meetings and send the link to candidates**: You can easily create FaceCode meeting links and directly send the interview link to the candidates for the assessment.
*   **Track job openings and prospective candidates**: After you create a requisition, Jobvite automatically posts your job openings on the web. It allows you to get the updates of the added job positions and you can also track the candidates who apply for these positions.
*   **Screen prospects quickly**: It organizes all your lead generation and sourcing results in one place. Additionally, the screening and ranking tools in Jobvite help you to identify suitable candidates.
*   **Map multiple HackerEarth tests to job requisition**: You can create and add multiple tests and invite candidates to fill a job position. There is no limitation on the number of candidates that you can assess at a time. All these tasks can be done directly from Jobvite’s interface.
*   **View detailed candidate reports in the workflow setup**: You can view their scores and other performance data in their Jobvite profile. This feature makes the selection process effective and less time-consuming. Additionally, if a candidate is shortlisted or rejected, then his or her status is updated automatically in both Jobvite and HackerEarth platforms.

Integrating Jobvite with HackerEarth

To integrate Jobvite with HackerEarth Assessment and use its features, follow these steps:

1.  [Generate the Jobvite Webhook key for your organization](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/900000614246-generating-the-jobvite-webhook-key-for-your-organization). 
2.  [Adding job requirements and tests](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/10006787976089-creating-jobs-and-inviting-candidates).

text:
Install HackerEarth App
1. Go to EightFold’s AppMarketplace.
2. Search for HackerEarth and open the tab.
3. Click install. It will install the app.
4. You will be able to see a form. Fill in the following details:
API Key
System ID which can be found in Admin Console -> Integrations -> Integrations System (https://app.eightfold.ai/integrations/ats)
Stage as “Phone Interview” for Assessments and “Onsite Interview” for FaceCode
Fetch report delay is not needed
5. Select Admin Console -> Integration -> Eightfold API and copy the Auth Basic
6. The auth token would be of the format “Basic abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz”. Copy only the part that is in bold.
7. Go to HackerEarth’s integration page and paste the auth token in the Access Token field and click Save.
markdown:
# Install HackerEarth App

1\. Go to [EightFold’s AppMarketplace](https://app.eightfold.ai/app_marketplace/).

2\. Search for HackerEarth and open the tab.

![3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/3-Jan-30-2023-11-28-17-2618-AM.png)

3\. Click install. It will install the app.

![4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/4-Jan-30-2023-11-28-15-8061-AM.png)

4\. You will be able to see a form. Fill in the following details:

*   *   *   API Key
            
        *   System ID which can be found in Admin Console -> Integrations -> Integrations System ([**https://app.eightfold.ai/integrations/ats**](https://app.eightfold.ai/integrations/ats)**)**
            

![5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/5-Jan-30-2023-11-28-20-8688-AM.png)

*   Stage as “Phone Interview” for Assessments and “Onsite Interview” for FaceCode
    
*   Fetch report delay is not needed
    

![6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/6-Jan-30-2023-11-28-14-0533-AM.png)

5\. Select Admin Console -> Integration -> Eightfold API and copy the Auth Basic

6\. The auth token would be of the format “Basic **abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz**”. Copy only the part that is in bold.

![9.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/9-4.png)

7\. Go to HackerEarth’s integration page and paste the auth token in the Access Token field and click **Save**.

![10.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/10-3.png)

text:
Initial workflow setup
You can do the initial workflow setup on Jobvite portal by the following steps:
1. Go to the Jobvite portal
2. Click the Profile icon and then click Admin.
3. Click on ATS -> View Workflows and edit General workflow.
4. Now add the following custom stages:
Send First HE Test
First HE Test Sent
First HE Test Completed
Shortlisted from First HE Test
Send Second HE Test
Second HE Test Sent
Second HE Test Completed
Shortlisted from Second HE Test
Send Third HE Test
Third HE Test Sent
Third HE Test Completed
Shortlisted from Third HE Test
Send Fourth HE Test
Fourth HE Test Sent
Fourth HE Test Completed
Shortlisted from Fourth HE Test
Send Fifth HE Test
Fifth HE Test Sent
Fifth HE Test Completed
Shortlisted from Fifth HE Test
HE Action Error
5. If the user wants to Integrate Facecode too, then they will have to add a few more custom stages:
Send First HE Interview
First HE Interview Sent
First HE Interview Completed
Send Second HE Interview
Second HE Interview Sent
Second HE Interview Completed
Send Third HE Interview
Third HE Interview Sent
Third HE Interview Completed
Send Fourth HE Interview
Fourth HE Interview Sent
Fourth HE Interview Completed
Send Fifth HE Interview
Fifth HE Interview Sent
Fifth HE Interview Completed
6. Now click on Configurations -> View Custom Fields.
7. Under Requisition add these 5 custom fields:
First HE Test ID
Second HE Test ID
Third HE Test ID
Fourth HE Test ID
Fifth HE Test ID
Note: While creating these fields, select Type as Text
8. Now under Candidates add these 5 custom fields:
First HE Test Result
Second HE Test Result
Third HE Test Result
Fourth HE Test Result
Fifth HE Test Result
Note: While creating these fields, select Type as Multi-line Text.
9. If the user wants to Integrate Facecode too, then they will have to add a few more custom fields:
First HE Interview Link
First HE Interview Result
Second HE Interview Link
Second HE Interview Result
Third HE Interview Link
Third HE Interview Result
Fourth HE Interview Link
Fourth HE Interview Result
Fifth HE Interview Link
Fifth HE Interview Result
Note: While creating these fields, select Type as Multi-line Text.

text:
Creating jobs and inviting candidates
You can create jobs in the jobvite portal by following these steps:
1. Go to Requisitions, and click Add Requisition.
2. Fill in the relevant job details for creating the job
3. Now, users have the option to link 5 HackerEarth assessments to a single job, which will be the First HE Test, Second HE Test till Fifth HE Test.
4. Now, users can go to the HackerEarth portal and copy the Recruiter API ID for the assessments they want to assign to the job(to know more about the Recruiter API ID, click here) and paste them for the respective fields in the job.
5. Save and publish the job.
Inviting Candidates
1. Create a candidate and assign him/her to the job.
2. Click Workflow Step and move the candidate to either Send First HE Test, Send Second HE Test, Send Third HE Test, Send Fourth HE Test, or Send Fifth HE Test.
3. Post this an invite mail will get triggered to the candidate automatically for that specific HE test.
4. The workflow status will be changed to either First HE Test Sent, Second HE Test Sent, Third HE Test Sent, Fourth HE Test Sent, or Fifth HE Test Sent based on the stage in which he/she was previously.
5. Once they complete the test, the workflow status would change to either, First HE Test Completed, Second HE Test Completed, Third HE Test Completed, Fourth HE Test Completed, or Fifth HE Test Completed, again based on the previous state.
6. Once the candidates are reviewed and shortlisted from the HackerEarth portal, the workflow status would change to Shortlisted from First HE Test, Shortlisted from Second HE Test, Shortlisted from Third HE Test, Shortlisted from Fourth HE Test, Shortlisted from Fifth HE Test respectively.
7. Once the candidates submit the assessment, their reports will be pushed to the candidate dashboard, under the Application Details section.
Note: Once the candidate’s workflow status is changed to Send First HE Test, Send Second HE Test, Send Third HE Test, Send Fourth HE Test, or Send Fifth HE Test, the invitation mail won’t be sent simultaneously, there might be a maximum delay of 30 minutes.
markdown:
# Creating jobs and inviting candidates

You can create jobs in the jobvite portal by following these steps:

1\. Go to Requisitions, and click Add Requisition.

2\. Fill in the relevant job details for creating the job

3\. Now, users have the option to link 5 HackerEarth assessments to a single job, which will be the First HE Test, Second HE Test till Fifth HE Test.

4\. Now, users can go to the HackerEarth portal and copy the Recruiter API ID for the assessments they want to assign to the job(to know more about the Recruiter API ID, click [here](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/900000073863-Test-overview)) and paste them for the respective fields in the job.

![8.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/8-Jan-30-2023-11-43-44-5005-AM.png)

5\. Save and publish the job.

**Inviting Candidates**

1\. Create a candidate and assign him/her to the job.

2\. Click Workflow Step and move the candidate to either Send First HE Test, Send Second HE Test, Send Third HE Test, Send Fourth HE Test, or Send Fifth HE Test.

3\. Post this an invite mail will get triggered to the candidate automatically for that specific HE test.

4\. The workflow status will be changed to either First HE Test Sent, Second HE Test Sent, Third HE Test Sent, Fourth HE Test Sent, or Fifth HE Test Sent based on the stage in which he/she was previously.

5\. Once they complete the test, the workflow status would change to either, First HE Test Completed, Second HE Test Completed, Third HE Test Completed, Fourth HE Test Completed, or Fifth HE Test Completed, again based on the previous state.

6\. Once the candidates are reviewed and shortlisted from the HackerEarth portal, the workflow status would change to Shortlisted from First HE Test, Shortlisted from Second HE Test, Shortlisted from Third HE Test, Shortlisted from Fourth HE Test, Shortlisted from Fifth HE Test respectively.

7\. Once the candidates submit the assessment, their reports will be pushed to the candidate dashboard, under the Application Details section.

![9.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/9-Jan-30-2023-11-43-45-9990-AM.png)

**Note:** Once the candidate’s workflow status is changed to Send First HE Test, Send Second HE Test, Send Third HE Test, Send Fourth HE Test, or Send Fifth HE Test, the invitation mail won’t be sent simultaneously, there might be a maximum delay of 30 minutes.

text:
SAP SuccessFactors: Overview
HackerEarth Assessment is integrated with a new ATS—SuccessFactors. This integration allows you to screen candidates efficiently and streamline the technical recruitment workflow. You can perform the following tasks on SuccessFactors:
Post job requirements on the SuccessFactors platform
List the HE tests that you have created at the SuccessFactors dashboard and associate them with various jobs
Send invites to the specific candidates directly from the SuccessFactors dashboard as soon as the candidates qualify for the Assessments stage
View the candidate report on the SuccessFactors dashboard after the candidate successfully completes the test at HackerEarth Assessment
Get a public link to view the candidate reports at HackerEarth Assessment
To integrate SuccessFactors with HackerEarth Assessment, follow these steps:
Generate the SuccessFactors API key for your organization
Set up assessments on the SuccessFactors platform
markdown:
# SAP SuccessFactors: Overview

HackerEarth Assessment is integrated with a new ATS—SuccessFactors. This integration allows you to screen candidates efficiently and streamline the technical recruitment workflow. You can perform the following tasks on SuccessFactors:

*   Post job requirements on the SuccessFactors platform
*   List the HE tests that you have created at the SuccessFactors dashboard and associate them with various jobs
*   Send invites to the specific candidates directly from the SuccessFactors dashboard as soon as the candidates qualify for the Assessments stage
*   View the candidate report on the SuccessFactors dashboard after the candidate successfully completes the test at HackerEarth Assessment
*   Get a public link to view the candidate reports at HackerEarth Assessment

To integrate SuccessFactors with HackerEarth Assessment, follow these steps:

1.  [Generate the SuccessFactors API key for your organization](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360038377013-generating-the-successfactors-api-key-for-your-organization)
2.  [Set up assessments on the SuccessFactors platform](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360037881394)

text:
Generating the SuccessFactors API key for your organization
To generate your SuccessFactors API key for your organization, follow these steps:
At HackerEarth's side
Log in to your HackerEarth Assessments account by using admin credentials.
Click .
In the Personal section, click Integrations.
In the SAP SuccessFactors section, click Generate API Key.
You have successfully generated your SuccessFactors API key.
Important: You cannot generate the API key twice. An organization can have only one SuccessFactors API key.
At SuccessFactors’ side
1. Share the username, companyId, password, and API server domain of your SF account with HackerEarth’s team.
2. Add and activate external vendor in SF. The externalPartnercode: HACKEREARTH
3. Generate Vendor packages CSV file for your packages in the given format.
4. This can be obtained from HackerEarth. Just share the CSV format, import this CSV in SF recruiting management
Link to KBA: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2081528
5. Create an External Event Connector that notifies HackerEarth when a candidate’s stage changes. Do the following:
Add HackerEarth’s endpoint URL: https://api.hackerearth.com/partner/successfactors/invite/
Setup the Basic authentication with the API keys (Username and Password)
markdown:
# Generating the SuccessFactors API key for your organization

To generate your SuccessFactors API key for your organization, follow these steps:

### At HackerEarth's side

1.  Log in to your HackerEarth Assessments account by using admin credentials.
2.  Click ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-33-16-3114-AM.png).
3.  In the **Personal** section, click **Integrations**.
4.  In the **SAP SuccessFactors** section, click **Generate API Key**.  
    ![mceclip0.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-33-12-5589-AM.png)

You have successfully generated your SuccessFactors API key.

_Important_: You cannot generate the API key twice. An organization can have only one SuccessFactors API key.  
![mceclip1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip1-Jan-30-2023-11-33-17-4491-AM.png)

### At SuccessFactors’ side

1\. Share the username, companyId, password, and API server domain of your SF account with HackerEarth’s team.

2\. Add and activate external vendor in SF. The externalPartnercode: **HACKEREARTH**

![SF1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/SF1-1.png)

3\. Generate Vendor packages CSV file for your packages in the given format.

![SF2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/SF2-1.png)

4\. This can be obtained from HackerEarth. Just share the CSV format, import this CSV in SF recruiting management  
Link to KBA: [https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2081528](https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2081528)

![SF3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/SF3-1.png)

5\. Create an External Event Connector that notifies HackerEarth when a candidate’s stage changes. Do the following:

*   *   Add HackerEarth’s endpoint URL: https://api.hackerearth.com/partner/successfactors/invite/
    *   Setup the Basic authentication with the API keys (Username and Password)

![Screenshot_from_2021-07-23_09-36-48.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Screenshot_from_2021-07-23_09-36-48-1.png)

# Jobvite FaceCode integration

You can now send the FaceCode interview link directly from the Jobvite dashboard. You need to have **FaceCode Interview Integration** enabled in your Integrations setting under the Jobvite section.

To learn more about Jobvite FaceCode integration, refer to [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/10006361393689-Initial-workflow-setup).

text:
Sending invites and view reports
Once the assessment is initiated, HackerEarth will not send the invitation link to the candidate but it will update the link to SuccessFactors and then SF will send the invite to the candidate.
You will be able to see the initiation date and the assessment name which has been initiated, once the invitation link has been sent.
Once the assessment is complete, you will be able to see the report along with the date of completion of the test.
markdown:
# Sending invites and view reports

Once the assessment is initiated, HackerEarth will not send the invitation link to the candidate but it will update the link to SuccessFactors and then SF will send the invite to the candidate.

![Veritas11.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Veritas11-1.png)

Once the assessment is complete, you will be able to see the report along with the date of completion of the test.

![Veritas22.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/Veritas22-1.png)

Greenhouse: Overview
Use HackerEarth Recruit along with your Greenhouse account to assess and evaluate candidates. 
For successful integration, follow these steps:
Generate your Greenhouse API key.
Enable and implement the Greenhouse-HackerEarth Recruit integration.
Add and configure the HackerEarth interview stage to your Greenhouse interview plan. 
Send the test invites to candidates and review test results.
markdown:
# Greenhouse: Overview

Use HackerEarth Recruit along with your Greenhouse account to assess and evaluate candidates. 

For successful integration, follow these steps:

1.  [Generate your Greenhouse API key](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004525113-generating-your-greenhouse-api-key).
2.  [Enable and implement the Greenhouse-HackerEarth Recruit integration](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004526673-enabling-and-implementing-greenhouse-hackerearth-integration).
3.  [Add and configure the HackerEarth interview stage to your Greenhouse interview plan](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004508414-adding-and-configuring-hackerearth-as-an-interview-stage-to-greenhouse). 
4.  [Send the test invites to candidates and review test results](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004540733-sending-test-invites-and-reviewing-test-results).

text:
Enabling and implementing Greenhouse-HackerEarth integration
To enable the integration, follow these steps:
Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using admin credentials.
Generate your Greenhouse API key.
Send the API key to your Greenhouse Account Manager.
The Manager will enter the API key into your Greenhouse account.
You will receive a confirmation mail when the integration is enabled.
Implementing the Greenhouse-HackerEarth integration
To implement the integration, follow these steps:
Send your request to implement the integration to support@greenhouse.io.
Important: Do not send the API key in this email.
You will receive a SendSafely link from the Greenhouse Support Team. Enter the generated API key into the link that notifies the Greenhouse Support Team once the API key is entered.
You will receive a confirmation mail from the Greenhouse Support Team about the successful setup of the API key in your account and integration.
Add HackerEarth as a stage to your interview pipeline in your Greenhouse account.
When candidates enter that stage, send invites through Greenhouse.
Once candidates submit their test, a link to the results is accessible through the interview kit in Greenhouse.
You have successfully implemented the integration.
markdown:
# Enabling and implementing Greenhouse-HackerEarth integration

To enable the integration, follow these steps:

1.  Log into your HackerEarth Recruit account using admin credentials.
2.  [Generate your Greenhouse API key](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004525113-generating-your-greenhouse-api-key).
3.  Send the API key to your Greenhouse Account Manager.
4.  The Manager will enter the API key into your Greenhouse account.

You will receive a confirmation mail when the integration is enabled.

**Implementing the Greenhouse-HackerEarth integration**

To implement the integration, follow these steps:

1.  Send your request to implement the integration to [support@greenhouse.io](mailto:support@greenhouse.io).
    
    _Important_: Do not send the API key in this email.
    
2.  You will receive a SendSafely link from the Greenhouse Support Team. Enter the generated API key into the link that notifies the Greenhouse Support Team once the API key is entered.
3.  You will receive a confirmation mail from the Greenhouse Support Team about the successful setup of the API key in your account and integration.
4.  [Add HackerEarth as a stage](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004508414-adding-and-configuring-hackerearth-as-an-interview-stage-to-greenhouse) to your interview pipeline in your Greenhouse account.
5.  When candidates enter that stage, send invites through Greenhouse.
6.  Once candidates submit their test, a link to the results is accessible through the interview kit in Greenhouse.

You have successfully implemented the integration.

text:
Adding and configuring HackerEarth as an interview stage to Greenhouse
To add HackerEarth as a stage to your interview plan:
Log into your Greenhouse account.
Navigate to a specific job, and click Job Setup.
Click Interview Plan.
Scroll down the page, and click Add Stage.
Click HackerEarth.
Click Add.
You have successfully added HackerEarth as an interview stage.
Configuring the stage
To configure the stage, follow these steps:
Once the stage has been added, click Edit Take Home Test.
A drop-down menu is displayed that reflects the assessment that you have previously set up in HackerEarth.
Select the appropriate assessment and assign at least one Greenhouse user to grade or review the assessment.
Click Save.
You have successfully configured the stage.
Important: The configuration of assessment, email templates, and interview instructions is done by HackerEarth.
markdown:
# Adding and configuring HackerEarth as an interview stage to Greenhouse

To add HackerEarth as a stage to your interview plan:

1.  Log into your Greenhouse account.
2.  Navigate to a specific job, and click **Job Setup**.
3.  Click **Interview Plan**.
4.  Scroll down the page, and click **Add Stage**.
5.  Click **HackerEarth**.
6.  Click **Add**.  
    ![](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/mceclip0-Jan-30-2023-11-35-35-2626-AM.png)

You have successfully added HackerEarth as an interview stage.

## **Configuring the stage**

To configure the stage, follow these steps:

1.  Once the stage has been added, click **Edit Take Home Test**.
2.  A drop-down menu is displayed that reflects the assessment that you have previously set up in HackerEarth.
3.  Select the appropriate assessment and assign at least one Greenhouse user to grade or review the assessment.
4.  Click **Save**.

You have successfully configured the stage.

_Important_: The configuration of assessment, email templates, and interview instructions is done by HackerEarth.

text:
Inviting candidates
Open the candidate profile.
Click Advance Stage and select Phone Interview.
A pop-up screen will appear, with the list of tests from which you have to select a test for the candidate.
Once the test is selected, an invite with the test link will be sent to the candidate email and to the candidate dashboard as well.
When the candidate finishes the test, the report will be displayed on the candidate's dashboard.
This is how you can easily invite the candidates with EightFold.
markdown:
# Inviting candidates

1.  Open the candidate profile.
    

![9.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/9-3.jpg)

2.  Click **Advance Stage** and select **Phone Interview.**
    
3.  A pop-up screen will appear, with the list of tests from which you have to select a test for the candidate.  
    ![10.jpg](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/10-1.jpg)
    
4.  Once the test is selected, an invite with the test link will be sent to the candidate email and to the candidate dashboard as well.  
    ![11.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/11-Jan-30-2023-11-47-53-1205-AM.png)
    
5.  When the candidate finishes the test, the report will be displayed on the candidate's dashboard.
    

![12.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/12-3.png)

This is how you can easily invite the candidates with EightFold.

text:
Greenhouse FaceCode integration
You can now send FaceCode interview link directly from the Greenhouse dashboard. You need to have FaceCode Interview Integration enabled in your Integrations setting under Greenhouse section.
Implementing the Greenhouse FaceCode integration
To implement the integration, follow these steps:
Send your request to implement the integration at support@greenhouse.io.

Important: Do not send the API key in this email. 
You will receive a SendSafely link from the Greenhouse Support Team. Enter the generated API key into the link that notifies the Greenhouse Support Team once the API key is entered.
You will receive a confirmation mail from the Greenhouse Support Team about the successful setup of the API key in your account and integration.
Add HackerEarth FaceCode Interview as a stage to your interview pipeline in your Greenhouse account. 
When candidates enter that stage, send invites through Greenhouse.
Once candidates submit their test, a link to the results is accessible through the interview kit in Greenhouse.
You have successfully implemented the integration.
Send interview invites to the candidates
To send test invites, follow these steps:
Log into your Greenhouse account.
Navigate to a candidate's profile.
Click Send Test.
You will be asked to enter the candidate’s email and the details along with the name of the person you want the test to be graded by. The interview email will be sent to the admin who has integrated with HackerEarth and not to the people you have selected. Click Send test. 
You have successfully sent the test invites.
You can also access the interview result report from the Greenhouse dashboard.
You can check if the test has been graded by the interviewer on the dashboard.
Once the test has been graded, you will be able to see the interview report in the dashboard.
This is how you can easily send the interview invites and view the candidate report on the Greenhouse dashboard.
markdown:
# Greenhouse FaceCode integration

You can now send FaceCode interview link directly from the Greenhouse dashboard. You need to have FaceCode Interview Integration enabled in your Integrations setting under Greenhouse section.

![GH1.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH1-1.png)

## **Implementing the Greenhouse FaceCode integration**

To implement the integration, follow these steps:

1.  Send your request to implement the integration at support@greenhouse.io.  
      
    _Important_: Do not send the API key in this email.
2.  You will receive a SendSafely link from the Greenhouse Support Team. Enter the generated API key into the link that notifies the Greenhouse Support Team once the API key is entered.
3.  You will receive a confirmation mail from the Greenhouse Support Team about the successful setup of the API key in your account and integration.
4.  Add **HackerEarth FaceCode Interview** as a stage to your interview pipeline in your Greenhouse account.![GH2.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH2-1.png)
5.  When candidates enter that stage, send invites through Greenhouse.
6.  Once candidates submit their test, a link to the results is accessible through the interview kit in Greenhouse.

You have successfully implemented the integration.

## **Send interview invites to the candidates**

## To send test invites, follow these steps:

1.  Log into your Greenhouse account.
2.  Navigate to a candidate's profile.
3.  Click **Send Test**.![GH3.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH3-1.png)  
    
4.  You will be asked to enter the candidate’s email and the details along with the name of the person you want the test to be graded by. The interview email will be sent to the admin who has integrated with HackerEarth and not to the people you have selected. Click **Send test**. ![GH4.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH4-1.png) 

You have successfully sent the test invites.

You can also access the interview result report from the Greenhouse dashboard.

1.  You can check if the test has been graded by the interviewer on the dashboard.![GH5.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH5-1.png)

1.  Once the test has been graded, you will be able to see the interview report in the dashboard.![GH6.png](https://help.hackerearth.com/hubfs/Knowledge%20Base%20Import/GH6-1.png)

This is how you can easily send the interview invites and view the candidate report on the Greenhouse dashboard.

text:
Release notes: September 7, 2021
Single interview link is now available to all the customers with new features 
We have introduced single interview link for all the customers now. To learn more about single interview link, refer to this article.
Calendar integration is available for all the customers
You can now integrate your interviews with the Calendar.
Import questions from the candidate’s assessment to the Facecode interview
You can now directly import questions from the candidate's assessment to the FaceCode interview.
Enhanced proctoring settings in Facecode

markdown:
# Release notes: September 7, 2021

*   **Single interview link is now available to all the customers with new features**

We have introduced single interview link for all the customers now. To learn more about single interview link, refer to [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006812634-Scheduling-a-new-interview).

*   **Calendar integration is available for all the customers**

You can now integrate your interviews with the Calendar.

*   **Import questions from the candidate’s assessment to the Facecode interview**

You can now directly import questions from the candidate's assessment to the FaceCode interview.

*   **Enhanced proctoring settings in Facecode**

The proctoring settings have been enhanced now. You can easily see if the candidate has navigated away from the window or is in the current interview tab.

*   **Quick access to plagiarism reports**

Plagiarism reports can now be quickly accessed as soon as the candidate finishes the assessment.

*   **Add tets cases directly into a problem** 

You can now manually add test cases to the programming questions through a text box.

*   **Search feature is now enabled in the HackerEarth library**

We have enabled an advanced search feature to help you navigate to the right question while creating a test.

text:
Release notes: May 7, 2024
The latest features update released in the month of May.
New candidate’s interface (Programming questions)
We have made several major changes in the candidate’s interface of the programming questions, which are as follows:
The results are now visible separately and appear upon code submission, eliminating the need to scroll to view them.
Visible and custom test cases have been moved and are accessible via a toggle to avoid back-and-forth scrolling between the problem statement and test cases. 
The submission result layout is redesigned for better clarity. 
To learn more about the candidate interface of programming questions, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: May 7, 2024

## The latest features update released in the month of May.

### New candidate’s interface (Programming questions)

We have made several major changes in the candidate’s interface of the programming questions, which are as follows:

*   The results are now visible separately and appear upon code submission, eliminating the need to scroll to view them.
*   Visible and custom test cases have been moved and are accessible via a toggle to avoid back-and-forth scrolling between the problem statement and test cases. 
*   The submission result layout is redesigned for better clarity. 

To learn more about the candidate interface of programming questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002656314-programming-problems).

text:
Release notes: April 7, 2024
New product features released in the month of April.
New candidate invite flow
HackerEarth has introduced a new candidate invite flow for assessments, which enhances the assessment experience. The new flow has fixed several bugs, and you will also be provided with a date picker to select the assessment's expiration date. This makes it easier to invite the candidate for an assessment. 
New candidate’s interface (Programming questions)
We have made several major changes in the candidate’s interface of the programming questions, which are as follows:
The results are now visible separately and appear upon code submission, eliminating the need to scroll to view them.
Visible and custom test cases have been moved and are accessible via a toggle to avoid back-and-forth scrolling between the problem statement and test cases. 
The submission result layout is redesigned for better clarity. 
To learn more about the candidate interface of programming questions, read this article. 
Visual Studio code interface in Full stack questions 
We have introduced the Visual Studio code interface in Fullstack IDE. This provides a better experience to the candidates as they mostly use VS code in their local machines as IDE. We also support Preview within the IDE, which enhances a candidate’s experience. For now, it is available for the following frameworks:
Flask
Django
Angular
NodeJS
React
FaceCode video blur
HackerEarth has introduced a new background option in the FaceCode interview, which allows you to blur your background while interviewing a candidate. You have three blur intensities that can be applied, which are as follows:
None: Applies no effect to the background of the video
Partial: Applies partial blur effect to the background of the video
Full: Applies complete blur effect to the background of the video
To learn more about the blur background feature, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: April 7, 2024

## New product features released in the month of April.

### New candidate invite flow

HackerEarth has introduced a new candidate invite flow for assessments, which enhances the assessment experience. The new flow has fixed several bugs, and you will also be provided with a date picker to select the assessment's expiration date. This makes it easier to invite the candidate for an assessment. 

### New candidate’s interface (Programming questions)

We have made several major changes in the candidate’s interface of the programming questions, which are as follows:

*   The results are now visible separately and appear upon code submission, eliminating the need to scroll to view them.
*   Visible and custom test cases have been moved and are accessible via a toggle to avoid back-and-forth scrolling between the problem statement and test cases. 
*   The submission result layout is redesigned for better clarity. 

To learn more about the candidate interface of programming questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002656314-programming-problems). 

### Visual Studio code interface in Full stack questions 

We have introduced the Visual Studio code interface in Fullstack IDE. This provides a better experience to the candidates as they mostly use VS code in their local machines as IDE. We also support Preview within the IDE, which enhances a candidate’s experience. For now, it is available for the following frameworks:

*   Flask
*   Django
*   Angular
*   NodeJS
*   React

### FaceCode video blur

HackerEarth has introduced a new background option in the FaceCode interview, which allows you to blur your background while interviewing a candidate. You have three blur intensities that can be applied, which are as follows:

1.  None: Applies no effect to the background of the video
2.  Partial: Applies partial blur effect to the background of the video
3.  Full: Applies complete blur effect to the background of the video

To learn more about the blur background feature, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/background-option-video-blur).

text:
Release notes: March 7, 2024
New product features released in the month of March. 
Candidate looking away 
HackerEarth has upgraded its snapshot proctroing features and introduced a new category in proctoring violation called candidate looking away. This will categorize different snapshots into different categories and allow you to see all kinds of violations a candidate can commit. It can detect the following violations:
Using secondary laptops to use Google/ChatGPT
Using mobiles below their desk to use Google/ChatGPT
Using a dual monitor setup to cheat
Looking at someone behind/on the side of the laptop for assistance
Leaning partially outside the webcam's view to use an external device
Integrity index
HackerEarth has introduced integrity index, a metric calculated from the number and severity of proctoring violations made by the candidate while taking the assessment. Proctoring violations detected by our system, such as tab switches, snapshot violations, and plagiarism, lower a candidate's integrity index, facilitating quicker decision-making by summarizing all the proctoring violations into a single index. To learn more about this, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: March 7, 2024

## New product features released in the month of March.

### Candidate looking away 

HackerEarth has upgraded its snapshot proctroing features and introduced a new category in proctoring violation called candidate looking away. This will categorize different snapshots into different categories and allow you to see all kinds of violations a candidate can commit. It can detect the following violations:

*   Using secondary laptops to use Google/ChatGPT
*   Using mobiles below their desk to use Google/ChatGPT
*   Using a dual monitor setup to cheat
*   Looking at someone behind/on the side of the laptop for assistance
*   Leaning partially outside the webcam's view to use an external device

### Integrity index

HackerEarth has introduced integrity index, a metric calculated from the number and severity of proctoring violations made by the candidate while taking the assessment. Proctoring violations detected by our system, such as tab switches, snapshot violations, and plagiarism, lower a candidate's integrity index, facilitating quicker decision-making by summarizing all the proctoring violations into a single index. To learn more about this, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/integrity-index).

text:
Release notes: February 7, 2024
New product features released in the month of February. 
Where is the candidate (FaceCode)
HackerEarth has introduced a new feature on FaceCode where we have introduced the feature of following the candidate, which allows you to follow the candidate’s activities while they are in the interview. This feature allows interviewers to automatically switch tabs and languages based on the candidate's actions. To learn more about this feature, read this article.
New DevOps questions in HackerEarth’s library
HackerEarth has added new DevOps questions in HackerEarth’s library, including questions about cloud services such as AWS, GCP, Azure, Terraform, etc. You can use these questions as a reference to create your own questions, and if you want to see more questions like these in the library, contact your Customer Success Manager.
markdown:
# Release notes: February 7, 2024

## New product features released in the month of February.

### Where is the candidate (FaceCode)

HackerEarth has introduced a new feature on FaceCode where we have introduced the feature of following the candidate, which allows you to follow the candidate’s activities while they are in the interview. This feature allows interviewers to automatically switch tabs and languages based on the candidate's actions. To learn more about this feature, read this [article](https://help.hackerearth.com/where-is-the-candidate).

### New DevOps questions in HackerEarth’s library

HackerEarth has added new DevOps questions in HackerEarth’s library, including questions about cloud services such as AWS, GCP, Azure, Terraform, etc. You can use these questions as a reference to create your own questions, and if you want to see more questions like these in the library, contact your Customer Success Manager.

Release notes: June 7, 2021
Babel support for front end questions

Submission retry and improved failure handling

markdown:
# Release notes: June 7, 2021

*   **Babel support for front end questions**

Babel is now supported in the editor for front end problems. This means that the candidates can now use popular front end frameworks such as Reach and Vue while attempting the questions. For more information on front end questions, read [this](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005832033-Creating-Front-end-questions).

*   **Bulk move questions to sections**

You can now bulk move questions to different sections.

*   **Submission retry and improved failure handling**

We have now improved submission retry flow and submission failure handling.

*   **Limit on MCQ questions in auto-generated tests**

We have now applied a limit on the MCQ questions in auto-generated test. To know more about MCQ questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002710473-Multiple-choice-questions-MCQs-).

*   **DS submission optimization**

The DS submission has now been optimized.

*    **Filter to see My interviews/All interviews**

We have added a small radio button filter to search for My interviews/All interviews. When my interviews option is selected, you can see all the interviews created by you or where you are the interviewer.

text:
Release notes: January 7, 2024
ID verification for Assessments
HackerEarth has added ID verification to the proctoring settings of assessments. When enabled, candidates are required to upload a valid photo ID before proceeding. The system verifies this ID by comparing it with a photo of the candidate. Any discrepancies are highlighted in the report. ID verification can be activated for any assessment in proctoring settings, and it's turned off by default. To learn more about proctoring settings, read this article.
Code quality in full stack questions
HackerEarth has introduced code quality in full stack questions for the React framework. The metrics generated are - Reliability, Security, and Maintainability. The code quality of an FS question will be available in the submission details section. To learn more about code quality in full-stack questions, read this article. 
Lock/unlock questions (FaceCode)
HackerEarth has added a new capability to FaceCode interviews, allowing administrators to lock and unlock questions. This feature enables admins to restrict candidates from modifying their solutions to interview questions by locking the code editor. You can unlock questions at a later stage. To learn more, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: January 7, 2024

#### ID verification for Assessments

HackerEarth has added ID verification to the proctoring settings of assessments. When enabled, candidates are required to upload a valid photo ID before proceeding. The system verifies this ID by comparing it with a photo of the candidate. Any discrepancies are highlighted in the report. ID verification can be activated for any assessment in proctoring settings, and it's turned off by default. To learn more about proctoring settings, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002987633-proctoring-settings).

#### Code quality in full stack questions

HackerEarth has introduced code quality in full stack questions for the React framework. The metrics generated are - Reliability, Security, and Maintainability. The code quality of an FS question will be available in the submission details section. To learn more about code quality in full-stack questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/code-quality). 

#### Lock/unlock questions (FaceCode)

HackerEarth has added a new capability to FaceCode interviews, allowing administrators to lock and unlock questions. This feature enables admins to restrict candidates from modifying their solutions to interview questions by locking the code editor. You can unlock questions at a later stage. To learn more, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/lock/unlock-questions-in-a-facecode-interview).

text:
Release notes: December 7, 2023
ID verification for Assessments
HackerEarth has added ID verification to the proctoring settings of assessments. When enabled, candidates are required to upload a valid photo ID before proceeding. The system verifies this ID by comparing it with a photo of the candidate. Any discrepancies are highlighted in the report. ID verification can be activated for any assessment in proctoring settings, and it's turned off by default. To learn more about proctoring settings, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: December 7, 2023

#### ID verification for Assessments

HackerEarth has added ID verification to the proctoring settings of assessments. When enabled, candidates are required to upload a valid photo ID before proceeding. The system verifies this ID by comparing it with a photo of the candidate. Any discrepancies are highlighted in the report. ID verification can be activated for any assessment in proctoring settings, and it's turned off by default. To learn more about proctoring settings, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002987633-proctoring-settings).

text:
Release notes: October 7, 2023
Keyword evaluation in subjective questions
HackerEarth has introduced a new evaluation type for subjective questions called Keyword evaluation. In this method, you can add keywords along with their respective scores, and if the candidate’s answer contains the exact keyword, the candidate is allocated the score assigned to that keyword. To learn more about the Keyword evaluation type, read this article. 
Full stack and DevOps questions now cover different skills
HackerEarth’s rich library of questions has now been rejuvenated with new skills being covered in our full stack and DevOps questions, including AI, LLM, Powershell, web scraping, etc. You can now assess candidates on these skills with the help of our full stack and DevOps questions. To learn more about our full stack questions, read this article.
Subjective file upload
HackerEarth has introduced a file upload option in subjective questions where you can ask the candidate to upload a file so that you can understand the candidate's approach to their submissions. This is recommended for Excel questions where you want to know the approach used by the candidate or if they have used the correct formula to get the answer. To learn more about subjective questions, read this article.
Improved front end question creation experience
We have now improved the way to create a front end question in a test. You can select the supported frameworks: Vanilla, React, and Angular. The experience has improved, and it is now easier to create a front end questions to assess candidates based on their front end skills. To learn more about how to create a front end question in a test, read this article. 
Improved automatic test creation
We have improved our automatic test creation based on the years of experience and skills provided. The assessment created based on the years of experience and skills mentioned will now contain more relevant questions and different question types such as MCQs, programming, selenium, full stack, DevOps questions, etc. To learn more about automatic test creation, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: October 7, 2023

### Keyword evaluation in subjective questions

HackerEarth has introduced a new evaluation type for subjective questions called Keyword evaluation. In this method, you can add keywords along with their respective scores, and if the candidate’s answer contains the exact keyword, the candidate is allocated the score assigned to that keyword. To learn more about the Keyword evaluation type, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/evaluation-of-subjective-questions#Keyword_evaluation). 

#### Full stack and DevOps questions now cover different skills

HackerEarth’s rich library of questions has now been rejuvenated with new skills being covered in our full stack and DevOps questions, including AI, LLM, Powershell, web scraping, etc. You can now assess candidates on these skills with the help of our full stack and DevOps questions. To learn more about our full stack questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/900002979943-full-stack-questions).

#### Subjective file upload

HackerEarth has introduced a file upload option in subjective questions where you can ask the candidate to upload a file so that you can understand the candidate's approach to their submissions. This is recommended for Excel questions where you want to know the approach used by the candidate or if they have used the correct formula to get the answer. To learn more about subjective questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/assessments-recruiters#subjective).

#### Improved front end question creation experience

We have now improved the way to create a front end question in a test. You can select the supported frameworks: Vanilla, React, and Angular. The experience has improved, and it is now easier to create a front end questions to assess candidates based on their front end skills. To learn more about how to create a front end question in a test, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/create-front-end-question-in-a-test).   

#### Improved automatic test creation

We have improved our automatic test creation based on the years of experience and skills provided. The assessment created based on the years of experience and skills mentioned will now contain more relevant questions and different question types such as MCQs, programming, selenium, full stack, DevOps questions, etc. To learn more about automatic test creation, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/12337541167513-creating-a-new-test).

text:
Release notes: September 7, 2023
Subjective evaluation
HackerEarth has introduced a new evaluation type for subjective questions called Keyword evaluation. In this method, you can add keywords along with their respective scores and if the candidate’s answer contains the exact keyword, the candidate is allocated the score assigned to that keyword. To learn more about the Keyword evaluation type, read this article. 
Global benchmarking
HackerEarth has introduced Global benchmarking that provides insights into a candidate's position within the broader HackerEarth developer community for their assessed skill. It presents the candidate's percentile compared to all other candidates who have taken the assessments. If you're interested in incorporating global benchmarking into your assessments, please reach out to us. 
Comparative skill scores
HackerEarth now offers Comparative Skill Scores, which indicate how many candidates achieved scores within a specific range for a particular skill. This feature enables you to categorize candidates into different skill levels, ranging from level 1 (highest) to level 4 (lowest) in various skills.
Linux and macOS support for Smart Browser
The Smart Browser now supports various operating systems including Linux and macOS. To see the complete list of supported operations systems, refer to this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: September 7, 2023

#### Subjective evaluation

HackerEarth has introduced a new evaluation type for subjective questions called Keyword evaluation. In this method, you can add keywords along with their respective scores and if the candidate’s answer contains the exact keyword, the candidate is allocated the score assigned to that keyword. To learn more about the Keyword evaluation type, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/evaluation-of-subjective-questions#Keyword_evaluation). 

#### Global benchmarking

HackerEarth has introduced Global benchmarking that provides insights into a candidate's position within the broader HackerEarth developer community for their assessed skill. It presents the candidate's percentile compared to all other candidates who have taken the assessments. If you're interested in incorporating global benchmarking into your assessments, please reach out to us. 

#### Comparative skill scores

HackerEarth now offers Comparative Skill Scores, which indicate how many candidates achieved scores within a specific range for a particular skill. This feature enables you to categorize candidates into different skill levels, ranging from level 1 (highest) to level 4 (lowest) in various skills.

#### Linux and macOS support for Smart Browser

The Smart Browser now supports various operating systems including Linux and macOS. To see the complete list of supported operations systems, refer to [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/advanced-proctoring-settings-smart-browser).

text:
Release notes: August 7, 2023
Download reports across tests
HackerEarth has added a new feature that helps you download custom reports across tests by selecting the range of dates. This solves the problem of requesting manual reports each time and also provides you with the information you need in a more user-friendly and streamlined format.
Improvements in the Instructions page (Candidate side)
HackerEarth has implemented notable updates to the Instructions page that is presented prior to the commencement of a test. We have worked on both User Interface (UI) refinements as well as revisions in the displayed content on the page. Our aim is to enhance the user experience and provide clearer guidance to participants as they start their assessment.
DevOps performance improvements
HackerEarth has introduced several performance enhancements in the DevOps IDE. The IDE now opens up faster as compared to the previous version. We have also significantly reduced the time to load all the dependencies to provide you with a seamless experience. We are working towards bringing more enhancements to our DevOps platform. To learn more about DevOps questions, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: August 7, 2023

#### Download reports across tests

HackerEarth has added a new feature that helps you download custom reports across tests by selecting the range of dates. This solves the problem of requesting manual reports each time and also provides you with the information you need in a more user-friendly and streamlined format.

#### Improvements in the Instructions page (Candidate side)

HackerEarth has implemented notable updates to the Instructions page that is presented prior to the commencement of a test. We have worked on both User Interface (UI) refinements as well as revisions in the displayed content on the page. Our aim is to enhance the user experience and provide clearer guidance to participants as they start their assessment.

#### DevOps performance improvements

HackerEarth has introduced several performance enhancements in the DevOps IDE. The IDE now opens up faster as compared to the previous version. We have also significantly reduced the time to load all the dependencies to provide you with a seamless experience. We are working towards bringing more enhancements to our DevOps platform. To learn more about DevOps questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/6318798000537-devops-questions).

text:
Release notes: July 7, 2023
Full stack performance improvements
HackerEarth has introduced several performance enhancements in the full stack platform. The full stack IDE now opens in less than 10 seconds making it all the faster. We have also significantly reduced the time to load all the dependencies to provide you with a seamless experience. We are working towards bringing more enhancements to our full stack platform. To learn more about full stack questions, read this article.
UI changes in the Assessments
HackerEarth has made changes to the header of the Assessments platform. The new User Interface (UI) is more intuitive and super-clean hence making it all the more user-friendly. We will be making more changes to the UI of the product in the coming days. 
Improvements in the Pre-assessment page 
HackerEarth has improved the design and content of the Pre-assessment page. The page now looks cleaner with much less but relevant content which will help the candidates to understand the instructions better.
Test report after the end of the assessment
HackerEarth has introduced a new test report after the end of the assessment for all the admins. This report will include all the data in the test analytics and will have a detailed report of all the candidates who have participated in the assessment. To learn more about test reports, read this article.
markdown:
# Release notes: July 7, 2023

### Full stack performance improvements

HackerEarth has introduced several performance enhancements in the full stack platform. The full stack IDE now opens in less than 10 seconds making it all the faster. We have also significantly reduced the time to load all the dependencies to provide you with a seamless experience. We are working towards bringing more enhancements to our full stack platform. To learn more about full stack questions, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/900002979943-full-stack-questions).

### UI changes in the Assessments

HackerEarth has made changes to the header of the Assessments platform. The new User Interface (UI)  is more intuitive and super-clean hence making it all the more user-friendly. We will be making more changes to the UI of the product in the coming days. 

### Improvements in the Pre-assessment page 

HackerEarth has improved the design and content of the Pre-assessment page. The page now looks cleaner with much less but relevant content which will help the candidates to understand the instructions better.

### Test report after the end of the assessment

HackerEarth has introduced a new test report after the end of the assessment for all the admins. This report will include all the data in the test analytics and will have a detailed report of all the candidates who have participated in the assessment. To learn more about test reports, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360009559394-test-analytics-overview).

text:
Release notes: June 7, 2023
Subjective questions in HackerEarth’s library
HackerEarth has added new subjective questions on various skills in HackerEarth’s library which can be auto-evaluated. There are questions available without answers too that need manual evaluation. To see the available questions, click here. You can also add your own subjective questions along with answers. To learn more about how to create a subjective question, read this article.
Custom skill test creation
HackerEarth has introduced the creation of custom skill tests in My library. You can now create custom skill tests in your library and add them to a learning path. To learn more about upskilling, read this article
Full stack questions supporting React Native

# Release notes: June 7, 2023

#### Subjective questions in HackerEarth’s library

HackerEarth has added new subjective questions on various skills in HackerEarth’s library which can be auto-evaluated. There are questions available without answers too that need manual evaluation. To see the available questions, click [here](https://app.hackerearth.com/recruiter/library/questions/?problemTypes=s). You can also add your own subjective questions along with answers. To learn more about how to create a subjective question, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006511414-creating-subjective-questions).

#### Custom skill test creation

HackerEarth has introduced the creation of custom skill tests in My library. You can now create custom skill tests in your library and add them to a learning path. To learn more about upskilling, read [this article](https://help.hackerearth.com/upskilling-introduction)

#### Full stack questions supporting React Native

These can be used to assess a candidate’s skills in developing a cross-platform mobile application, using JavaScript and React. text:
Release notes: 14th August
Recruiter New features 
Brand new help center
Our help center is up and running! We have help content for recruiters, candidates along with FAQs, product updates etc. Check it out here.
WYSIWYG all the way
We've switched to the WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) editor. It has become easier to create and format content for your test. From highlighting content to creating tables you can do everything much faster.
Skill-based tests
We've switched from role-based to skill-based tests. A role may require multiple skills. A test that is created based on skills gives you more flexibility in using the same test to assess for multiple roles.
Question-specific test instructions
We have introduced instructions specific to each question type in HackerEarth Recruit. The instructions are auto-generated based on the types of questions that are added to a test. The following instructions are displayed automatically:
General instructions: Instructions common to all tests. Candidates can view these instructions before starting a test. 
Question-specific instructions: Instructions based on the type of questions added to a test. 
Proctoring instructions: Instructions relevant to the proctoring settings made by you while creating the test.
Download the list of invited candidates
Now you can download the list of invited candidates from the Test dashboard.
Feature enhancements 
Skill-name list while creating a new automatic test
We've made this functionality more intuitive now. Suggestions are displayed on your screen as you start typing the name of a skill or question type. You can even enter any letter from the skill name and it will be displayed on the screen along with other names that contain the same letters or same sequence of letters.
New language support in the code editor
Swift 4.1 was added to the list of programming languages supported in the code editor.
HackerEarth Recruit is now GDPR compliant
HackerEarth Recruit was made GDPR compliant. This involved changing the Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and taking consent from users to send emails and updates.
Fixes 
We have fixed the issue with the dialog box of the All topics option in the HackerEarth Recruit Questions library.
Candidate New features 
Details about issues in the code editor
An alert is displayed to you when there are any issues in the test environment such as page loading, JavaScript error, etc. This also prompts to reload the page that fixes issues most of the times.
Enhanced test instructions
The test instructions in a test are rewritten based on the type of questions added in the test, which made the instructions much more useful and relevant to you.
Improvements 
Code player recording performance
The keystrokes entered by you are now recorded faster than before.
Theme of the code editor is changed
The default theme of the code editor has been made dark (black).
markdown:
# Release notes: 14th August

Recruiter New features

### _Brand new help center_

Our help center is up and running! We have help content for recruiters, candidates along with FAQs, product updates etc. Check it out [here.](https://help.hackerearth.com/)

### _WYSIWYG all the way_

We've switched to the WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) editor. It has become easier to create and format content for your test. From highlighting content to creating tables you can do everything much faster.

### _Skill-based tests_

We've switched from role-based to skill-based tests. A role may require multiple skills. A test that is created based on skills gives you more flexibility in using the same test to assess for multiple roles.

### _Question-specific test instructions_

We have introduced instructions specific to each question type in HackerEarth Recruit. The instructions are auto-generated based on the types of questions that are added to a test. The following instructions are displayed automatically:

*   **General instructions**: Instructions common to all tests. Candidates can view these instructions before starting a test.
*   **Question-specific instructions**: Instructions based on the type of questions added to a test.
*   **Proctoring instructions**: Instructions relevant to the proctoring settings made by you while creating the test.

### _Download the list of invited candidates_

Now you can download the list of invited candidates from the Test dashboard.

Feature enhancements

### _Skill-name list while creating a new automatic test_

We've made this functionality more intuitive now. Suggestions are displayed on your screen as you start typing the name of a skill or question type. You can even enter any letter from the skill name and it will be displayed on the screen along with other names that contain the same letters or same sequence of letters.

  

### _New language support in the code editor_

Swift 4.1 was added to the list of programming languages supported in the code editor.

### _HackerEarth Recruit is now GDPR compliant_

HackerEarth Recruit was made GDPR compliant. This involved changing the Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and taking consent from users to send emails and updates.

Fixes 

We have fixed the issue with the dialog box of the **All topics** option in the HackerEarth Recruit Questions library.

Candidate New features

### _Details about issues in the code editor_

An alert is displayed to you when there are any issues in the test environment such as page loading, JavaScript error, etc. This also prompts to reload the page that fixes issues most of the times.

### _Enhanced test instructions_

The test instructions in a test are rewritten based on the type of questions added in the test, which made the instructions much more useful and relevant to you.

Improvements

### _Code player recording performance_

The keystrokes entered by you are now recorded faster than before.

### _Theme of the code editor is changed_

The default theme of the code editor has been made dark (black).

text:
Release notes: November 7, 2023
Multiple domain support
HackerEarth has introduced multiple domain support in a single HackerEarth account. Large companies with several subsidiaries can now combine their usage of HackerEarth into one account. Additionally, now you can log in to the HackerEarth account using your email address, regardless of which domain it belongs to (either normal login or SSO if configured).
Resuing the custom tags
You can now reuse the custom tags created for a particular test. Previously, you needed to add the tags for each question, even if the tags had already been added to another question.
We have now started saving and recommending tags that have been added to the HackerEarth library and also by you in your own account. This will make it easier to find relevant questions for your assessments.
What’s new 
We have included a new option in the profile menu called What’s new!, which will show you the product release notes so that you do not miss any features that have been introduced in the month. This will help you stay updated on the new features introduced and updates done in the platform.
markdown:
# Release notes: November 7, 2023

### Multiple domain support

HackerEarth has introduced multiple domain support in a single HackerEarth account. Large companies with several subsidiaries can now combine their usage of HackerEarth into one account. Additionally, now you can log in to the HackerEarth account using your email address, regardless of which domain it belongs to (either normal login or SSO if configured).

### Resuing the custom tags

You can now reuse the custom tags created for a particular test. Previously, you needed to add the tags for each question, even if the tags had already been added to another question.

We have now started saving and recommending tags that have been added to the HackerEarth library and also by you in your own account. This will make it easier to find relevant questions for your assessments.

### What’s new 

We have included a new option in the profile menu called **What’s new!,** which will show you the product release notes so that you do not miss any features that have been introduced in the month. This will help you stay updated on the new features introduced and updates done in the platform.
